Aspis: Lightweight Neural Network Protection Against Soft Errors; This paper introduces Aspis, an efficient software protection scheme that provides a performance-reliability tradeoff for convolutional neural networks by using the Taylor criterion to pinpoint and selectively harden critical weights against soft errors in DRAM.

Scenario-based resilience assessment framework for critical infrastructure systems: Case study for seismic resilience of seaports; This paper proposes a probabilistic framework for scenario-based resilience assessment of infrastructure systems, which accounts for uncertainties in the entire process from hazard intensity to repair, and applies it to a hypothetical seaport terminal.

Development of a risk framework for forecasting earthquake losses in port systems; This paper presents a framework for the seismic risk management of a port-wide system that calculates losses by using spatially correlated ground motions to estimate damage to wharves and cranes, their subsequent repair costs and downtimes, and the resulting impact on operations.

Synthesis of trenchless technologies.; This study reviews the state of the practice for trenchless technologies in highway construction, concluding that while widely adopted, design guidelines and specifications vary significantly, and accurate subsurface characterization is critical for safety.

Framework for earthquake risk assessment for container ports; This paper provides an overview of concepts and methods developed for the seismic risk management of ports, focusing on system-wide disruptions caused by earthquake damage, which are not considered in current design practices.

A method of mapping sinkhole susceptibility using a geographic information system: a case study for interstates in the karst counties of Virginia; This study proposes using a geographic information system to create a sinkhole susceptibility map for Virginia's karst terrain by analyzing five geological and soil-related risk factors to pinpoint regions most at risk.

Design and Application of an Open-Science Electrical Resistivity Meter to Make Geotechnical Laboratory Education More Relevant and Engaging; This work proposes the design and validation of an intuitive, low-cost, open-source electrical resistivity meter for hands-on geotechnical education that accurately characterizes subsurface conditions in tabletop experiments.

Conceptualizing social justice in civil engineering and professors’ perspective: A systematic literature review; This paper argues that civil engineering curricula should integrate a focus on Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Justice to produce students with a stronger sense of social agency, addressing the current lack of human-centered learning environments and tools for professors.

Multimodal Transportation Facility Resilience Index; This project develops a graph theory-based methodology, which includes novel traffic volume-based weighting strategies, to determine the resilience index of a transportation infrastructure system and applies it to the highway network of Albemarle County, Virginia.

Using readily available data and GIS to map sinkhole risk in the Karst Counties of Virginia; This study proposes and tests a methodology for creating sinkhole susceptibility maps using readily available geographic information system data and five risk factors shown to accelerate sinkhole formation in the karst region of Virginia.

Understanding Host Network Stack Overheads; This paper presents a measurement study of the Linux kernel network stack at 100Gbps, revealing a fundamental shift in bottlenecks where previously insignificant overheads like lock contention and data structure access now dominate CPU utilization.

Network-Wide Heavy Hitter Detection with Commodity Switches; This paper presents a distributed heavy-hitter detection scheme for programmable switches that uses adaptive thresholds in the data plane to accurately identify network-wide heavy hitters with up to 70% savings in communication overhead.

{TCP}{≈}{RDMA}:{CPU-efficient} Remote Storage Access with i10; This paper presents i10, a new remote storage stack implemented entirely in the kernel that runs on commodity hardware and saturates a 100Gbps link with CPU utilization comparable to state-of-the-art user-space and RDMA-based solutions.

Towards s Tail Latency and Terabit Ethernet: Disaggregating the Host Network Stack; This paper presents NetChannel, a disaggregated network stack architecture that enables independent scaling of resources per layer, allowing a single application thread to saturate multi-hundred gigabit links and achieve near-linear scalability for small message processing.

dcPIM: Near-Optimal Proactive Datacenter Transport; This paper introduces Datacenter Parallel Iterative Matching (dcPIM), a transport design that leverages a new theoretical analysis to achieve near-optimal tail latency and network utilization with a constant number of control plane rounds.

Fast & Safe IO Memory Protection; To address significant performance degradation from state-of-the-art I/O memory protection, this paper presents Fast & Safe, a simple modification to existing IOMMU mechanisms that provides strong safety properties while achieving high performance.

Building Networked Systems for Terabit Ethernet; This paper argues that due to diverging hardware trends of rapidly increasing network bandwidth and stagnant CPU capacity, network performance bottlenecks have shifted from the network itself to the host network stacks responsible for packet processing.
High-throughput and Flexible Host Networking via Control and Data Path Physical Separation

Harmony: A Congestion-free Datacenter Architecture; This paper addresses the challenges posed by best-effort datacenter networks, where unpredictable queueing, delays, and drops introduce inefficiency and complexity into host hardware and software design.

OptORAMa: optimal oblivious RAM; This paper explores the long-standing open question of whether an optimal Oblivious RAM construction exists that matches the logarithmic lower bounds without making large memory word assumptions.

Doubly efficient private information retrieval and fully homomorphic RAM computation from ring LWE; This work constructs the first unkeyed, doubly efficient private information retrieval scheme, where the server can perform its own preprocessing, and proves its security under the standard ring learning-with-errors assumption.

Oblivious hashing revisited, and applications to asymptotically efficient ORAM and OPRAM; This paper revisits a prior O(log N)-overhead Oblivious RAM result, patches an incompleteness in its underlying Cuckoo hashing scheme, and then presents a new, simpler ORAM construction that achieves the same optimal asymptotic overhead.

Delegating RAM computations with adaptive soundness and privacy; This paper presents the first RAM delegation scheme that provides both soundness and privacy guarantees in the adaptive setting, where a user can delegate a sequence of computations over a persistent database to a server.

Cryptography for parallel RAM from indistinguishability obfuscation; This work demonstrates the design of asymptotically optimal cryptographic solutions for the Parallel RAM model of computation, including the first publicly verifiable delegation scheme with privacy in the persistent database setting, based on indistinguishability obfuscation.

A logarithmic lower bound for oblivious ram (for all parameters); This work proves a new lower bound for Oblivious RAM in a natural setting of parameters where previous bounds were trivial, specifically when the ORAM cell size is not much larger than the original cell size.

Black box crypto is useless for doubly efficient PIR; This paper shows that constructing secret-key doubly efficient private information retrieval from a large class of generic cryptographic primitives in a black-box way is impossible, suggesting that specific algebraic assumptions are necessary.

MegaBlocks: Breaking the Logarithmic I/O-Overhead Barrier for Oblivious RAM; This work presents a new hierarchical Oblivious RAM construction that closes a theoretical gap for the asymmetric setting and achieves practical performance with small constants and without requiring large local memory, significantly outperforming prior schemes.

Efficient Garbled Pseudorandom Functions and Lookup Tables from Minimal Assumption; This paper develops new techniques to construct efficient garbling schemes for specific functionalities like one-hot encoding and lookup tables using only minimal assumptions of standard pseudorandom functions, eliminating the need for circular security.

Doubly efficient cryptography: commitments, arguments and RAM MPC; This paper shows how to construct "doubly efficient" cryptographic schemes, such as commitments and MPC, in the plain model by using doubly efficient private information retrieval as a building block, allowing for sublinear online time after an offline preprocessing phase.

Computational design of peptides that target transmembrane helices; This paper describes a computational method for designing peptides that specifically target transmembrane helices, demonstrating its success by creating peptides that recognize the TM helices of two closely related integrins.

The structure and function of platelet integrins; This article discusses platelet integrins, particularly αIIbβ3, which binds fibrinogen and other proteins to mediate platelet aggregation, and notes that while poised to shift from a resting to an active state, the mechanism remains a key question.

Protein-protein interactions in the membrane: sequence, structural, and biological motifs; This review highlights how single-span transmembrane helices use specific sequence and structural motifs to direct protein complex assembly and mediate signal transduction, suggesting these interactions are potential therapeutic targets.

Evolution of Invasion in a Diverse Set of Fusobacterium Species; Using whole-genome sequencing and comparative analysis, this study investigates the evolution of active and passive invasion strategies in Fusobacterium species, inferring that active invasion followed an adaptive radiation involving new gene acquisition and expansions of gene families.

Single-enzyme biomineralization of cadmium sulfide nanocrystals with controlled optical properties; This paper reports the discovery of a single enzyme, a putative cystathionine γ-lyase (smCSE), that is capable of both catalyzing the mineralization of CdS and templating its growth into quantum-confined nanocrystals.

Optimizing Scaled up Production and Purification of Recombinant Hydrophobin HFBI in Pichia pastoris; This study reports an optimized, five-day, methanol-fed batch shake flask induction and single-step purification process for the recombinant expression of hydrophobin HFBI in Pichia pastoris, achieving yields of 86.6 mg/L.

Effect of Mutations on Smlt1473 Binding to Various Substrates Using Molecular Dynamics Simulations; This study uses molecular docking, molecular dynamics simulations, and machine learning to investigate the binding stability and molecular interactions of various substrates with the polysaccharide lyase Smlt1473 and two of its mutants.

Applying a polysaccharide lyase from Stenotrophomonas maltophilia to disrupt alginate exopolysaccharide produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa clinical isolates; This study investigates the potential of the polysaccharide lyase Smlt1473 from Stenotrophomonas maltophilia to degrade the exopolysaccharide alginate, a key factor in the antibiotic resistance and immune evasion of Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms.

Directed Evolution of Silicatein Reveals Biomineralization Synergism between Protein Sequences; This work investigates the catalytic mechanism of the biomineralization protein silicatein and uses directed evolution to generate mutant proteins with augmented activity for synthesizing metal oxide nanoparticles.

Integrating Bacteriocins and Biofilm-Degrading Enzymes to Eliminate L. monocytogenes Persistence; This study investigates a novel dual-action approach combining an engineered polysaccharide-degrading enzyme with a bacteriocin to effectively disrupt biofilms and inactivate Listeria monocytogenes, offering a potential alternative for enhancing food safety.

Cyborg maintenance: Design, breakdown, and inclusion; This paper critiques the utopic imaginaries of the Transhumanist movement by focusing on the ignored daily reality of maintenance for actual cyborgs, arguing that upkeep, rather than upgrading, will be the norm for cyborg bodies.

Engineering our selves: morphological freedom and the myth of multiplicity; This article poses a series of questions about human enhancement, asking readers to consider whether they would use technology to improve existing skills, gain new ones, or acquire abilities outside the current range of human capability.

Morphological freedom and the construction of bodymind malleability from eugenics to transhumanism; This dissertation critiques the goal of perfecting the human bodymind held by eugenicists and transhumanists, arguing instead for a philosophy of intra-dependence grounded in the lived experiences of non-normative people and agential realism.

Imagining Otherwise: The Importance of Speculative Fiction to New Social Justice Imaginaries; This book review discusses how Bodyminds Reimagined by Sami Schalk analyzes speculative fiction to illustrate the intersectional oppressions navigated by disabled women of color, using Octavia Butler's novel Kindred as a key example.

Cyborg-Technology Relations; Drawing from disability studies and crip technoscience, this paper advocates for a disability-forward philosophy of cyborg-technology relations that accounts for technoableism and listens to the experiences of existing disabled technology users.

The Problem of the Sexy Cyborg: The Ethics of Cyborg Imagery; This article argues that popular cyborg tropes in media—apotheosis and grotesquerie—reinforce problematic narratives about disabled people, connecting these images to eugenicist beliefs and resistance to social services.

Social Foundations of Education as a Model for Social Foundations of Engineering: Possibilities for Engaging the Philosophy of Engineering; This paper argues for the creation of a new field, social foundations of engineering, by drawing parallels with social foundations of education and identifying intellectual frameworks from STS, ethics, and social justice to build its conception.

Embodiment Diffracted: Queering and Cripping Morphological Freedom; This article critiques the transhumanist concept of Morphological Freedom, arguing that its insistence on treating everyone as an individual disregards the political and social power of shared embodiment, thus implicitly favoring the wealthy.

Deadnames and Missing Chiralities: A Response to Steve Fuller’s “The Problem of Cishumanism”; This article traces the origin and adoption of the term "cisgender," explaining its Latin roots, its use in chemistry to describe chirality, and its role in transgender activism to de-naturalize identity politics.

Microresonator soliton dual-comb spectroscopy; This paper demonstrates a miniature, soliton-based dual-comb system with high-coherence and broad spectral envelopes, showing the potential for integrated, chip-based spectroscopy with high signal-to-noise ratios and fast acquisition rates.

Soliton frequency comb at microwave rates in a high-Q silica microresonator; This work demonstrates soliton mode locking in high-Q silica resonators, which produce low-phase-noise soliton pulse trains at detectable rates, providing two essential properties for the operation of on-chip, self-referenced frequency combs.

Searching for exoplanets using a microresonator astrocomb; This paper demonstrates an atomic/molecular line-referenced Kerr soliton microcomb for the calibration of astronomical spectrographs, offering an ideal match for spectrograph resolution and a path towards compact systems for exoplanet detection.

Chaos-assisted broadband momentum transformation in optical microresonators; This paper reports the observation of broadband and fast momentum transformations of light in asymmetric whispering gallery microresonators, a phenomenon that enhances third-harmonic generation efficiency by over three orders of magnitude.

Bridging ultrahigh-Q devices and photonic circuits; This paper presents an integrated resonator with a record Q factor over 200 million, demonstrating its use in creating both soliton sources with electronic repetition rates and high-coherence Brillouin lasers, thereby bridging the gap between ultrahigh-Q performance and photonic integration.

Integrated Architecture for the Automated Generation and Coil Stabilization of a PZT-Enabled Microcomb; This paper demonstrates a simplified, stabilized dissipative Kerr soliton microcomb architecture using a single laser and a single-point electronic control to both generate and stabilize the comb to a coil-resonator reference, achieving low phase noise and high stability.

Photonic chip-based optical frequency division with PZT-integrated soliton microcombs; This work advances on-chip optical frequency division technology by using an integrated high-speed PZT actuator on a SiN soliton microcomb to rapidly tune and stabilize the comb, enabling low-noise millimeter-wave generation.

Microcavity Kerr optical frequency division with integrated SiN photonics; This paper demonstrates an ultralow-phase-noise millimeter-wave oscillator by leveraging integrated SiN photonic components, where a Kerr soliton microcomb is stabilized to a coil cavity to perform optical frequency division.

Low voltage, high speed PZT actuated Si3N4 microcombs for laser-tuning-free soliton generation and modulation; This paper demonstrates an integrated PZT SiN Kerr-microcomb that requires less than 10 Volts to initiate a 106.8 GHz soliton without laser frequency tuning, showing a significant improvement in actuation and modulation bandwidth.

Heterogeneous integration of a high-speed photodiode with microcavity solitons for on-chip mmWave generation; This paper presents a photonically driven on-chip millimeter-wave source, enabled by the heterogeneous integration of a high-speed photodiode and silicon nitride microcavity solitons, that delivers 98 GHz signals with low phase noise.

Using LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT and LEJOS in an advanced software engineering course; This paper describes the benefits of using LeJOS and the Lego Mindstorms NXT set for teaching advanced software development concepts like threading and network communications in a simulated production environment.

From domain models to architecture frameworks; This paper discusses how domain analysis helped create reusable architectures and components for a real-time embedded system in the domain of portable wireless communication devices, highlighting differences from typical framework development processes.

Computing classification system 1998: current status and future maintenance report of the CCS Update Committee; This article reports on the substantial revision of the ACM Computing Classification System (CCS) to reflect the changed nature of computing, describing the changes and proposing processes for future updates.

The Effectiveness of the Stylometry of Function words in Discriminating between Shakespeare and Fletcher; This study evaluates the effectiveness of statistical language analysis for determining authorship in Elizabethan and Jacobean drama by analyzing word usage in plays by Shakespeare and Fletcher to develop procedures for attributing scenes in collaborative works.

Architecting for domain variability; This paper discusses how domain analysis led to the creation of reusable architectures and components in Motorola's FLEX™ Kernel, a set of components for developing portable wireless communication devices.

How student surveys drive change: using the data buddies department report from the computing research association; This panel provides examples of how faculty use the Data Buddies Survey, administered by the Computing Research Association, to refine, expand, and evaluate initiatives for broadening participation in computing.

Hazard Mitigation Planning for Utilities: Forming Partnerships for Leveraging Resources and Funding Opportunities; This document outlines the necessity and process for water and wastewater utilities to engage in hazard mitigation planning, which is required for federal grant eligibility and essential for protecting functionality and minimizing recovery costs from disasters.

Teaching second-level Java and software engineering with Android; This tutorial proposal outlines a plan to help educators incorporate the Android OS platform into second-year Java and software engineering courses, based on beneficial experiences from five course sessions at two universities.

Role of larger software artifacts in introductory computer science courses; This paper compares a conventional lecture-based approach with one using larger software artifacts and guided exercises to teach introductory computer science concepts, assessing impacts on student self-confidence and knowledge.

RAPTOR: Routing Attacks on Privacy in Tor; This paper presents Raptor, a suite of new attacks by Autonomous Systems that exploit Internet routing asymmetries, churn, and BGP hijacks to compromise Tor user anonymity, and proposes monitoring frameworks to counter them.

Bamboozling certificate authorities with {BGP}; This paper rigorously analyzes and demonstrates how network-level adversaries can exploit BGP vulnerabilities to obtain bogus certificates from top Certificate Authorities, and proposes countermeasures like multi-vantage point verification and BGP monitoring.

Counter-RAPTOR: Safeguarding Tor against active routing attacks; To mitigate and detect active BGP routing attacks against Tor, this paper presents a new measurement study on network resilience, proposes a new guard relay selection algorithm that improves client security, and describes a live BGP monitoring system.
Securing internet applications from routing attacks; This sentence states that both application-layer and network-layer defenses are critical for fortifying against routing attacks.

Tempest: Temporal dynamics in anonymity systems; This paper presents Tempest, a suite of novel attacks based on temporal dynamics like client mobility and network routing changes, which are shown to severely degrade user privacy across a wide range of anonymity networks including Tor.

Scaling SCIERA: A Journey Through the Deployment of a Next-generation Network; This paper presents key lessons learned from deploying the SCION Education, Research, and Academic (SCIERA) network infrastructure, which was built to facilitate native SCION connectivity for applications and enhance deployment scalability at academic sites.

RPKI-Based Location-Unaware Tor Guard Relay Selection Algorithms; This paper proposes and evaluates new location-unaware guard relay selection algorithms for Tor that leverage the Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) to defend against routing attacks with minimal performance overhead.

Exploring the Ecosystem of DNS HTTPS Resource Records: An End-to-End Perspective; This paper presents the first longitudinal study on the adoption of the DNS HTTPS resource record, analyzing both server-side deployment trends and client-side browser support, while highlighting challenges in its deployment.

Mutual TLS in Practice: A Deep Dive into Certificate Configurations and Privacy Issues; By analyzing over a billion mutual TLS connections from a large campus network, this study quantifies the prevalent use of untrusted certificates and uncovers security concerns arising from misconfigurations, certificate sharing, and long expirations.

Intercepting Bluetooth Traffic from Wearable Health Devices; This work investigates active attacks that intercept Bluetooth connections between wearable health devices and smartphones, finding that several popular devices are vulnerable due to a lack of security mechanisms, allowing adversaries to extract health data from encrypted packets.

A learning platform for SQL injection; This paper presents a hands-on, extensible web application system with 12 levels designed to teach university students about various SQL injection vulnerabilities and how to exploit them.

Hobbits: Hadoop and Hive based Internet traffic analysis; This paper presents Hobbits, a Hadoop and Hive based traffic analysis system that performs scalable IP and TCP analysis of large-sized Internet traffic, outperforming previous solutions in both job completion time and storage efficiency.

MapReduce-based deep learning with handwritten digit recognition case study; This research improves the accuracy of handwritten digit recognition by implementing a Convolutional Neural Network with elastic distortion and enhances efficiency by using a distributed implementation on a Spark cluster.

Who needs help? Automating student assessment within exploratory learning environments; This article describes the development of a regression model that successfully estimates student assessments in an exploratory medical diagnosis tutor, demonstrating a technique that can direct teachers' attention to students in need of help.

Prediction of enzyme mutant activity using computational mutagenesis and incremental transduction; This paper proposes an incremental transductive method using Delaunay tessellation and random forests to predict enzyme mutant activity during mutagenesis, showing significantly better performance than one-shot learning methods.

How many words does it take to understand a low-resource language?; This study is the first to evaluate the minimum documentation needed for transfer learning in low-resource languages, finding that sentence embedding performance accelerates with a vocabulary size of 1000 or less and levels off around 25,000.

ASCI: AI-Smart Classroom Initiative; This paper presents the Artificial Intelligence Smart Classroom Initiative, a re-imagined set of interoperable online course tools including a smart office hours queue, an automatic grouping algorithm, and a local LLM, designed to support growing computer science classes.

Towards more efficient office hours for large courses: Using cosine similarity to efficiently construct student help groups; This poster introduces a novel office hours queue feature that automatically groups students based on the cosine similarity of their reported issues, with simulations showing significant decreases in wait time on the busiest days.

Providing a Choice of Time Trackers on Online Assessments; This semester-long study investigated student preferences for online quiz timers in computer science courses, finding that while timer choice did not impact performance, students preferred graphical representations like a color-changing progress bar.

Empowering Diabetes Patients by Providing Machine Learning-Driven Predictions and Personalized Visualization Results; This project created an end-to-end platform that uses a Random Forest model with 95.6% accuracy to predict early-stage diabetes and then visualizes patient data for users with similar symptoms to facilitate health conversations.

An introduction to sequential dynamical systems; This chapter provides the formal definition of sequential dynamical systems (SDS) and begins the study of systems where the update order is a permutation of the vertex set of the underlying graph.

Elements of a theory of simulation II: sequential dynamical systems; This paper studies a class of sequential dynamical systems defined by a graph, vertex update functions, and a permutation-based update ordering, deriving a decomposition result, characterizing invertibility, and analyzing fixed points.

Discrete, sequential dynamical systems; This paper studies a class of discrete dynamical systems called sequential dynamical systems (SDS), which are defined by a graph, a set of local update functions, and a permutation ordering, and analyzes their invertibility and the number of non-isomorphic systems.

Elements of a theory of simulation III: Equivalence of SDS; This paper analyzes a class of discrete sequential dynamical systems, providing a combinatorial upper bound for the number of non-equivalent systems, a full characterization of invertible systems, and an analysis of fixed points.

Epidemiological and Economic Impact of COVID-19 in the US; This research combines a detailed disease model with a model of the US economy to estimate the non-linear trade-offs between economic losses and lives saved under different COVID-19 lockdown scenarios.

Pandemics in Silico: Scaling Agent-Based Simulations on Realistic Social Contact Networks; This work presents Loimos, a scalable parallel framework for simulating epidemic diffusion on large social contact networks, which uses a hybrid of time-stepping and discrete event simulation implemented on the Charm++ runtime.

DIMPLES: Distributed Influence Maximization for Pandemic pLanning on Exascale Systems; This paper presents exascale parallel algorithms for influence maximization that can process a realistic US social contact network of 285 million nodes, achieving a two-orders-of-magnitude improvement over the state-of-the-art.

Epihiper—A high performance computational modeling framework to support epidemic science; This paper describes EpiHiper, a high-performance computational modeling framework that supports custom disease models and user-programmable interventions on dynamic, large-scale social contact networks for studying epidemic science.

A Scalable Game-theoretic Approach to Urban Evacuation Routing and Scheduling; This paper presents a game-theoretic approach to the computationally hard problem of large-scale evacuation routing and scheduling by formulating a strategic game where every instance has a Nash equilibrium and an optimal outcome is always an equilibrium.

Role of heterogeneity: National scale data-driven agent-based modeling for the US COVID-19 Scenario Modeling Hub; This paper uses the national-scale agent-based model UVA-EpiHiper to study the role of heterogeneity on model complexity and epidemic dynamics, discussing its impact on model initialization, calibration, and analysis for the US COVID-19 Scenario Modeling Hub.

Autonomous vehicles on the edge: A survey on autonomous vehicle racing; This paper presents the first holistic survey of research in autonomous racing, covering the algorithms, methods, and approaches used in perception, planning, control, and end-to-end learning for high-performance race vehicles.

MLE+ a tool for integrated design and deployment of energy efficient building controls; This paper presents MLE+, a tool that leverages EnergyPlus and Matlab to facilitate the integrated design, co-simulation, and analysis of energy-efficient building automation and control systems.

Forecasting groundwater table in a flood prone coastal city with long short-term memory and recurrent neural networks; This study explores the use of LSTM and RNN machine learning models to forecast groundwater table response to storm events in the coastal city of Norfolk, Virginia, finding that LSTM networks trained on storm-only data perform best in real-time forecasting scenarios.

Training machine learning surrogate models from a high‐fidelity physics‐based model: Application for real‐time street‐scale flood prediction in an urban coastal community; This study explores the potential of a Random Forest machine learning method to serve as a computationally efficient surrogate for physics-based models in predicting real-time, street-scale urban pluvial flooding in coastal cities.

F1/10: An open-source autonomous cyber-physical platform; This paper presents F1/10, an open-source, affordable, and high-performance 1/10 scale autonomous vehicle testbed designed to augment research and education in autonomous systems and make the field more accessible.

DBF-MA: A Differential Bayesian Filtering Planner for Multi-Agent Autonomous Racing Overtakes; This work presents a derivative-free approach to trajectory synthesis for autonomous racing overtakes, framing the problem as one of Bayesian Inference over Composite Bezier Curves which successfully outperforms existing methods in closed-loop analysis.

Probabilistic Collision Risk Estimation through Gauss-Legendre Cubature and Non-Homogeneous Poisson Processes; This paper introduces the Gauss-Legendre Rectangle (GLR) algorithm, a principled two-stage integration method that accurately estimates collision risk for autonomous racing overtakes by accounting for vehicle geometry and trajectory uncertainty, outperforming state-of-the-art baselines.

HALO: Fault-Tolerant Safety Architecture For High-Speed Autonomous Racing; This paper presents a comprehensive overview of the HALO safety architecture for a full-scale autonomous racing vehicle, including a failure mode analysis and runtime monitoring methods to mitigate risks from various software and hardware faults.

Trajectory-to-Action Pipeline (TAP): Automated Scenario Description Extraction for Autonomous Vehicle Behavior Comparison; This paper introduces the Trajectory-to-Action Pipeline (TAP), a scalable and automated method for extracting Scenario Description Language labels from large trajectory datasets to support AV safety analysis and edge case detection.

Foreword for ICCPS’24 Special Issue; This special issue contains a selection of original papers extending earlier results from the 15th ACM/IEEE International Conference on Cyber-Physical Systems (ICCPS), covering various aspects of CPS research with both methodological rigor and practical impact.

50-kHz-rate 2D imaging of temperature and H2O concentration at the exhaust plane of a J85 engine using hyperspectral tomography; This paper introduces and demonstrates hyperspectral tomography, a novel laser diagnostic technique capable of simultaneous 2D imaging of temperature and water-vapor concentration at up to 50 kHz in a practical aero-propulsion engine.

Thermal management of cylindrical batteries investigated using wind tunnel testing and computational fluid dynamics simulation; This work presents a combined numerical and experimental study on the air-cooling of a lithium-ion battery pack, developing and validating a 2D CFD model that accurately captures the cooling dynamics under various practical flow conditions.

Tomographic imaging of temperature and chemical species based on hyperspectral absorption spectroscopy; This paper reports the development and demonstration of a novel tomography technique based on hyperspectral absorption spectroscopy that enables simultaneous imaging of temperature and species concentration with a reduced number of projections.

Combined experimental and numerical study of thermal management of battery module consisting of multiple Li-ion cells; This work studies the thermal management of a multi-cell Li-ion battery module both experimentally in a wind tunnel and computationally with a high-fidelity 2D CFD model, obtaining reasonable agreement between simulations and measurements.

Numerical and experimental validation of a three-dimensional combustion diagnostic based on tomographic chemiluminescence; This work discusses a 3D diagnostic based on tomographic chemiluminescence, developing a hybrid reconstruction algorithm and an experimental approach to quantify its accuracy and spatial resolution for resolving 3D flame structures.

Correction of Beam Steering for Optical Measurements in Turbulent Reactive Flows; This work investigated and demonstrated a method using a guiding laser to correct for beam steering effects, significantly enhancing the accuracy of particle image velocimetry measurements in turbulent reactive flames.

In situ imaging of 4D fire events in a ground vehicle testbed using customized fiber-based endoscopes; This work describes the design and implementation of a customized fiber-based endoscope setup to overcome limited optical access and enable four-dimensional flame measurements within a ground vehicle testbed to study fire dynamics.

3D tomography integrating view registration and its application in highly turbulent flames; This work extended the reconstruction integrating view registration (RIVR) method to 3D measurements of highly turbulent reactive flows, demonstrating that it effectively enhances the reconstruction accuracy of thin flame fronts and key flame properties.

Development of a Two-Dimensional Thermal Model for Li-Ion Battery Pack With Experimental Validation; This paper reports the development and validation of a two-dimensional two-states model for real-time analysis of thermal behaviors in large-scale Li-ion battery packs, filling a niche between computationally expensive detailed models and 1D lumped models.

Regularized tomographic PIV for incompressible flows based on conservation of mass; To reduce uncertainties in 3D3C velocity measurements, this work developed a regularized tomographic particle image velocimetry method that significantly enhances accuracy by incorporating the conservation of mass into the reconstruction process.

Deepcache: Principled cache for mobile deep vision; This paper presents DeepCache, a principled cache design for deep learning inference in continuous mobile vision that exploits temporal locality in video streams to improve model execution efficiency without requiring model modification.

A first look at deep learning apps on smartphones; This paper presents the first empirical study on 16,500 popular Android apps, using a new static tool to demystify how they exploit deep learning, what they use it for, and what their models look like.

How far can client-only solutions go for mobile browser speed?; Leveraging a large web usage dataset, this paper examines client-only solutions for improving mobile browser speed, finding that a new approach called speculative loading can significantly improve performance where caching and prefetching are limited.

Characterizing smartphone usage patterns from millions of android users; This paper presents an empirical analysis of app usage behaviors from millions of users of a leading Android marketplace in China, revealing interesting patterns in app management activities and network traffic generation.

Why are web browsers slow on smartphones?; By examining the internals of web browsers on smartphones, this work finds that over half of visited webpages are not mobile-optimized and that resource loading, not compute-intensive operations, contributes most to browser delay.

Proto: A Guided Journey through Modern OS Construction; This paper introduces Proto, a new instructional OS that runs on commodity hardware and uses an incremental, app-driven approach to teach modern OS features through engaging, media-rich applications.

Profiling Large Language Model Inference on Apple Silicon: A Quantization Perspective; This paper investigates Apple Silicon's unified memory architecture for on-device LLM inference, finding through extensive benchmarks that its large unified memory makes it both cost-effective and efficient against NVIDIA GPUs for ultra-large models.

WhisperFlow: speech foundation models in real time; This paper presents WhisperFlow, a novel framework that uses both model and system optimizations to enable efficient processing of streaming speech on resource-constrained client devices using large speech foundation models like Whisper.

A Journey of Modern OS Construction From boot to DOOM; This paper describes VOS, a first-of-its-kind instructional OS that runs on commodity hardware and uses an "inverse engineering" method to teach modern OS features through the progressive enabling of engaging, media-rich apps.

AnA: An Attentive Autonomous Driving System; This paper proposes AnA, a system that refactors autonomous driving systems to guide perception with driving knowledge, reducing collisions by 2x and compute usage by 44% on challenging benchmarks.

Full Paper: Exploratory Look at First-Year Engineering Students Sense of Belonging and Belonging Uncertainty; This exploratory study investigates the complex correlations between sense of belonging, belonging uncertainty, and other factors like engineering identity and use of support resources among first-year engineering students.

Comparing Project-Based Learning (PBL) Approaches in BIM Education: Student-Identified vs. Industry-Provided Projects; This study explores the effectiveness of two distinct project-based learning approaches—Student-Identified and Industry-Provided—in an introductory Building Information Modeling course, finding that both were effective but a hybrid model may be optimal.

Assessing the Effectiveness of Educational Interventions on Digital Skills for Middle Schoolers in Underserved Communities. The TechSpark Immokalee Case Study on Digital …; This study evaluates the effectiveness of educational interventions, contextualized around future construction industry careers, in enhancing the awareness and interest of middle school students from an underrepresented community in developing digital skills.

Personal Values to Foster the Inclusion of Minority-Owned Subcontractor Firms in the Procurement of Construction Services: A Preliminary Study; This study explores whether priming universalism values in construction project owners can increase the perceived importance of including underrepresented firms when selecting a general contractor, testing the hypothesis on a sample of engineering and architecture students.

Synergizing Case-Based Learning and Industry Involvement in a CEM Course–A Case Study; This paper synthesizes lessons learned from developing and teaching a Case-Based Learning course in Construction Engineering and Management with industry partners, identifying factors that foster student learning and highlighting the benefits of practitioner interaction.

Boundary layer turbulence and flow structure over a fringing coral reef; This study measured velocity and turbulence across a fringing coral reef, finding that drag coefficients over coral were three to five times greater than over a sandy bottom, with a local balance between turbulent kinetic energy production and dissipation.

Wave and tidally driven flows in eelgrass beds and their effect on sediment suspension; This study quantifies how an eelgrass bed alters its hydrodynamic environment, finding that it reduces near-bottom mean velocities by 70-90% and wave heights by 45-70% compared to an adjacent unvegetated region.

The Sponge Pump: The Role of Current Induced Flow in the Design of the Sponge Body Plan; By quantifying the pumping activity and respiration of the glass sponge Aphrocallistes vastus, this study reveals that the energetic cost of pumping is much higher than previously estimated, suggesting that current-induced passive flow is highly beneficial.

Benthic flow environments affect recruitment of Crassostrea virginica larvae to an intertidal oyster reef; This study collected velocity and turbulence data over various intertidal surfaces to determine how benthic flow affects oyster larval recruitment, finding that the natural oyster reef had significantly higher hydrodynamic roughness and turbulence compared to restoration sites.

Wave attenuation by oyster reefs in shallow coastal bays; This study demonstrates that restored intertidal oyster reefs can effectively attenuate wave energy in shallow coastal bays, reducing wave heights by an average of 30-50% under various tidal and wind conditions.

Performance Evaluation of Natural and Nature-Based Features for Coastal Protection and Co-Benefits; This review identifies and synthesizes long-term monitoring data from a selection of natural and nature-based features projects to provide a literature-based performance evaluation and better inform their design criteria for coastal protection.

The turbulent soundscape of intertidal oyster reefs; By making side-by-side turbulence and soundscape measurements over oyster reefs, this study found a significant relationship between flow noise and turbulent kinetic energy, suggesting that reef turbulence and sounds may attract oyster larvae in complementary ways.

Spectral Wave Energy Dissipation by a Seagrass Meadow; By comparing field observations with different prediction models, this study shows that accounting for canopy flow modifications and seagrass flexibility is crucial for accurately predicting wave dissipation in dense seagrass meadows.

Utilizing GIS-based multi-criteria decision analysis to map flooding and assess vulnerability of the mobility impaired in the coastal-urban community of Norfolk, Virginia; This research applies a GIS-based multicriteria decision analysis to Norfolk, VA, to understand the impacts of urban stormwater flooding on disabled populations and help target resources for hazard mitigation and emergency response.

Monolithic germanium/silicon avalanche photodiodes with 340 GHz gain–bandwidth product; This paper reports a monolithically grown germanium/silicon avalanche photodetector with a record-high gain–bandwidth product of 340 GHz and a sensitivity of −28 dBm at 10 Gb/s, rivaling commercial III–V compound devices.

Microstructured silicon photodetector; This paper reports on photodetectors fabricated on microstructured silicon that exhibit high responsivities of 92 A/W at 850 nm and 119 A/W at 960 nm, explained by a proposed generation-recombination gain mechanism.

Thermal treatment studies of the photoluminescence intensity of porous silicon; Through concurrent photoluminescence and infrared spectroscopy studies, this work concludes that the SiH2 surface species is essential to the visible luminescence in porous Si, as its desorption coincides with a sharp reduction in PL intensity.

Correlation between silicon hydride species and the photoluminescence intensity of porous silicon; This study shows that the appearance of silicon dihydride (SiH2) on the surface of porous Si coincides with an increase in photoluminescence intensity, in contrast to the weak luminescence observed with predominant silicon monohydride (SiH) termination.

Recent advances in telecommunications avalanche photodiodes; This paper provides a brief review of avalanche photodiode fundamentals and describes significant advances in materials and device structures that have improved their performance for high-bit-rate, long-haul fiber optic communications.

Matrix quantum kinetic treatment of impact ionization in avalanche photodiodes; This paper develops a matrix-based quantum kinetic theory for impact ionization that goes beyond the conventional Born approximation, enabling the microscopic treatment of electron-electron scattering essential for modeling avalanche photo-diodes.

Extended wavelength photodiodes in the B-III–V material system; This paper reports the epitaxial growth, fabrication, and characterization of nearly strain-free, all-BGaInAs pin photodiodes on GaAs substrates, demonstrating that boron incorporation effectively reduces strain while extending the operating wavelength.

Edge-coupled digital alloy AlInAsSb SPAD with high avalanche breakdown probability; This work simulates and experimentally characterizes an edge-coupled, 1550 nm AlInAsSb-based single-photon avalanche detector, reporting avalanche breakdown probabilities greater than 85% at an over-bias of less than 2.5%.

Ternary-containing Al0.7InAsSb digital alloys on InP and InP-on-Si; This work investigates the growth of AlInAsSb digital alloys on both InP and InP-on-Si templates, confirming high-quality material and achieving low dark currents and high gains from PIN diodes grown on both substrates.

A passivation study for AlInAsSb avalanche photodiodes; This study systematically compares the impact of different passivation techniques on the performance of AlInAsSb p-i-n avalanche photodiodes, finding that ALD-Al2O3 deposited at 200 °C is most effective at suppressing dark current.

Elucidating the contribution of mobile hydrogen-deformation interactions to hydrogen-induced intergranular cracking in polycrystalline nickel; By coupling mechanical testing with targeted microscopy, this study shows that mobile hydrogen-deformation interactions are not an intrinsic requirement for hydrogen-induced intergranular fracture in nickel, as it also occurs at cryogenic temperatures where such interactions are precluded.

Effect of corrosion severity on fatigue evolution in Al–Zn–Mg–Cu; Using crack surface marker-band analysis and a fracture mechanics model, this study establishes that the substantial reduction in fatigue life of pre-corroded 7075-T6511 is nearly independent of corrosion exposure time after an initial sharp degradation.

Driving forces for localized corrosion‐to‐fatigue crack transition in Al–Zn–Mg–Cu; This research on fatigue crack formation from a corroded 7075-T651 surface reveals that the process involves a complex interaction of elastic stress concentration from pit macro-topography and plastic strain concentration from local micro-topography.

On the suitability of slow strain rate tensile testing for assessing hydrogen embrittlement susceptibility; Through a combined experimental and modeling approach, this study indicates that hydrogen diffusion alone is insufficient to explain observed intergranular fracture depths in a Ni-Cu superalloy, with phase field simulations suggesting that sub-critical crack growth begins early in the failure process.

Measurement and modeling of hydrogen environment-assisted cracking in Monel K-500; This study quantifies hydrogen environment-assisted cracking of Monel K-500 using slow-rising stress intensity loading, finding that the alloy is susceptible to intergranular cracking under cathodic polarization and that this susceptibility correlates with a critical crack tip diffusible hydrogen concentration.

Effect of Laser Surface Treatment on the Distribution of Beta Phase and Intermetallic Particles and the Surface Integrity of AA5456 Alloy; This study examines how fiber laser surface treatment (LST) affects the distribution of β phase and intermetallic particles, as well as the surface integrity and defect formation, in the corrosion-susceptible AA5456 aluminum alloy.

Methods for Regulating Depth of Corrosion Fissures in Simulated Fastener Holes of 7050-T7451 Aluminum Alloy; This study presents a new test method for inducing controlled corrosion fissures in simulated fastener holes of 7050-T7451 aluminum alloy, finding that galvanic coupling with an SS316 cathode significantly accelerates corrosion compared to chemical exposure alone.
Guest Editorial for the special issue on" Understanding hydrogen-materials interactions"

The role of hydrogen-metal interactions in hydrogen environmentally assisted cracking susceptibility in additively manufactured 17-4 PH stainless steel; This study examines the role of hydrogen-metal interactions in the cracking susceptibility of additively manufactured 17-4 PH stainless steel, revealing that AM alloys have lower diffusible hydrogen content but increased hydrogen diffusivity compared to wrought materials.
Corie L. Cobb Named a 2024 Fellow of the National Academy of Inventors

Principal geodesic analysis for the study of nonlinear statistics of shape; This paper develops the method of principal geodesic analysis to describe population variability for complex geometric shapes represented by medial axis parameters, which lie in a nonlinear Riemannian symmetric space rather than a Euclidean vector space.

Functional connectivity magnetic resonance imaging classification of autism; This study uses whole-brain resting-state fMRI to characterize functional connectivity abnormalities in autism, demonstrating that a machine learning classifier can distinguish individuals with autism from controls with high accuracy, suggesting its potential as a diagnostic metric.

Riemannian geometry for the statistical analysis of diffusion tensor data; This paper proposes using Riemannian geometry for the statistical analysis of diffusion tensor data, developing methods for computing averages and modes of variation that preserve the positive-definite constraint of the tensors.

Deformable M-Reps for 3D Medical Image Segmentation; This paper describes the use of deformable m-reps, a multiscale medial representation, to effectively capture prior geometric information for the segmentation of anatomic objects in 3D medical images.

Longitudinal changes in cortical thickness in autism and typical development; To clarify age-related brain development in autism, this large longitudinal study examines changes in cortical thickness over time in autistic and typically developing males using MRI scans.

RealDeal: Enhancing Realism and Details; This work proposes RealDeal, an image-to-image diffusion model that enhances the realism of generated brain MRIs by adding fine anatomical details, sharp edges, and realistic imaging noise.

MedIL: Generating Arbitrary-Resolution Medical Images with Implicit Latent Spaces; The paper introduces MedIL, a novel autoencoder that uses implicit neural representations to generate medical images at arbitrary resolutions, preserving fine details without prior resampling.

RealDeal: Enhancing Realism and Details in Brain Image Generation via Image-to-Image Diffusion Models; This work proposes RealDeal, an image-to-image diffusion model that enhances the realism of generated brain MRIs by adding fine anatomical details, sharp edges, and realistic imaging noise.

LDDMEm: Large Deformation Diffeomorphic Metric Embedding: Decoupling Shape Analysis from Image Registration; This paper presents LDDMEm, a method and software that decouples diffeomorphic shape analysis from image registration by embedding arbitrary deformation vector fields into the LDDMM framework.

Point-based shape representation generation with a correspondence-preserving diffusion model; This work proposes a novel diffusion model designed to generate realistic point-based shape representations that preserve point correspondences, as demonstrated on hippocampal shape data.

Locally differentially private protocols for frequency estimation; This paper introduces a generalized framework for Local Differential Privacy (LDP) protocols, leading to two new optimized protocols that provide better utility for frequency estimation.

Privacy at scale: Local differential privacy in practice; This tutorial surveys the technical underpinnings, current research, and open problems of Local Differential Privacy (LDP) as used in practice by major technology organizations.

When machine unlearning jeopardizes privacy; This paper investigates the unintended privacy risks of machine unlearning by proposing a novel membership inference attack that exploits model output differences to infer if a data sample was removed.

Locally differentially private frequent itemset mining; This paper proposes SVIM and SVSM, two new protocols for locally differentially private frequent item and itemset mining in set-valued data, which significantly improve utility over existing methods.

Graph unlearning; This paper proposes GraphEraser, a novel machine unlearning framework for graph data that uses new graph partitioning algorithms and a learning-based aggregation method to preserve model utility.

Network-Aware Differential Privacy; This paper initiates the new research direction of network-aware differential privacy, identifying opportunities at the intersection of networking and DP related to network security and topology.

White-box Membership Inference Attacks against Diffusion Models; This paper designs a highly effective white-box membership inference attack against diffusion models by using model gradients as the attack feature, achieving near-flawless performance.

From easy to hard: Building a shortcut for differentially private image synthesis; This work proposes a two-stage, curriculum learning-inspired framework for differentially private image synthesis that first trains a diffusion model on simple "central images" before fine-tuning with DP-SGD.

Benchmarking differentially private tabular data synthesis; This paper proposes a unified benchmark for differentially private tabular data synthesis, revealing a significant utility-efficiency trade-off among state-of-the-art methods.

DPImageBench: A Unified Benchmark for Differentially Private Image Synthesis; This paper introduces DPImageBench, a unified benchmark for differentially private image synthesis that corrects flawed evaluation protocols and reveals key findings, such as the variable impact of pretraining.

Operationalising competencies in higher education for sustainable development; This chapter advocates for case study research as a reliable and credible methodology for analyzing social situations in higher education for sustainable development.

Anticipatory life-cycle assessment for responsible research and innovation; This paper argues that traditional Life-Cycle Assessment (LCA) is ineffective for responsible research and innovation (RRI) and calls for an anticipatory approach that is not retrospective and emphasizes stakeholder engagement.

Illustrating anticipatory life cycle assessment for emerging photovoltaic technologies; This paper introduces a novel framework for anticipatory Life Cycle Assessment (LCA) that incorporates technology forecasting and social engagement to guide emerging technologies like photovoltaics toward lower environmental burdens.

Sustainability Education Framework for Teachers: Developing sustainability literacy through futures, values, systems, and strategic thinking; This paper presents the Sustainability Education Framework for Teachers (SEFT), which uses four interconnected ways of thinking—futures, values, systems, and strategic—to build sustainability literacy.

Acquisition of T-shaped expertise: an exploratory study; This paper explores the concept of "T-shaped" expertise for complex problem-solving and presents an exploratory study evaluating its emergent attributes in two different STEM educational programs.

The Myths of Regional Innovation: Sustainability Challenges and Responsible Innovation; Drawing on extensive interviews, this book dispels three common myths about regional innovation and proposes a new assessment method that incorporates sustainability and social values beyond simple economic growth.

How did STEM students respond to a cross-campus discussion forum about macroethics? An exploratory content analysis of students’ written reflections; This research uses content analysis to explore how STEM students from different universities responded to a cross-campus online discussion forum focused on societal and global level macroethics.

Divergence and Convergence in Engineering Leadership, Entrepreneurship, Management, and Policy; This paper uses a mixed-methods approach to identify areas of convergence, such as program design, and divergence between the ASEE divisions for engineering leadership and entrepreneurship.
Practical Information

Investigating innovation ecosystems for wearable medical devices; This paper reviews literature on innovation ecosystems to develop a more robust model for wearable medical devices that addresses the trade-offs between profitability and health outcomes.

Compositional effects of additively manufactured refractory high-entropy alloys under high-energy helium irradiation; This letter investigates the response of additively manufactured refractory high-entropy alloys to helium ion bombardment, showing that compositional complexity can limit helium bubble effects.

Strain modulation using defects in two-dimensional; This study investigates how defects introduced by ion irradiation can be used to tune both tensile and compressive strain in two-dimensional MoS2, identifying sulfur vacancies as the most favorable defect type.

Controlling neutral and charged excitons in MoS2 with defects; This work uses heavy ion irradiation and photoluminescence spectroscopy to demonstrate that defect densities in two-dimensional MoS2 can be controlled to tailor optical properties by binding excitons.

Non‐Linear Optics at Twist Interfaces in h‐BN/SiC Heterostructures; This paper demonstrates a scalable approach to achieve twist-dependent properties by growing nanocrystalline hexagonal boron nitride on silicon carbide, yielding strong non-linear optical effects and low thermal conductivity.

Effect of the catalyst metal content and the carbon support on proton-exchange membrane fuel cells performance and durability; This study systematically investigates the effect of Pt catalyst metal content and carbon support type on PEMFC performance and durability, finding that local Pt content is more important than average content for durability.

Tip-Induced Etching and Vacancy Island Evolution on 2H-TaS2 Revealed by STM; Using scanning tunneling microscopy, this study reveals and quantifies the tip-induced etching and linear growth kinetics of vacancy islands on 2H-TaS2, a first step toward scanning probe nanolithography.

Atomic-resolution spectroscopic analysis of magnons in 2D materials; This work uses monochromated electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) in a scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) to perform atomic-resolution spectroscopic analysis of magnons in 2D antiferromagnetic Fe2O3.

Atomic-Scale Exciton Binding Energy Determination of Defected Transition Metal Dichalcogenides; This study proposes using multiple advanced characterization tools to obtain both localized optical and structural data for atomic-scale determination of exciton binding energy in defected 2D semiconductors.

Phonon Damping in Amorphous Nitrides and Oxides Observed with Vibrational EELS; This work proposes using localized vibrational EELS to study phonon damping in amorphous materials by decoupling the contributions of boundary scattering and anharmonic interactions.

Immobilization of Escherichia coli RNA Polymerase and Location of Binding Sites by Use of Chromatin Immunoprecipitation and Microarrays; Using chromatin immunoprecipitation and microarrays (chIP-chip), this study determined the genome-wide location of 1,139 RNA polymerase binding sites in Escherichia coli, including 721 previously unknown sites.

Genome-Scale Analysis of the Uses of the Escherichia coli Genome: Model-Driven Analysis of Heterogeneous Data Sets; This study presents an in silico, model-driven analysis of heterogeneous data for the entire Escherichia coli genome, estimating promoter strengths and revealing large-scale chromosomal organization.

Sequence-based analysis of metabolic demands for protein synthesis in prokaryotes; This paper develops a scalable formalism to analyze the metabolic demands of protein synthesis in prokaryotes, which can be integrated with existing genome-scale metabolic models.

Long-range periodic patterns in microbial genomes indicate significant multi-scale chromosomal organization; Using wavelet analysis, this study detects significant long-range periodic patterns in 163 microbial chromosomes, indicating that a nonrandom, multi-scale organization is linked to genome size and composition.

BME Labs in the Era of COVID-19: Transitioning a Hands-on Integrative Lab Experience to Remote Instruction Using Gamified Lab Simulations; This paper describes and assesses the transition of a hands-on biomedical engineering lab to remote instruction during COVID-19 using asynchronous lectures and gamified simulations.

BOARD# 293: Reflection on Outcomes Data from Eight Years of a Summer REU Site in Systems Bioengineering and Biomedical Data Sciences; This paper reflects on eight years of outcomes from a summer REU Site in systems bioengineering and biomedical data sciences, highlighting the need to train a diverse workforce in quantitative skills for "big data" analysis.

REU Site: Multi-Scale Systems Bioengineering and Biomedical Data Sciences; This abstract describes a three-year REU Site focused on multi-scale systems bioengineering and biomedical data sciences, which combines experimentation with computational analysis to train undergraduates in disease research.

Board 7: Work in Progress: A Collaborative, Principle-focused Curriculum Design Process for a BME Undergraduate Program; This work-in-progress paper describes a collaborative, principle-focused curriculum design process for a BME undergraduate program aimed at addressing new ABET outcomes like ethics and inclusivity.

Physicochemical principles driving small molecule binding to RNA; This work uses a large dataset of RNA-small molecule binding data to derive physicochemical "STaR rules" that define a chemical space enriched for RNA binders to accelerate drug discovery.

The Effect of In-Person versus Pre-recorded Final Presentations on Student Learning Outcomes and Engagement; This preliminary study evaluates student learning outcomes and engagement by comparing pre-recorded versus in-person final presentations in a Systems Bioengineering course.

Opportunities and obstacles for deep learning in biology and medicine; This paper reviews applications of deep learning in biology and medicine, finding that while promising, it has yet to revolutionize the field due to unique challenges posed by complex biomedical data.

Feature squeezing: Detecting adversarial examples in deep neural networks; This paper proposes feature squeezing, an inexpensive strategy to detect adversarial examples in deep neural networks by comparing model predictions on original and feature-reduced inputs.

Random forest for bioinformatics; This chapter reviews the Random Forest (RF) machine learning technique, highlighting its advantages for bioinformatics in handling small sample sizes, high-dimensional feature spaces, and complex data structures.

Textattack: A framework for adversarial attacks, data augmentation, and adversarial training in nlp; This paper introduces TextAttack, a modular Python framework for adversarial attacks, data augmentation, and adversarial training in NLP designed to democratize research and improve model robustness.

Black-box Generation of Adversarial Text Sequences to Evade Deep Learning Classifiers; This paper presents DeepWordBug, a black-box algorithm that generates adversarial text by applying character-level transformations to important words, effectively evading deep learning classifiers.

Zero-knowledge LLM hallucination detection and mitigation through fine-grained cross-model consistency; This paper presents Finch-Zk, a black-box framework that detects and mitigates LLM hallucinations without external knowledge by using fine-grained cross-model consistency checking.

AIDE: Attribute-Guided MultI-Hop Data Expansion for Data Scarcity in Task-Specific Fine-tuning; This paper proposes AIDE, a novel data synthesis framework that uses an attribute-guided, multi-hop process to expand a small seed dataset for task-specific LLM fine-tuning.

Reward Is Enough: LLMs Are In-Context Reinforcement Learners; This work demonstrates that reinforcement learning emerges in LLMs at inference time, proposing a multi-round "ICRL prompting" framework where the model improves its responses by maximizing a scalar reward signal.

Hierarchical Prompt Decision Transformer: Improving Few-Shot Policy Generalization with Global and Adaptive Guidance; This paper introduces a hierarchical prompting approach for decision transformers that uses retrieval augmentation to learn global and adaptive soft tokens for context-aware, few-shot policy generalization.

Augmented Adversarial Trigger Learning; This work proposes ATLA, an augmented adversarial trigger learning method that uses a weighted loss to more efficiently learn generalizable jailbreak prompts and extract system prompts from LLMs.

Seismic response control using shape memory alloys: a review; This article provides an extensive review of the use of shape memory alloys (SMAs) for seismic response control in civil structures, covering their unique properties, material models, and applications.

Application of semi-active control strategies for seismic protection of buildings with MR dampers; This study proposes two semi-active control methods, a direct adaptive control method and a neuro-fuzzy controller, for the seismic protection of buildings using MR dampers.

Optimal design of superelastic‐friction base isolators for seismic protection of highway bridges against near‐field earthquakes; This study performs a sensitivity analysis to determine the optimal design parameters for a novel superelastic-friction base isolator (S-FBI) used for seismic protection of highway bridges.

Seismic assessment of bridge structures isolated by a shape memory alloy/rubber-basedisolation system; This paper performs a sensitivity analysis to assess the effectiveness of a shape memory alloy (SMA)/rubber-based isolation system for the seismic protection of bridges against near-field earthquakes.

Evaluation of the performance of a sliding-type base isolation system with a NiTi shape memory alloy device considering temperature effects; This paper investigates the seismic performance of a sliding-type base isolation system with a shape memory alloy (SMA) device, considering temperature effects and using a genetic algorithm for optimization.

Development of a latticed long-stroke SMA bar restrainer for seismic protection of bridges; This paper proposes and analyzes a latticed long-stroke restrainer with buckling-restrained shape memory alloy (SMA) bars (LLSR) that significantly enhances stability for seismic protection of bridges.

Evaluating Contributions of Emerging Technologies to Civil Infrastructure System Resilience. I: A Decision-Making Workflow; This paper presents a decision-making workflow, in the form of a logic graph, to evaluate how an emerging technology contributes to the resilience of a civil infrastructure system.

Evaluating Contributions of Emerging Technologies to Civil Infrastructure System Resilience. II: Case Studies; Following Part I's proposal of a qualitative workflow for evaluating emerging technologies, this paper presents a graph-theoretic analysis of the workflow and applies it to several case studies in civil engineering.

Experimental characterization of superelastic friction dampers with a focus on cyclic response, failure behavior and reparability; This study experimentally investigates the cyclic response, failure behavior, and reparability of a hybrid superelastic friction damper (SFD) that combines shape memory alloy cables with a friction-based system.

Shake Table Testing on a Four-Story Steel Frame Building with Shape Memory Alloy Cable Braces; This study explores the performance of a promising self-centering shape memory alloy (SMA) cable bracing system through shake table tests on a four-story steel frame building.

Teaching through a global pandemic: educational landscapes before, during and after COVID-19; This working group paper explores lessons learned from the shift to online learning during the COVID-19 pandemic to imagine a post-pandemic academic landscape and improve future teaching practices in computing education.

Gender and engagement in CS courses on piazza; This study analyzes student engagement by gender on the Piazza online discussion forum to investigate whether women are less likely to participate in computer science courses where they are a minority.

Stop reinventing the wheel! promoting community software in computing education; This working group paper explores why instructor-developed computing education tools see limited adoption, hypothesizing that discoverability, adaptability, and institutional barriers contribute to the constant reinvention of software.

Educational Landscapes during and after COVID-19; This working group explores the educational shift caused by the COVID-19 pandemic, aiming to identify valuable new practices that can be carried forward to improve post-pandemic teaching in computing education.

How do students collaborate? Analyzing group choice in a collaborative learning environment; This observational study analyzes the collaboration trends of 189 students in a computer science algorithms course, offering insight into how group size and membership evolve when students are given freedom to self-select.

Student Outcomes When Provided Programming Language Choice in an Algorithms Course; This study examines the programming language preferences and performance of 268 students in an upper-level algorithms course to understand student outcomes when given a choice of language.

Escaping the CS Dungeon: Modern College Curricula within and Beyond Computing; This study surveys instructors at 50 large public universities to explore how and where computing is integrated into STEM and non-STEM undergraduate programs for non-majors.

Auto-grading in Computing Education: Perceptions and Use; This paper surveys 44 computer science instructors on their use of auto-graders, finding a preference for customizable tools and a need for integrated solutions with robust core features and extensibility.

Kinematic and injury response of reclined PMHS in frontal impacts; To define biofidelity targets for human surrogates in reclined postures, this study evaluated the kinematic and injury response of five reclined post-mortem human subjects (PMHS) in frontal sled tests.

Submarining sensitivity across varied anthropometry in an autonomous driving system environment; This study uses frontal crash finite element simulations to investigate how occupant size, seat recline, and knee bolster position affect submarining risk and injury metrics for reclined occupants.

Submarining sensitivity across varied seat configurations in autonomous driving system environment; This study uses frontal crash finite element simulations to investigate how seat cushion angle affects submarining risk and lumbar spine loads for reclined occupants in autonomous driving environments.

Occupant safety in automated vehicles-effect of seatback recline on occupant restraint; This study performs a preliminary assessment of two occupant FE models to examine restraint interactions, kinematics, and protection challenges for reclined occupants in frontal collisions in automated vehicles.

Thoracolumbar spine kinematics and injuries in frontal impacts with reclined occupants; This study uses postmortem human subjects (PMHS) in frontal impact sled tests to investigate the kinematics and mechanisms of thoracolumbar spine loading and injury for reclined occupants.

Microstructure of the anterior iliac Spine: Identification of trends and relation to fracture tolerance; This study evaluates local bone microstructural properties at the anterior iliac spine using micro-CT to better understand the wide variation in iliac wing fracture tolerance under seatbelt loading.

Female and Combined Male–Female Injury Risk Functions for the Anterior Pelvis Under Frontal Lap Belt Loading Conditions; This study explores female iliac wing fracture tolerance under frontal lap belt loading and combines the data with previous male data to develop new, more robust injury risk functions for the anterior pelvis.

Evaluation of lap belt-pelvis load transfer in frontal impact simulations using finite element occupant models; This study uses a DOE with three finite element occupant models to examine the relationship between lap belt tension and force at the iliac wing, developing preliminary transfer functions to predict pelvic loads.

Assessing the Ability of Pressure Sensors Inserted into Intervertebral Discs to Detect Compression, Flexion, and Combined Flexion+ Compression Loading; This study evaluates the effectiveness of pressure sensors inserted into lumbar intervertebral discs of postmortem human subjects for detecting compression, flexion, and combined loading conditions in simulated vehicle crashes.

Restraint of Design for Obese Occupants: Rear-Seat Simulations [Second of Four Parts]; This study evaluates the biofidelity of obese human body models by comparing their kinematics to obese postmortem human surrogates in frontal sled tests, using a finite element model of the test buck to define boundary conditions.

HAMLET: A Hierarchical Multimodal Attention-based Human Activity Recognition Algorithm; This paper introduces HAMLET, a hierarchical deep neural network for multimodal human activity recognition that uses a novel attention mechanism to fuse spatio-temporal features for robust robot collaboration.

Movement coordination in human–robot teams: a dynamical systems approach; This paper presents a new dynamical systems approach for human-robot teams that enables a robot to perceive human group motion, anticipate future actions, and contingently coordinate its own movements.

Multi-GAT: A Graphical Attention-based Hierarchical Multimodal Representation Learning Approach for Human Activity Recognition; This work introduces Multi-GAT, a graphical attention-based approach for human activity recognition that hierarchically learns complementary multimodal features and uses a novel message-passing mechanism to capture cross-modal relations.

Human Robot Teaming: Approaches from Joint Action and Dynamical Systems; This chapter discusses recent work, applications, and practical challenges in human-robot teaming, drawing on approaches from joint action and dynamical systems to achieve fluent coordination.

Activity recognition in manufacturing: The roles of motion capture and sEMG+inertial wearables in detecting fine vs. gross motion; This study investigates the efficacy of motion capture versus wearable sensors for recognizing fine and gross-grained human motion in manufacturing, finding that motion capture yielded higher accuracy for both.

FuseCodec: Semantic-Contextual Fusion and Supervision for Neural Codecs; This paper introduces FuseCodec, a neural codec for speech tokenization that unifies acoustic, semantic, and contextual representations through strong cross-modal alignment and globally informed supervision to achieve state-of-the-art performance.

Energy-Based Transformers are Scalable Learners and Thinkers; This paper introduces Energy-Based Transformers (EBTs), a new class of models that enable System 2 Thinking by framing prediction as energy minimization, demonstrating faster scaling and improved performance on language and vision tasks.

A Data Capture and Gesture Recognition System to Enable Human-Robot Collaboration; This paper introduces a novel gesture recognition system for human-robot collaboration that leverages a vision-language model guided by retrieval-augmented generation and chain-of-thought to improve adaptability and accuracy.

Using Physiological Measures, Gaze, and Facial Expressions to Model Human Trust in a Robot Partner; This work is the first to use physiological measures, gaze, and facial expressions from an in-person, human-robot supervisory interaction study to model and predict human trust in a robot partner.

A fault injection technique for VHDL behavioral-level models; This article describes a technique for injecting faults into a system's VHDL behavioral-level model to perform early, simulation-based evaluation of fault tolerance for safety-critical systems.

Dependability metrics to assess safety-critical systems; This paper develops two new dependability metrics for the assessment of safety-critical systems: steady-state safety (S_ss) and the Mean Time To Unsafe Failure (MTTUF).
