Quantifying Explanatory Inversion in Post-Hoc Model Explanations; This paper introduces Inversion Quantification (IQ), a framework to quantify the degree to which post-hoc explanations rationalize predictions from the output, and proposes Reproduce-by-Poking (RBP) to mitigate this explanatory inversion.

A Survey of Scaling in Large Language Model Reasoning; This survey provides a comprehensive examination of scaling in LLM reasoning, categorizing it into multiple dimensions and analyzing how different scaling strategies contribute to improving reasoning capabilities.

Text classification algorithms: A survey; This paper provides a brief survey of text classification algorithms, covering feature extraction, dimensionality reduction, existing techniques, and evaluation methods, and discusses their limitations and real-world applications.

Hdltex: Hierarchical deep learning for text classification; This paper introduces HDLTex, a hierarchical deep learning approach for text classification that employs stacks of deep learning architectures to provide specialized understanding at each level of the document hierarchy.

Rmdl: Random multimodel deep learning for classification; This paper introduces Random Multimodel Deep Learning (RMDL), a new ensemble, deep learning approach for classification that solves the problem of finding the best deep learning architecture while improving robustness and accuracy.

Using mobile sensing to test clinical models of depression, social anxiety, state affect, and social isolation among college students; This study uses mobile sensing (GPS) and in-situ self-reports to test clinical models of how state affect, depression, and social anxiety are associated with time spent at home among college students.

Patient2vec: A personalized interpretable deep representation of the longitudinal electronic health record; This paper proposes Patient2Vec, a computational framework that learns an interpretable deep representation of longitudinal electronic health record (EHR) data, personalized for each patient, to predict future hospitalizations.

WatchAnxiety: A Transfer Learning Approach for State Anxiety Prediction from Smartwatch Data; This paper presents WatchAnxiety, a transfer learning approach that uses smartwatch data to predict state anxiety in socially anxious college students, achieving 60.4% balanced accuracy in a real-world evaluation.

SocialPulse: An On-Smartwatch System for Detecting Real-World Social Interactions; This paper presents SocialPulse, a real-time, on-smartwatch system that uses transfer learning to detect both in-person and virtual social interactions from foreground speech and conversational cues.

Advances and Open Problems in Federated Learning; This monograph discusses recent advances in federated learning (FL), a decentralized machine learning setting, and presents an extensive collection of open problems and challenges in the field.

Feature Squeezing: Detecting Adversarial Examples in Deep Neural Networks; This paper proposes feature squeezing, a new strategy to harden deep neural networks by detecting adversarial examples through a comparison of model predictions on original and feature-reduced inputs.

Localization for Mobile Sensor Networks; This paper introduces the sequential Monte Carlo Localization method for mobile sensor networks, arguing that it can exploit mobility to improve the accuracy and precision of localization without additional hardware.

Faster Secure Two-Party Computation Using Garbled Circuits; This paper demonstrates several techniques for improving the efficiency of the garbled-circuit technique for secure two-party computation, resulting in an implementation that is significantly faster and more scalable than previous approaches.

Using Directional Antennas to Prevent Wormhole Attacks; This paper analyzes wormhole attacks in wireless networks and proposes a cooperative protocol using directional antennas to prevent them by having nodes share directional information.

Pitfalls in Evaluating Inference-time Methods for Improving LLM Reliability; This paper evaluates the replicability and generalizability of inference-time methods for improving LLM reliability, finding that while promising, their performance varies significantly across different domains, tasks, and base models.

Do Prevalent Bias Metrics Capture Allocational Harms from LLMs?; This work examines the reliability of prevalent bias metrics in assessing allocational harms from LLMs, finding that they fail to reliably capture group disparities in allocation outcomes.

Steering the CensorShip: Uncovering Representation Vectors for LLM "Thought" Control; This paper uses representation engineering to study censorship in LLMs, presenting a method to find a refusal-compliance vector that can detect and control the level of censorship in model outputs.

Inferring Events from Time Series using Language Models; This paper conducts the first study of whether Large Language Models (LLMs) can infer natural language events from time series data, evaluating 18 LLMs on a new sports-based benchmark.

Sensing and Steering Stereotypes: Extracting and Applying Gender Representation Vectors in LLMs; This paper adapts representation engineering techniques to study gender representation in LLMs, introducing a new method to extract and steer concept representations to mitigate gender bias.

Widar3.0: Zero-Effort Cross-Domain Gesture Recognition with Wi-Fi; This paper proposes Widar3.0, a Wi-Fi-based zero-effort cross-domain gesture recognition system that derives and extracts domain-independent features of human gestures from wireless signals.

Widar2.0: Passive human tracking with a single Wi-Fi link; This paper presents Widar2.0, the first Wi-Fi-based system that enables passive human localization and tracking using a single link on commodity devices by leveraging multi-dimensional signal parameters.

Widar: Decimeter-level passive tracking via velocity monitoring with commodity Wi-Fi; This paper proposes Widar, a Wi-Fi-based tracking system that simultaneously estimates a human's moving velocity and location at a decimeter level by building a theoretical model of CSI dynamics.

Enabling contactless detection of moving humans with dynamic speeds using CSI; This article proposes a novel scheme for device-free passive detection of moving humans using Channel State Information (CSI) from multi-antenna Wi-Fi systems, exploring the full potential of both frequency and space diversity.

Inferring motion direction using commodity Wi-Fi for interactive exergames; This work presents WiDance, a Wi-Fi-based user interface for interactive exergames that extracts complete motion-induced Doppler shifts from commodity Wi-Fi to infer motion direction without training.

Toward Spoofing-Resilient and Communication-Integrated MmWave Radar Sensing; This paper presents SCR, a new spoofing-resilient and communication-integrated radar sensing scheme that uses a novel chirp configuration and signal processing pipeline to reliably detect spoofing and communication signals.

Radio Frequency Ray Tracing with Neural Object Representation for Enhanced RF Modeling; This paper introduces RFScape, a novel framework that bridges neural scene representation and RF propagation modeling by learning per-object electromagnetic properties for flexible and accurate scene composition.

Rfcanvas: Modeling rf channel by fusing visual priors and few-shot rf measurements; This paper proposes RFCanvas, a framework that fuses visual priors and few-shot RF measurements to accurately and responsively model RF channel propagation in dynamic environments.

Keystub: A passive rfid-based keypad interface using resonant stubs; This paper introduces KeyStub, a passive RFID-based keypad interface that uses multiple resonant stubs to discriminate discrete keystrokes by creating predefined impedance mismatches detectable by a commodity reader.

Neuroradar: A neuromorphic radar sensor for low-power iot systems; This paper proposes NeuroRadar, a neuromorphic radar sensor that jointly optimizes analog hardware and a spiking neural network computation model to achieve low-power wireless sensing for IoT systems.

Insights into the biodegradation of weathered hydrocarbons in contaminated soils by bioaugmentation and nutrient stimulation; This microcosm study investigates the biodegradation of weathered hydrocarbons in contaminated refinery soils, finding that biostimulation with nutrients and bioaugmentation with degraders significantly reduced hydrocarbon fractions.

Enhanced biodegradation of phenol by a microbial consortium in a solid–liquid two phase partitioning bioreactor; This work demonstrates the enhanced biodegradation of phenol by a mixed microbial population in a solid-liquid two-phase partitioning bioreactor (TPPB) using solid EVA polymer beads.

Learning to organise risk management in organisations: what future for enterprise risk management?; This paper argues that Enterprise Risk Management (ERM) is weakly rooted in organizational theory and identifies key aspects for its empirical study, including risk commensuration, portfolio comprehensiveness, and communication.

Management of petroleum hydrocarbon contaminated sites in Nigeria: Current challenges and future direction; This paper reviews the current challenges in managing petroleum hydrocarbon contaminated sites in Nigeria, highlighting fragmented regulatory instruments and the need for appropriate, risk-based policy.

Assessing bioavailability of complex chemical mixtures in contaminated soils: Progress made and research needs; This review analyzes the science and regulatory inclusion of bioavailability in assessing complex chemical mixtures in contaminated soils, identifying challenges and research needs for improving risk assessment frameworks.

Recovery of infauna macrobenthic invertebrates in oil-polluted tropical soft-bottom tidal flats: 7 years post spill; This 7-year post-spill study monitored the recovery of infauna macrobenthic invertebrates in an oil-polluted tidal flat, finding a change in community structure and an improvement in species richness and number.

Linking bioavailability and toxicity changes of complex chemicals mixture to support decision making for remediation endpoint of contaminated soils; This laboratory study uses an integrated approach to show that compost and biochar amendments to contaminated soils significantly affect the bioavailability and toxicity of complex chemical mixtures, providing evidence for remediation end-point assessment.

Prediction of bioavailability and toxicity of complex chemical mixtures through machine learning models; This study uses empirical data from a mesocosm experiment to assess the ability of artificial neural network and random forest models to predict temporal bioavailability changes and toxicity of complex chemical mixtures in amended soils.

Insights into mixed contaminants interactions and its implication for heavy metals and metalloids mobility, bioavailability and risk assessment; This 12-month mesocosm experiment investigates the effect of physicochemical factors and weathering on heavy metal and metalloid fractionation in multi-contaminated soils, providing insights into their mobility and bioavailability.

Stakeholder engagement and the sustainable environmental management of oil-contaminated sites in Nigeria; This chapter presents a case study of the Niger Delta, showing how constructive stakeholder engagement can be used to integrate community values into environmental regulation and sustainable development for oil-contaminated sites.

Bewell: A smartphone application to monitor, model and promote wellbeing; This paper presents BeWell, a comprehensive smartphone application that automatically tracks sleep, physical activity, and social interactions to monitor multi-dimensional wellbeing and provide intelligent feedback.

Toss'n'turn: smartphone as sleep and sleep quality detector; This study explores using smartphone sensors to detect sleep states and quality by collecting one month of data from 27 users. The resulting models achieved high accuracy in classifying sleep state, daily sleep quality, and overall sleep quality, with individual models outperforming general ones.

Bewell: Sensing sleep, physical activities and social interactions to promote wellbeing; This article presents BeWell+, an enhanced smartphone app that monitors sleep, physical activity, and social interaction to promote wellbeing through ambient feedback on the device's wallpaper. The new version introduces community-adaptive feedback and wellbeing-adaptive energy allocation to address limitations of the original app.

Identifying behavioral phenotypes of loneliness and social isolation with passive sensing: statistical analysis, data mining and machine learning of smartphone and fitbit data; This study investigates using passive sensing data from smartphones and Fitbits to infer loneliness levels and identify corresponding behavioral patterns in college students. Using statistical analysis, data mining, and machine learning on data from 160 students, the research successfully extracted behavioral patterns associated with loneliness.

Detecting depression and predicting its onset using longitudinal symptoms captured by passive sensing: a machine learning approach with robust feature selection; This study presents a machine learning approach using passive sensing data from smartphones and fitness trackers of 138 college students to detect and predict depressive symptoms. The novel feature extraction technique achieved high accuracy in identifying students with depressive symptoms and predicting their onset 11-15 weeks in advance.

4.3 Evaluation of MoodRing Passive Mood Monitoring Application on Improving Quality of Depression Management in Adolescents; This pilot randomized controlled trial evaluates MoodRing, a mobile application that uses passively collected smartphone data to provide symptom feedback and coping strategies for adolescents with depression. The study aims to determine if the app, which includes components for the adolescent, parent, and clinician, improves the quality of depression management compared to treatment as usual.

Characterization and Feasibility of Wearable Spectroscopic Tracking of Nutrition Biomarkers; This study explores the feasibility of using a multiwavelength optical sensor in an off-the-shelf wearable device to noninvasively track nutritional biomarkers in the blood. The device's ability to measure spectral absorption profiles of various nutrients is compared against a spectrophotometer to assess its potential for real-time dietary monitoring.

Predicting The Severity of Anxiety in Adolescents Through Passively Sensed Behaviors; This 24-week study investigates whether the severity of anxiety in 55 adolescents can be predicted using passively sensed behaviors from Fitbits and mobile phones. The research finds that anxiety can be predicted with a low mean absolute error, with phone usage, mobility, and activity behaviors being particularly useful predictors.

SAINT: Attention-Based Modeling of Sub-Action Dependencies in Multi-Action Policies; This paper introduces the Sub-Action Interaction Network using Transformers (SAINT), a novel policy architecture for reinforcement learning in combinatorial action spaces. SAINT represents multi-component actions as unordered sets and models their dependencies using self-attention, consistently outperforming strong baselines in complex combinatorial environments.

Student Receptiveness to Circadian-Aware AI-Driven Scheduling; This paper investigates the desirability of a circadian-aware, AI-driven scheduling application for college students by evaluating prototypes with varying levels of circadian awareness. While students overwhelmed by time management found the tool less helpful, the results indicate that students are receptive to AI schedulers that consider their circadian rhythms.

Photoacoustic image-guided delivery of plasmonic-nanoparticle-labeled mesenchymal stem cells to the spinal cord; This work presents a combined ultrasound and photoacoustic imaging tool to provide real-time, image-guided delivery and monitoring of nanoparticle-labeled stem cells into the spinal cord. The system successfully guided needle placement and detected as few as 1000 gold nanosphere-tagged stem cells during delivery.

Development of a stem cell tracking platform for ophthalmic applications using ultrasound and photoacoustic imaging; This study develops an ultrasound/photoacoustic (US/PA) imaging platform for the longitudinal tracking of stem cells delivered to the trabecular meshwork (TM) of the eye as a potential glaucoma therapy. Mesenchymal stem cells labeled with gold nanospheres were successfully injected and visualized in ex vivo porcine eyes, demonstrating the platform's potential to expedite clinical translation.

Improving stem cell delivery to the trabecular meshwork using magnetic nanoparticles; This study demonstrates that labeling mesenchymal stem cells with magnetic Prussian blue nanocubes (PBNCs) allows for magnetically steered delivery to the trabecular meshwork (TM) in the eye. This targeted approach significantly increased the delivery of stem cells to the entire circumference of the TM, a potential therapeutic strategy for glaucoma.

Gold nanoparticles conjugated with DNA aptamer for photoacoustic detection of human matrix metalloproteinase-9; This paper presents a photoacoustic contrast agent for detecting human matrix metalloproteinase-9 (MMP-9) in the tumor microenvironment using gold nanospheres functionalized with a DNA aptamer. The aggregation of these nanospheres in the presence of MMP-9 enhances the near-infrared optical absorption, enabling sensitive and selective detection via ultrasound-guided photoacoustic imaging.

Prussian blue nanocubes as a multimodal contrast agent for image-guided stem cell therapy of the spinal cord; This study develops a multimodal imaging approach using ultrasound, photoacoustic, and magnetic resonance imaging augmented with Prussian blue nanocubes (PBNCs) to guide and monitor stem cell therapies in the spinal cord. The technique enabled real-time needle guidance and detection of low concentrations of PBNC-labeled stem cells in ex vivo rat models.

Ultrasound and photoacoustic imaging of cancer; This chapter reviews the role and advantages of ultrasound (US) and photoacoustic (PA) imaging for cancer detection, therapy guidance, and monitoring. It summarizes the key principles of this hybrid multimodal approach, which combines the benefits of optics and acoustics to provide both morphological and functional feedback.

Monitoring the immune/tumor microenvironment to improve cancer immunotherapy; This special research topic highlights cutting-edge imaging and diagnostic technologies for visualizing the complex spatiotemporal dynamics of the immune-tumor microenvironment. The collection of articles offers insights into mechanisms of resistance and guides the optimization of current and novel cancer immunotherapies.

Nanoengineered cytotoxic T cells for photoacoustic image-guided combinatorial cancer therapy; This study demonstrates that surface-engineering cytotoxic T cells with drug-loaded nanoparticles enhances their delivery for a potent combinatorial cancer therapy. Using ultrasound-guided photoacoustic imaging, the targeted delivery of these nanoengineered cells was confirmed, facilitating precise image-guided delivery and increased nanoparticle accumulation in tumors.

Acoustic loudness factor as an experimental parameter for benchmarking small molecule photoacoustic probes; This paper introduces the acoustic loudness factor (ALF), a novel benchmarking parameter for predicting the performance of small molecule dyes in photoacoustic imaging (PAI) without needing photoacoustic instrumentation. The study demonstrates that ALF can guide the design of dyes with enhanced photoacoustic signals and that improvements in ALF translate to in vivo PAI.

Introducing the Stool Stomper: A Device Designed to Enable Accelerated and Standardized Stool Sample Preparation Using the Kato–Katz Technique; This paper introduces the Stool Stomper, a handheld mechanical device designed to standardize and accelerate stool sample preparation for the Kato-Katz technique used in diagnosing soil-transmitted helminth infections. In-country testing in Tanzania showed that the device reduced preparation and counting time while improving the consistency and accuracy of artificial egg counts.

New modeling and experimental framework to characterize hindered and restricted water diffusion in brain white matter; This paper proposes a theoretical framework called CHARMED, which combines hindered and restricted models of water diffusion to characterize anisotropic water diffusion in brain white matter. The model uses both a hindered extra-axonal compartment and a restricted intra-axonal compartment to explain diffusion signals across a range of MRI b-values.

Comprehensive approach for correction of motion and distortion in diffusion‐weighted MRI; This paper presents a comprehensive approach to correct for patient motion and eddy current-induced distortions in diffusion-weighted imaging (DWI) data. The method uses a mutual information-based registration technique with a spatial transformation model that simultaneously optimizes parameters for distortion and rigid body motion.

Optimal mass transport: Signal processing and machine-learning applications; This article provides a practical overview of transport-based techniques for signal and data analysis, which have shown state-of-the-art results in applications like content-based retrieval and machine learning. It covers the mathematical underpinnings of optimal mass transport methods, their numerical implementation, and demonstrates several applications.

The NIH MRI study of normal brain development; This paper describes a multi-center project to create a large, demographically balanced MRI, clinical, and behavioral database of normal brain development in approximately 500 children from birth to 18 years. Using a uniform acquisition protocol, the project aims to provide a comprehensive resource for researchers and clinicians to better understand normal brain development.

The adaptive bases algorithm for intensity-based nonrigid image registration; This paper proposes the adaptive bases algorithm, a method for intensity-based nonrigid image registration that permits spatial adaptation of the transformation's compliance. This approach reduces the number of degrees of freedom in the transformation, which speeds up the process and improves convergence properties.

Corrosion detection from IR thermal images in signed cumulative distribution transform domain; This study introduces a novel transport-based mathematical model to detect corrosive defects on metal substrates from infrared thermal images. A new detection technique is devised that uses the signed cumulative distribution transform (SCDT) and a subspace classifier to analyze 1D thermal signals and identify corrosive regions.

Linear optimal transport subspaces for point set classification; This paper proposes a framework for classifying point sets experiencing spatial deformations by employing the linear optimal transport (LOT) transform to obtain a linear embedding of the set-structured data. The method uses a nearest-subspace algorithm in the LOT space, demonstrating label efficiency and non-iterative behavior for classifying datasets with affine deformations.

System, method and computer readable medium for video-based facial weakness analysis for detecting neurological deficits; This work describes an automated and quantitative facial weakness screening framework that uses a Bi-LSTM network to model the temporal dynamics of shape and appearance features from video. The technique is designed to help non-neurologists identify neurological deficits like facial weakness for emergency triage or chronic disease management.

Local sliced Wasserstein feature sets for illumination invariant face recognition; This paper presents a new method for illumination-invariant face recognition based on modeling local gradient distributions using the Radon Cumulative Distribution Transform (R-CDT). The approach models lighting variations as a subspace in the R-CDT domain and performs recognition using a nearest subspace method, outperforming alternatives in challenging lighting conditions.

An Efficient Transport-Based Dissimilarity Measure for Time Series Classification under Warping Distortions; This paper proposes a novel dissimilarity measure for time series classification based on Optimal Transport, designed to handle warping distortions efficiently. The proposed method is shown to solve the classification problem under a deformation-based model and demonstrates its efficacy on simulated and real data at a reduced computational cost compared to DTW.

An iterative BP-CNN architecture for channel decoding; This paper proposes a novel iterative belief propagation-convolutional neural network (BP-CNN) architecture for channel decoding under correlated noise. The architecture alternates between a standard BP decoder and a trained CNN to progressively improve the decoding signal-to-noise ratio and achieve better performance.

Towards optimal power control via ensembling deep neural networks; This paper proposes a deep neural network (DNN) based power control method, PCNet, to maximize the sum rate of a fading multi-user interference channel using unsupervised learning. To improve generalization, the authors also present PCNet+ and an ensemble method, ePCNet(+), which consistently outperforms existing solutions.

Design and analysis of uplink and downlink communications for federated learning; This paper presents a design and analysis of physical layer quantization and transmission methods for wireless federated learning (FL), addressing both uplink and downlink communications. New convergence analyses for FEDAVG under non-i.i.d. data and finite-precision quantization reveal trade-offs between communication efficiency and learning performance.

Federated Multi-armed Bandits with Personalization; This paper proposes a general framework for personalized federated multi-armed bandits (PF-MAB) that balances generalization and personalization in a mixed bandit learning problem. The proposed Personalized Federated Upper Confidence Bound (PF-UCB) algorithm is proven to achieve an O(log(T)) regret and is validated on synthetic and real-world datasets.

Collaborative service placement for edge computing in dense small cell networks; This paper investigates collaborative service placement in MEC-enabled dense small cell networks, where edge servers have limited resources and must judiciously decide which services to host. The authors formulate a service placement problem to maximize the number of offloaded tasks and propose both an optimal algorithm for small-scale scenarios and a low-complexity heuristic for large-scale networks.

Edge intelligence through in-sensor and near-sensor computing for the artificial intelligence of things; This paper discusses the paradigm shift toward edge intelligence, where in- and near-sensor computing transforms traditional sensors into active data processing nodes. It presents the emerging device technologies, circuit architectures, and algorithmic frameworks for implementing the artificial intelligence of things, along with their capabilities, challenges, and strategic roadmaps.

The 11th Mining and Learning from Time Series (MILETS): From Classical Methods to LLMs; This paper summarizes the 11th Mining and Learning from Time Series (MILETS) workshop, which aims to identify key challenges and explore recent advances in temporal data mining. The workshop covers a range of topics from classical methods to emerging techniques involving large language models (LLMs) to foster collaboration and highlight new research directions.

Graph Prompting for Graph Learning Models: Recent Advances and Future Directions; This paper provides a systematic review of recent advancements in graph prompting, a technique for adapting pre-trained graph learning models to downstream tasks without altering the model weights. It introduces representative graph pre-training methods and reviews mainstream graph prompting techniques, categorizing them based on their design of learnable prompts.

Federated Split Learning with Improved Communication and Storage Efficiency; This paper proposes CSE-FSL, a novel communication and storage-efficient federated split learning method that addresses the high overhead of transmitting smashed data and gradients. CSE-FSL utilizes an auxiliary network for local client updates while maintaining a single server model, thereby avoiding frequent transmissions and reducing server storage requirements.

Chain-of-Thought Enhanced Shallow Transformers for Wireless Symbol Detection; This paper proposes CHOOSE (CHain Of thOught Symbol dEtection), a CoT-enhanced shallow Transformer framework for wireless symbol detection that improves reasoning capacity without increasing model depth. By introducing autoregressive latent reasoning steps, CHOOSE enables lightweight Transformers to achieve detection performance comparable to much deeper models, making it suitable for resource-constrained devices.

Fetal outcome in motor-vehicle crashes: effects of crash characteristics and maternal restraint; This study analyzes in-depth investigations of 57 crashes involving pregnant occupants to understand factors associated with adverse fetal outcomes. The results show that fetal outcome is most strongly associated with crash severity and maternal injury, and that proper maternal belt-restraint use is associated with acceptable fetal outcomes.

National survey of emergency department alcohol screening and intervention practices; This study surveyed emergency department (ED) directors at Level I and II trauma centers to describe current alcohol screening and brief intervention practices. The results show that while most ED directors support these practices, few use standardized instruments or have formal policies in place, citing barriers like lack of resources and training.

Increased depth of subcutaneous fat is protective against abdominal injuries in motor vehicle collisions; This study investigates the effect of subcutaneous fat depth on injury patterns in adult motor vehicle collision occupants using CT scans from 67 crash subjects. The findings suggest that increased subcutaneous fat depth is associated with significantly decreased abdominal injury severity in females.

Biomechanics of the human brain during dynamic rotation of the head; This study generated a dataset describing in situ human brain motion under injurious rotational loading conditions using unembalmed post-mortem specimens instrumented with sonomicrometry crystals. The results provide crucial experimental data for validating computational models used to understand the mechanisms of traumatic brain injury.

Gender differences in hip anatomy: possible implications for injury tolerance in frontal collisions; This study of 92 adult pelvic CT scans found significant gender differences in bony pelvic geometry, including acetabular socket depth and femoral head width. These anatomical differences may provide biomechanical insight into why males have reduced tolerance for hip fractures in frontal motor vehicle collisions.

Peripheral Vasopressor Use in Early Sepsis-Induced Hypotension; This secondary analysis of the CLOVERS trial evaluates the safety and clinical outcomes of administering vasopressors through peripheral intravenous catheters in early sepsis resuscitation. The study aims to identify factors associated with vasopressor route selection and assess the generalizability of peripheral vasopressor use in US hospitals.

Human Cervical Intervertebral Disc Pressure Response During Non-Injurious Quasistatic Motion: A Feasibility Study; This feasibility study presents a novel approach for measuring cervical spine intervertebral disc (IVD) pressure in whole-body post-mortem human subjects using minimally invasive sensors. The results demonstrate the feasibility and repeatability of measuring IVD pressure changes during various head and neck motions, providing valuable data for biomechanics research.

Acetaminophen for prevention and treatment of organ dysfunction in critically ill patients with sepsis: the ASTER randomized clinical trial; This phase 2b randomized clinical trial investigated whether intravenous acetaminophen increases days alive and free of organ dysfunction in critically ill patients with sepsis compared to a placebo. The study, conducted in 40 US hospitals, randomized adults with sepsis and respiratory or circulatory organ dysfunction to receive either acetaminophen or a placebo for five days.

Mass Gathering Medicine: A Guide to the Medical Management of Large Events; This textbook provides guidance for the medical management of mass gathering events, covering topics from general deployment and staffing to complex issues like legal implications and managing adverse events. Written by an international group of contributors, it serves as an invaluable text for healthcare professionals, event planners, and security personnel involved in mass events.

Using formal verification to evaluate human-automation interaction: A review; This paper reviews the use of formal verification, a mathematical technique for proving system properties, to evaluate human-automation interaction (HAI). It discusses how the method has been used to assess usability, find potential mode confusion, and evaluate system safety in light of formally modeled human behavior.

A systematic approach to model checking human–automation interaction using task analytic models; This paper presents the enhanced operator function model (EOFM), an XML-based language for describing task analytic models to support the integration of human behavior into formal system verification. The authors provide the formal syntax and semantics of the EOFM and a method for automatically translating it into the input language of a model checker.

Generating phenotypical erroneous human behavior to evaluate human–automation interaction using model checking; This paper presents a novel method for automatically generating task analytic models that include both normative and phenotypically erroneous human behavior from normative task models. This method allows engineers to use formal methods to evaluate how different types of human error can contribute to system failures.

Formally verifying human–automation interaction as part of a system model: limitations and tradeoffs; This paper discusses a modeling effort that combined human factors engineering and formal methods to verify human-automation interaction with a programmable patient-controlled analgesia pump. The work highlights the limitations and tradeoffs involved in using a system architecture of decoupled models to perform formal verification of realistic systems.

The mathematical meaninglessness of the NASA task load index: A level of measurement analysis; This paper investigates the mathematical meaningfulness of the NASA Task Load Index (NASA-TLX), a standard method for assessing human mental workload. The analysis concludes that because the level of measurement of the six constituent dimensions is ordinal, neither of the two standard methods for computing an overall workload score is mathematically meaningful.

Integrating an intuitive tactical navigation solution to enable situational awareness for people with visual disabilities; This research designed and evaluated a wearable vibrotactile display to provide intuitive orientation and communication cues for navigation by people with visual disabilities. An experiment with fully blind participants showed that the device, which communicates the three levels of situation awareness, improved navigation performance and was subjectively preferred.

Examining Dual-Task Interference Effects of Visual and Auditory Perceptual Load in Virtual Reality; This study examined the intramodal and crossmodal effects of visual and auditory perceptual load on dual-task interference in a virtual reality (VR) environment. Results showed that perceptual load and task type influenced intramodal interference, but no crossmodal interference was observed, suggesting a degree of independence between visual and auditory processing resources.

Validation of a Formal Method for Human Error Rate Prediction With Negative Transfer; This article validates a formal method that combines task analytic modeling and statistical model checking to predict human error rates and the effect of negative transfer from design changes. The validation study, based on the OpenEMR electronic medical record system, addresses deficiencies of prior work by using a more realistic example and refining the prediction method.

Towards a Signal Detection Based Measure for Assessing Information Quality of Explainable Recommender Systems; This paper proposes an objective metric based on signal detection theory to evaluate the Veracity, or information quality, of explanations in explainable recommender systems. Veracity is decomposed into Fidelity (accuracy of information) and Attunement (reflection of user preferences), which are combined to calculate a sensitivity score that captures differences in explanation quality.

A Trust-Aware Reinforcement Learning Approach to Enhance Human-Agent Teaming: An Overcooked-AI Study; This study integrates a dynamic trust prediction model into a reinforcement learning framework to enhance human-agent collaboration in the Overcooked-AI environment. The agent's reward strategy is modified to account for real-time trust predictions, promoting trust-building actions and discouraging those that erode trust.

Polypeptide organic radical batteries; This work presents polypeptide organic radical batteries as a sustainable alternative to traditional lithium-ion batteries, addressing ethical and environmental challenges associated with mineral mining and disposal. These batteries utilize redox-active materials from sustainable sources that are designed to be stable during operation but degradable and reconstructible at their end of life.

Biomaterials via peptide assembly: Design, characterization, and application in tissue engineering; This review discusses the rational design of biomaterials via peptide self-assembly, focusing on creating dynamic, physical hydrogels that mimic native tissue microenvironments for tissue engineering applications. It covers the design of assembling peptides and the molecular and macroscopic features that govern their assembly, morphology, and biological interactions.

The effect of comb architecture on complex coacervation; This study combines coarse-grained Monte Carlo simulations and experiments to investigate how a comb-like polymer architecture affects complex coacervation. The results show that the comb architecture mitigates cooperative interactions between oppositely charged polymers, leading to less stable coacervates compared to linear-linear polymer pairs.

Crystallization-driven assembly of fully degradable, natural product-based poly (l-lactide)-block-poly (α-d-glucose carbonate) s in aqueous solution; This paper reports the crystallization-driven self-assembly of fully degradable amphiphilic block copolymers derived from l-lactide, l-cysteine, and d-glucose. The resulting PLLA-b-PDGC-cys copolymers formed various micellar nanostructures in water, including spheres, cylinders, and bundled platelets, depending on the polymer composition.

Molecular engineering of antimicrobial peptide (AMP)–polymer conjugates; This review discusses the molecular engineering of antimicrobial peptide (AMP)-polymer conjugates as a strategy to overcome the clinical challenges of AMPs, such as limited stability and toxicity. It highlights how non-linear polymer architectures and supramolecular assemblies can maximize bacterial killing while enhancing stability and compatibility with mammalian cells.

Programming Peptide Assembly for Advanced Biomaterials: Organic Processing Conditions and Stereocomplexation; This work focuses on programming peptide assembly to create advanced biomaterials by exploring the influence of organic processing conditions and stereocomplexation. The research aims to control the structure and properties of peptide-based materials for various applications.

Repressed ang 1-7 in covid-19 is inversely associated with inflammation and coagulation; This work provides methods for treating subjects with coronavirus infections, particularly those with prothrombotic conditions like COVID-19, by administering an angiotensin (1-7) peptide or related agonists. It also describes compositions where these peptides are associated with degradable or nondegradable polymers for delivery.

Presenting Antimicrobial Peptides on Poly (ethylene glycol): Star-Shaped vs Comb-Like Architectures; This study compares conjugates of the antimicrobial peptide P9 with star-shaped and comb-like poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG) architectures. The results show that comb-like conjugates exhibit increased helicity, solubility, antimicrobial activity, and proteolytic stability compared to star-shaped conjugates of similar composition.

Orally Delivered Milk-Derived Nanovesicles Loaded with Connexin 43 Peptides for Targeted Cardiac Ischemia-Reperfusion Therapy; This paper reports an innovative approach for targeted oral delivery of therapeutic peptides to injured tissues using milk-derived small extracellular vesicles (mEVs). By loading mEVs with a Connexin 43 peptide, the engineered nanocarriers demonstrated remarkable injury-targeting capabilities and significantly reduced infarct size in a mouse model of myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury.

Multi-scale modeling of ionic electrospray emission; This paper combines molecular dynamics, particle-particle, and particle-in-cell models to investigate the physics of ionic electrospray propulsion across nine orders of magnitude in length scale. The multi-scale model is applied to simulate beam emission from porous emitters, analyzing the impact of multiple emission sites on grid interception and beam neutralization.

Grid-based Vlasov simulation of collisionless plasma expansion; This study uses grid-based Vlasov simulations to re-evaluate the one-dimensional collisionless plasma expansion into a vacuum, eliminating the statistical noise of particle-based methods. The simulations reveal that the expansion generates both ion-acoustic and electron Langmuir wave modes, and show that the isothermal electron fluid assumption is only valid within a quasi-neutral, self-similar region.

Simulations of Pure Ionic Electrospray Thruster Plume Neutralization; This study uses fully kinetic Particle-in-Cell simulations to investigate the neutralization process of pure ionic electrospray thrusters in bi-polar operation. The results indicate that beam neutralization is primarily achieved through ion bouncing within a potential well established between the beam front and the thruster exit.

Grid-Based Kinetic Simulations of Collisionless Plasma Expansion; This study presents a grid-based Vlasov model to simulate collisionless plasma expansion, aiming to reduce numerical noise and better study electron kinetic properties. The model is benchmarked against particle-in-cell simulations and analytical solutions, successfully capturing the anisotropic kinetic characteristics observed in previous PIC simulations.

Development of a Parallel Multi-dimensional Grid-based Vlasov Solver for Plasma Plume Simulation; This paper introduces Vlasolver, a parallel, multi-dimensional, grid-based Vlasov solver for plasma plume simulation. The paper details the model, algorithm, and parallelization strategies, and verifies the code's correctness and efficiency on two-stream instability and Landau damping problems.

Vlasov simulations of electric propulsion beam; This study develops a grid-based Vlasov simulation model to investigate the two-dimensional unmagnetized electric propulsion (EP) plasma beam emission process, eliminating particle noise to accurately resolve higher-order velocity moments. The simulations reveal that the electron velocity distribution function is non-Maxwellian, leading to near-constant electron temperature along the beam direction but near-adiabatic cooling in the transverse direction.

Quantifying PIC Noise Effects on Particle Velocity Moments: Comparisons of PIC and Vlasov Simulations; This paper investigates the statistical noise effects on particle velocity moments in fully kinetic Particle-in-Cell (PIC) simulations by comparing them with grid-based Vlasov simulations. By analyzing plasma expansion and instability problems, the study derives the scaling of PIC statistical noise in density, velocity, temperature, and heat flux, and discusses its limitations.

Impact of Initial Non-Maxwellian Electron Velocity Distribution Function on Electric Propulsion Beam Expansion: Grid-Based Vlasov Simulations; This study uses grid-based Vlasov simulations to investigate the impact of initial non-Maxwellian electron velocity distribution functions (eVDFs), specifically the Kappa distribution, on electric propulsion beam expansion. The results show a near-constant ion acceleration ratio and an anomalous electron temperature enhancement when starting with an initial Kappa velocity distribution.

Rigorously conservative charge and current deposition in 3D cylindrical PIC; This paper presents a charge and current deposition method for electromagnetic particle-in-cell simulations in 3D cylindrical coordinates that rigorously satisfies the continuity equation. The method is a direct extension of the Villasenor and Buneman method and eliminates edge errors by correctly computing the volumes swept by cylindrical sector charges.

Electron Scale Physics in Plasma Expansion: Grid-based Vlasov Simulations; This work uses a parallel, multi-dimensional, grid-based Vlasov-Poisson solver to study electron-scale physics in plasma expansion, a fundamental problem with applications in spacecraft wake formation and electric propulsion. The study focuses on how electrons, often treated as an equilibrium fluid, are actually non-equilibrium and anisotropic, and investigates the excitation of electron Langmuir waves.

Synthesis of human-in-the-loop control protocols for autonomous systems; This paper proposes an approach to synthesize control protocols for autonomous systems, such as UAVs, that accounts for uncertainties and imperfections in interactions with human operators. By modeling human-automation interactions as stochastic two-player games, the approach enables the synthesis of operator-dependent optimal mission plans and can provide informative feedback.

Safe multi-agent reinforcement learning via shielding; This paper presents two shielding approaches, centralized and factored, to guarantee safety in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) by monitoring agents' actions and correcting unsafe ones. Experimental results show that both approaches guarantee safety during learning without compromising policy quality, with factored shielding offering better scalability.

Deeptake: Prediction of driver takeover behavior using multimodal data; This paper presents DeepTake, a novel deep neural network framework that predicts a driver's intention, time, and quality of takeover when engaged in non-driving tasks in an automated vehicle. Using features from vehicle data, driver biometrics, and subjective measurements, DeepTake aims to ensure the driver can safely resume control when a takeover is required.

Medirl: Predicting the visual attention of drivers via maximum entropy deep inverse reinforcement learning; This paper proposes MEDIRL, a novel inverse reinforcement learning formulation for predicting the visual attention of drivers in accident-prone situations. The model learns a task-sensitive reward function from the eye fixation patterns of attentive drivers and outperforms existing models on several benchmark datasets, including the newly introduced EyeCar dataset.

Controller synthesis for autonomous systems interacting with human operators; This paper proposes an approach to synthesize control protocols for autonomous systems, such as UAVs, that accounts for uncertainties and imperfections in interactions with human operators. By abstracting interactions as Markov decision processes or stochastic two-player games, the method enables the synthesis of operator-dependent optimal mission plans.

Robust Permissive Controller Synthesis for Interval MDPs; This paper presents the first framework for robust permissive controller synthesis on Interval Markov Decision Processes (IMDPs) to guarantee that all compliant strategies satisfy specifications under uncertain dynamics. The problem is formulated as mixed-integer linear programs with two proposed encodings, a baseline vertex-enumeration method and a scalable duality-based method.

IrrMap: A Large-Scale Comprehensive Dataset for Irrigation Method Mapping; This paper introduces IrrMap, the first large-scale, ML-ready dataset for irrigation method mapping, consisting of 1.1 million patches of multi-resolution satellite imagery and auxiliary data. The dataset, which spans over 11 million acres in the western U.S., is accompanied by a complete generation pipeline to enable extension to new regions.

Runtime Safety through Adaptive Shielding: From Hidden Parameter Inference to Provable Guarantees; This paper develops a runtime shielding mechanism for reinforcement learning that provides probabilistic safety guarantees for systems with hidden parameters, such as a robot's mass or friction. The mechanism uses function encoders for real-time parameter inference and a shield that adapts online by forecasting future safety risks and accounting for uncertainty via conformal prediction.

Counterfactual Explanations for Continuous Action Reinforcement Learning; This paper proposes a novel approach for generating counterfactual explanations in continuous action reinforcement learning by computing alternative action sequences that improve outcomes while minimizing deviations from the original. The method, evaluated in Diabetes Control and Lunar Lander domains, leverages a distance metric for continuous actions and accounts for policy constraints.

ChatGPT: Applications, opportunities, and threats; This study reviews ChatGPT, an AI technology from OpenAI, examining its applications, opportunities, and threats across 10 domains with a focus on business and education. An experimental study was also conducted to compare the performance and effectiveness of different GPT versions.

Profit-oriented partial disassembly line design: dealing with hazardous parts and task processing times uncertainty; This paper addresses the profit-oriented disassembly line balancing problem, considering partial disassembly, hazardous parts, and uncertain task processing times. The authors use stochastic programming models and an exact-based solution method to design a serial line that maximizes revenue and balances workload under uncertainty.

Disassembly line balancing under high variety of end of life states using a joint precedence graph approach; This paper proposes using a joint precedence graph to address the disassembly line balancing problem for products with a high variety of end-of-life (EOL) states. The approach is shown to be beneficial for achieving an optimal line balance where traditional methods are used, as demonstrated with a pen and a laptop example.

Disassembly liaison graphs inspired by word clouds; This paper introduces a method inspired by word clouds to transform a standard liaison graph into a weighted liaison graph (WLG) for disassembly. The WLG graphically depicts both physical mates and disassembly precedence relations, allowing users to quickly comprehend the order of disassembly and component embeddedness.

Social choice rules, fallback bargaining, and related games in common resource conflicts; This paper uses the Graph Model for Conflict Resolution methodology to model a common resource conflict and then applies social choice voting rules and a new "Related games" approach to analyze the outcomes. The proposed method adds a new analytical stage to sieve socially optimal outcomes from the graph model's equilibria.

Refining a Novel AI Restaurant Recommender Application: A Systems Approach to Increasing User Engagement and Retention; This study addresses the challenge of restaurant selection by improving dinemait, an AI-powered mobile recommender application, with the goal of increasing user engagement and retention. Using a systems-based approach, the team evaluated the existing application and improved outreach features based on focus groups, surveys, and user data.

Check-In Check-Up: Analyzing and Improving Pre-Appointment Engagement in a Primary Care Clinic at UVA Health System; This project focuses on increasing pre-appointment patient engagement with the UVA Health System's secure patient portal to enhance the patient experience at a primary care clinic. To address the low completion rate of eCheck-In tasks, the study analyzed patient data and conducted surveys to identify barriers and inform potential solutions.

Redesign of the University of Virginia’s Emergency Department Waiting Room Layout to Optimize Patient Flow and Increase Satisfaction; This study addresses emergency department (ED) crowding at UVA Health by proposing and simulating a redesign of the ED waiting room layout to improve patient flow and satisfaction. Using FlexSim HC software, the redesign, which creates "progression areas" to reduce returns to the main lobby, was shown to significantly decrease patient wait times and increase satisfaction.

A novel approach for multi-objective truck scheduling problems in a cross-docking center; This paper proposes an operational approach for multi-objective truck scheduling in a cross-docking system, considering truck breakdown probability, capacity constraints, and earliness penalties. The authors use genetic algorithms and particle swarm optimization to find near-optimal solutions that minimize total completion time and outbound truck earliness/tardiness.

Expanding VIAble Employment for Adults with Autism: A Systems Approach to Increase Nonprofit Sales; This project partners with VIAble Ventures, a microbusiness run by the VIA Centers for Neurodevelopment, to increase online sales and expand employment opportunities for adults with autism. Using a systems approach, the team analyzed past transactions and redesigned the website to improve the user experience and drive sales growth.

Automobile injury trends in the contemporary fleet: Belted occupants in frontal collisions; This study examined injury distributions and risk trends for belted occupants in frontal automobile collisions using NASS-CDS data from 1998-2015. Logistic regression models revealed that newer model year vehicles (2009 and later) carry a lower risk of moderate to severe injuries compared to older vehicles.

Human surrogates for injury biomechanics research; This article reviews the attributes of human surrogates commonly used in injury biomechanics research, including human cadavers, volunteers, animals, dummies, and computational models. It assesses the merits of each surrogate relative to its ability to characterize living human response and injury in an impact environment.

Accidental injury: biomechanics and prevention; This book provides a state-of-the-art overview of the applied biomechanics of accidental injury and its prevention, with chapters from renowned researchers covering various aspects of human injury assessment. The third edition is thoroughly revised and expanded, addressing topics such as injury mechanisms, human tolerance, and crashworthiness applications for adult and pediatric populations.

Predicting rib fracture risk with whole-body finite element models: development and preliminary evaluation of a probabilistic analytical framework; This study developed a strain-based probabilistic method to predict rib fracture risk using whole-body finite element (FE) models. The framework combines an age-adjusted ultimate strain distribution with collision exposure information to predict injury risk and the potential effectiveness of interventions like advanced seatbelts.

A Novel Method for Quantifying Human In Situ Whole Brain Deformation under Rotational Loading Using Sonomicrometry; This study developed a methodology to investigate three-dimensional, in situ brain deformation during pure rotational loading of the head using sonomicrometry. A human cadaveric head-neck specimen was instrumented with an array of 32 sonomicrometry crystals to directly measure dynamic brain motion, providing data for validating finite element models of traumatic brain injury.

Disc Injury and Spine Loads in Low-to-Moderate-Severity Frontal Impacts: R. Kent and J. Forman; This study analyzed data from 282 impact tests to determine the cervical and lumbar spine forces and moments generated in belted occupants during low-to-moderate-severity frontal impacts. The results show that the spinal loads are well below established injury reference values and are within the range of loads tolerated during daily activities.

Assessing seatbelt use among pregnant drivers in Australia: correct seatbelt positioning, discomfort, knowledge and information sources; This online survey of 1,491 pregnant vehicle drivers in Australia investigated seatbelt use, positioning, comfort, and knowledge. While nearly all participants reported always wearing a seatbelt, only 41.4% positioned it correctly, and most had not received information on proper use during pregnancy.

Evaluation of THOR-50M-RS under reclined seating conditions; This study evaluated the performance of the THOR-50M for Reclined Seating (THOR-50M-RS) anthropomorphic test device in nine frontal sled tests under reclined seating conditions. The results, including kinematics and injury metrics, were compared to tests conducted with post-mortem human subjects under the same conditions to assess the device's biofidelity.

Seatbelt use trends by pregnancy status and state in the United States, 2011–2024; This study uses data from the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (2011–2024) to evaluate geographic differences and trends in habitual seatbelt use, with a focus on pregnant females. A Bayesian regression model was used to analyze the effects of state, year, age, sex, pregnancy status, and enforcement type on self-reported seatbelt use.

Pulmonary injury risk assessment for short-duration blasts; This study developed new injury risk assessment curves for short-duration blast-induced pulmonary injury by analyzing data from over 1,100 large animal experiments. A two-variable nonlinear logistic regression was performed on the data for threshold injury and lethality in terms of pressure and duration for both incident and reflected pressure conditions.

Pressure-induced mechanical stress in the carotid artery bifurcation: a possible correlation to atherosclerosis; This study investigates a possible correlation between high intramural wall stress and the development of atherosclerotic lesions in the carotid artery bifurcation. Using finite element models based on in vivo and cadaveric data, the analysis identified highly localized stress concentrations at the bifurcation point and in the sinus bulb, regions known to be prone to atherosclerosis.

Experimental investigation of cavitation as a possible damage mechanism in blast-induced traumatic brain injury in post-mortem human subject heads; This study investigates localized cavitation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) as a potential damage mechanism in blast-induced traumatic brain injury. Experiments using instrumented post-mortem human subject heads in shock tubes indicated that cavitation may occur at pressure levels below those for a 50% risk of blast lung injury.

Survival risk assessment for primary blast exposures to the head; This study determined a brain fatality risk function for primary blast exposure to the head using anesthetized rabbits whose thoraces were protected. The fatality data from brain injury was analyzed using Fisher's exact test, showing that greater blast intensity was associated with a higher likelihood of fatality.

Use of a Porcine Cadaver Model as a Human Surrogate for Behind Armor Blunt Trauma; This study compared the viability of a 40-kg porcine cadaver model as a human surrogate for thoracoabdominal behind armor blunt trauma (BABT) response. By conducting 74 matched BABT impacts on postmortem human subjects and porcine cadavers, injury risk functions were generated and compared across species for lung, liver, and sternum locations.

Back Muscle Activity During One Hour of Vertical Vibration Simulating a Helicopter Flight; This study investigated back muscle response over one hour of vertical whole-body vibration simulating a helicopter flight to better understand the high rates of back pain in aircrew members. Surface electromyography data collected from 14 subjects showed low muscle activity, with a significant increase in the multifidus muscle over time, suggesting a link to postural control.

A Systematic Literature Review of Impact Systems for Developing Generalized Medical Injury Criteria for Behind Armor Blunt Trauma; This systematic literature review examines behind armor blunt trauma (BABT) studies with a focus on impact systems and the development of injury criteria for the thoraco-abdominal region. The review aims to identify articles covering thoraco-abdominal injuries, impact delivery systems, and the development of risk curves to enhance medical injury criteria.

Matched-pair hybrid test paradigm for behind armor blunt trauma using an experimental animal model; This paper presents a matched-pair hybrid test paradigm using live and cadaver swine to develop regional human injury criteria for behind armor blunt trauma (BABT). By delivering BABT loading to liver and lung regions, the study characterized impact loading and correlated it with physiological responses and necropsy findings to establish injury metrics.

Development of a biofidelic computational model of human pelvis for predicting biomechanical responses and pelvic fractures; This study introduces and validates a biofidelic computational finite element (FE) model of the human pelvis to enhance the understanding of pelvic injury mechanisms under lateral loading. The mid-sized male model, featuring variable cortical thickness, was comprehensively validated against various experimental tests, showing good correlation in predicting biomechanical responses and fracture patterns.

Stein variational message passing for continuous graphical models; This paper proposes a novel distributed inference algorithm for continuous graphical models by extending Stein variational gradient descent (SVGD) to leverage Markov dependency structures. The approach uses a set of structured local kernel functions defined on each node's Markov blanket, which alleviates the curse of dimensionality and enables decentralized inference.

SIMPLE: A Gradient Estimator for k-Subset Sampling; This paper introduces SIMPLE, a novel gradient estimator for k-subset sampling problems. The proposed method aims to provide an efficient and effective way to handle optimization tasks involving the selection of a fixed-size subset from a larger set.

Efficient Search-Based Weighted Model Integration; This paper proposes an efficient search-based algorithm for weighted model integration (WMI) on problems with tree-structured primal graphs. The algorithm exploits the sparse graph structure and context-specific independence to greatly improve computational efficiency compared to existing WMI solvers.

Probabilistically Rewired Message-Passing Neural Networks; This work introduces probabilistically rewired message-passing neural networks (PR-MPNNs), which leverage differentiable k-subset sampling to learn to add relevant edges and omit less beneficial ones in a graph. Theoretical analysis shows how PR-MPNNs enhance expressive power and mitigate issues like over-squashing, with empirical results demonstrating competitive performance against traditional MPNNs and graph transformers.

Scaling up Hybrid Probabilistic Inference with Logical and Arithmetic Constraints via Message Passing; This paper introduces MP-WMI, a scalable weighted model integration (WMI) solver based on message passing that addresses the limitations of existing solvers for hybrid probabilistic inference. MP-WMI is the first solver capable of exact inference on all tree-structured WMI problems and can perform inter-query amortization, dramatically outperforming existing solvers on a large set of benchmarks.

Deep generative models with hard linear equality constraints; This work proposes a probabilistically sound approach for enforcing hard linear equality constraints in deep generative models (DGMs) to generate constraint-compliant and realistic data. The proposed gradient estimators allow the constrained data distribution to be differentiably learned, achieving superior generative performance and guaranteed constraint satisfaction across multiple benchmarks.

Neurosymbolic Learning and Reasoning for Trustworthy AI; This dissertation addresses two fundamental challenges in neurosymbolic AI: enabling differentiable learning of deep neural networks under symbolic constraints and performing scalable, reliable probabilistic reasoning over expressive symbolic constraints. The work demonstrates how these neurosymbolic approaches achieve trustworthiness through explainability, uncertainty quantification, and domain-knowledge incorporation.

A unified approach to count-based weakly supervised learning; This paper develops a unified approach for count-based weakly-supervised learning, where weak labels dictate the frequency of each class over a set of instances. The core of the approach is a differentiable, exact, and efficient method to compute the probability of a specific count of true outputs, which is used to derive a count loss function.

Collapsed inference for bayesian deep learning; This paper introduces a novel collapsed inference scheme for Bayesian neural networks (BNNs) that improves scalability and performance by revealing a connection between BNN inference and volume computation problems. The method performs Bayesian model averaging using collapsed samples, where a subset of weights are sampled and paired with a closed-form conditional distribution over the rest, achieving state-of-the-art uncertainty estimation.

Federated learning enables big data for rare cancer boundary detection; This paper presents the largest federated learning study to date, involving 71 sites across six continents, to create an automatic tumor boundary detector for glioblastoma without sharing patient data. The resulting model showed a 33% improvement in delineating the surgically targetable tumor and a 23% improvement for the complete tumor extent over a publicly trained model.

Modeling and forecasting short-term power load with copula model and deep belief network; This paper proposes a data-driven deep learning framework using a copula model and a deep belief network to forecast short-term power load. The framework first models the tail-dependence of power load on price and temperature using copulas and then uses a deep belief network to forecast hourly load, outperforming classical neural networks in case studies.

Parametric human body shape modeling framework for human-centered product design; This study develops a novel parametric human body shape modeling framework for human-centered product design, based on 3D scan data of 250 subjects. The framework uses statistical analysis to correlate body shape variations with body size measurements, enabling an interactive modeling interface that generates a corresponding body shape model from user inputs.

Deep learning for synthetic microstructure generation in a materials-by-design framework for heterogeneous energetic materials; This paper proposes using generative adversarial networks (GANs) to create large ensembles of synthetic microstructures for heterogeneous energetic materials. This approach supports a materials-by-design framework by enabling the meso-scale simulations required to quantify hot spot ignition and develop models for microstructure-dependent energy deposition.

Deep segmentation networks predict survival of non-small cell lung cancer; This study shows that convolutional neural networks (CNNs) trained solely for the task of tumor segmentation on PET/CT images can predict the survival of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients. The deep segmentation networks, without any other information, demonstrated predictive power comparable to or exceeding that of established clinical and radiomic prognostic factors.

A physics-aware deep learning model for shear band formation around collapsing pores in shocked reactive materials; This study advances the Physics-Aware Recurrent Convolutional Neural Network (PARCv2) to model hotspot formation in crystalline energetic materials under weak-to-moderate shock loading. The improved architecture is capable of predicting strong shock responses and addresses the computational challenges of direct numerical simulations for these complex physical phenomena.

Towards a Physics Foundation Model; This paper presents the General Physics Transformer (GPhyT), a model trained on 1.8 TB of diverse simulation data that demonstrates foundation model capabilities for physics. GPhyT achieves superior performance across multiple domains, zero-shot generalization to unseen systems via in-context learning, and stable long-term predictions, opening a path toward a universal Physics Foundation Model.

Reduced Order Modeling of Energetic Materials Using Physics-Aware Recurrent Convolutional Neural Networks in a Latent Space (LatentPARC); This work accelerates the Physics-Aware Recurrent Convolutional Network (PARC) for modeling energetic materials by projecting the original dynamics onto a lower-dimensional latent space, creating LatentPARC. This approach decouples the problem into learning complex geometric features and modeling dynamics in the reduced feature space, significantly decreasing training time while maintaining comparable accuracy.

Towards fair decentralized benchmarking of healthcare AI algorithms with the Federated Tumor Segmentation (FeTS) challenge; This paper describes the Federated Tumor Segmentation (FeTS) Challenge, a competition designed to benchmark federated learning aggregation algorithms and state-of-the-art segmentation models on real-world, internationally distributed brain tumor data. The challenge provides a paradigm for fair, decentralized evaluation of healthcare AI algorithms, yielding benefits for adaptive weight aggregation and client sampling.

Latent Representation Learning of Multi-scale Thermophysics: Application to Dynamics in Shocked Porous Energetic Material; This work investigates a meta-learning approach to develop closure models for multi-scale material simulations by learning a reduced representation of micro-scale physics to accelerate meso-scale learning. Applied to shock-induced energy localization in a porous energetic material, the model learns a probabilistic latent representation of micro-scale dynamics as building blocks, outperforming a standard physics-aware model when meso-scale data is scarce.

Validating design methods and research: the validation square; This paper proposes the "validation square," a framework for validating design research and methods, which often rely on subjective statements in addition to mathematical modeling. Anchored in epistemology, the framework explores how to confirm new knowledge in a field where traditional scientific validation based on logical induction or deduction can be problematic.

Applying Ecological Input‐Output Flow Analysis to Material Flows in Industrial Systems: Part I: Tracing Flows; This paper constructs a framework for modeling physical material and energy flows in industrial systems using input-output mathematics, independent of monetary implications. Based on previous research in ecological systems, the approach allows a modeler to fully consider both direct and indirect relationships among conserved flows.

The validation square: how does one verify and validate a design method; This paper presents the validation square, a framework for verifying and validating design methods that rely on subjective statements as well as mathematical modeling. It addresses the problem that traditional, purely quantitative validation anchored in scientific inquiry is often problematic for this type of engineering research.

Assessing engineering design process knowledge; This paper describes the development of an assessment tool to rigorously measure students' engineering design process knowledge in a large college setting. The approach involves having students critique a proposed design process, with their responses assessed using an analytic scoring rubric to gauge their embodied design knowledge.

Applying ecological input‐output flow analysis to material flows in industrial systems: part II: flow metrics; This article, a continuation of a companion piece, expounds on the use of ecological input-output techniques to analyze material flows in industrial systems. It introduces several material flow metrics, such as measures of material cycling, to characterize system behavior and link flow analysis to system synthesis and design.

Using design timelines for tracking and reflection on design processes: Emerging insights; This paper explores the student experience of tracking and reflecting on their design processes by creating visual timelines during team-based engineering projects. By analyzing survey responses, the study finds that self-tracking design activities provides authentic opportunities for reflection and helps students develop metacognitive awareness.

A Decision-Driven Methodology for Business Intelligence Dashboards in Start-Ups; This paper describes a decision-driven methodology for designing business intelligence dashboards that effectively display important metrics for startups based on user and enterprise needs. The methodology involves understanding enterprise data, conducting stakeholder interviews to identify key business decisions, and then determining system objectives and metrics for each decision.

Impacts of a Short-Term International Engineering and Business Consulting Practicum; This study characterizes how students' views on cultural differences change after participating in a short-term, practicum-based international engineering and business consulting program in Argentina. Analysis of pre- and post-program responses shows a shift from ethnocentric, surface-level observations to more ethnorelative perspectives that consider deeper cultural context and values.

A Systems Methodology for Informed Solar Energy Decision-Making; This paper proposes a systems methodology for navigating the complex decision-making process of commercial solar energy adoption, presented through a case study of a non-profit in Virginia. The methodology involves establishing objectives with stakeholders, identifying limitations, determining key decisions, and interpreting metrics to compare diverse proposals from solar companies.

A model for integrating engineering design into science teacher education; This paper describes a model used for the past eight years to prepare secondary pre-service science teachers to integrate engineering design into their science instruction, as required by the Next Generation Science Standards. The authors provide the outcomes and suggestions for implementing this model, which they believe is transferable to other teacher education programs.

Thermal conductivity and thermal boundary resistance of atomic layer deposited high-k dielectric aluminum oxide, hafnium oxide, and titanium oxide thin films on silicon; This study uses time domain thermoreflectance to measure the thermal conductivity and thermal boundary resistance of atomic layer deposited aluminum oxide, hafnium oxide, and titanium oxide thin films on silicon. The results are used to create a design map of effective thermal resistances, which is critical as the shrinking size of dielectric layers makes interfacial resistance a dominant factor.

Phonon scattering effects from point and extended defects on thermal conductivity studied via ion irradiation of crystals with self-impurities; This study experimentally investigates how point and extended defects impact phonon scattering by using ion irradiation to introduce controlled strain and defects into silicon crystals. By irradiating natural silicon with silicon isotopes, the results demonstrate that point defects decrease thermal conductivity more than extended defect structures for the same damage level.

Orders of magnitude reduction in the thermal conductivity of polycrystalline diamond through carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen ion implantation; This study investigates the effect of C3+, N3+, and O3+ ion implantation on the thermal conductivity of polycrystalline diamond. Using time-domain thermoreflectance, the results show that implantation can reduce the thermal conductivity by nearly two orders of magnitude while the material remains polycrystalline in the thermally probed regions.

Thermal resistance and heat capacity in hafnium zirconium oxide (Hf1–xZrxO2) dielectrics and ferroelectric thin films; This paper reports on the thermal resistances and heat capacities of 20 nm thin films of hafnium zirconium oxide (Hf1–xZrxO2) with varying compositions. Using time-domain thermoreflectance, the study found that effective thermal resistances decreased upon crystallization and determined the heat capacities for two specific compositions.

Interface and layer periodicity effects on the thermal conductivity of copper-based nanomultilayers with tungsten, tantalum, and tantalum nitride diffusion barriers; This work reports on the thermal conductivity of sputter-deposited Cu/W, Cu/Ta, and Cu/TaN nanomultilayers with varying thicknesses. The study uses different materials as thermal barriers to manipulate interfacial effects on thermal transport and discusses the resistive interfacial effects in relation to structural transformations upon annealing.

Ruddlesden-Popper chalcogenides push the limit of mechanical stiffness and glass-like thermal conductivity in single crystals; This paper reports that single-crystalline Ruddlesden-Popper chalcogenides (Ban+1ZrnS3n+1) exhibit both ultrahigh mechanical stiffness and intrinsic, glass-like ultralow thermal conductivity. This unusual combination is attributed to strong anharmonicity and intra-unit-cell rock-salt blocks that form intrinsic superlattices, impeding heat conduction through broadband phonon scattering.

Limitations and Advances in Optical Thermal Transport Measurements: Extremes in Properties, Length Scales, and Temperature; This review focuses on the challenges and strategies associated with nano- and microscale optical thermal transport measurements across extreme properties, length scales, and temperatures.
