It discusses the limitations and error sources in thermoreflectance and pyrometry techniques, highlighting the need for rigorous uncertainty treatment to advance metrology for materials with high thermal conductivity or complex structures.

Picking the Right TMD is the Key to Controlling Heat In a Phase Change Superlattice; This study investigates the suitability of VTe2 and ZrTe2 for use in phase-change memory (PCM) superlattices by examining their thermal properties. The findings indicate that both materials are promising candidates due to their high crystalline quality, thermal stability, and consistently low thermal conductivity contrast between phases.

Suspended silicon nitride platforms for thermal sensing applications in the limit of minimized membrane thickness; This paper reports on the development and thermal characterization of low-stress, suspended silicon nitride platform devices with membrane thicknesses ranging from 120 nm down to less than 10 nm. The study demonstrates thermal conductivities as low as 1.1 W m−1 K−1 near room temperature, highlighting the potential of these platforms for enhancing the performance of thermal sensors.

Cost-related medication non-adherence among US adults with diabetes; This study uses Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System data to examine factors affecting cost-related medication non-adherence (CRN) among US adults with diabetes. The results show that 16.5% of adults with diabetes report CRN, with financial factors like low income and lack of insurance being the most important predictors.

Evaluating the costs of nurse burnout-attributed turnover: a Markov modeling approach; This study uses a Markov model and a cost-consequence analysis to understand the cost of nurse burnout-attributed turnover from a hospital payer perspective. The model compares a "status quo" scenario with a "burnout reduction program" scenario to evaluate the financial impact of burnout on nurse retention.

A scoping review of racial/ethnic disparities in sleep; This scoping review summarizes the characteristics of 116 existing studies on racial and ethnic disparities in sleep to identify evidence gaps. The review found that most studies focus on disparities between Whites and Blacks, with disproportionately fewer studies examining sleep in Hispanic, Asian, and other racial/ethnic groups.

Second-line agents for glycemic control for type 2 diabetes: are newer agents better?; This study developed and validated a new population-based glycemic control Markov model to assess the benefits and harms of four common second-line antihyperglycemia treatment regimens for type 2 diabetes. The model, calibrated with US data, compared sulfonylurea, DPP-4 inhibitors, GLP-1 receptor agonists, and insulin against metformin monotherapy based on clinical effectiveness, quality of life, and cost.

ID: 4340773 ELECTROCARDIOGRAPHY FROM DEEPER SLEEP BETTER PREDICTS ATRIAL FIBRILLATION RISK; This study developed and validated a single-lead sleep ECG-based AI model to predict the risk of incident atrial fibrillation (AF) using data from the Sleep Heart Health Study. The model demonstrated that ECG data from deeper sleep stages (N2 and N3) yielded better AF risk prediction compared to awake or REM sleep ECGs.

Positional obstructive sleep apnea and cardiovascular outcomes; This single-center study investigated whether patients with positional obstructive sleep apnea (POSA), where apnea occurs predominantly in the supine position, have different future cardiovascular (CV) risk compared to non-positional OSA patients. A Cox proportional hazard model was used to assess the risk of new CV events in patients who underwent polysomnography.

Ends in Multiple Sclerosis Mortality by Race and Ethnicity in the United States: Analysis of the CDC WONDER Database; This study analyzes trends in multiple sclerosis (MS) mortality by race and ethnicity in the United States using the CDC WONDER database. The research aims to identify disparities in MS-related deaths among different racial and ethnic groups.

1112 Association of High-Risk OSA with Incident Atrial Fibrillation: The Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis; This study used data from the Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis (MESA) to examine whether "High-Risk" obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), characterized by high hypoxic burden or heart rate response, is linked to increased incidence of atrial fibrillation (AF). The analysis followed participants for a median of 6.8 years to ascertain new AF events.

Disparities in Antidiabetic Medication Discontinuation Between Non-Hispanic White and Black Beneficiaries in Medicare Across Diabetes Belt and Surrounding Area; This retrospective cohort study used Medicare data to assess racial and geographic disparities in antidiabetic medication discontinuation between non-Hispanic (NH) White and NH Black beneficiaries with type 2 diabetes. A multivariable Cox regression was used to examine the influence of race and location within or outside the Diabetes Belt on medication discontinuation.

Design & analysis of fault tolerant digital systems; This book presents methods for estimating the reliability of digital systems, with a focus on intermittent or transient faults. It provides techniques for analyzing the behavior of systems in the presence of such faults, for which generally applicable results were previously unavailable.

Methods for secure enrollment of personal identity credentials into electronic devices; This work describes a method and system for securely enrolling personal identity credentials into electronic devices, involving a device manufacturer and a recognized enrollment authority. The manufacturer records a unique identifier and a self-generated public key for each device, while the authority validates the individual before enrollment.

Fault-tolerant microprocessor-based systems; This tutorial outlines the causes of faults in microprocessor-based systems and describes the basic techniques for achieving fault tolerance. It addresses how computers can fail and what can be done to deal with those failures.

The Codesign of Embedded Systems: A Unified Hardware/Software Representation: A Unified Hardware/Software Representation; This book describes a cooperative hardware/software codesign approach that utilizes a unified view of hardware and software to overcome limitations of traditional, separate development paths. It presents a unified representation, the decomposition graph, which can describe both hardware and software, enabling better exploration of tradeoffs.

Example application of D_RAMP for Safety Analysis; This paper summarizes the D_RAMP safety analysis methodology and demonstrates its application for quantifying system safety in terms of Mean Time Between Hazardous Events (MTBHE). The D_RAMP toolkit is presented as a novel approach for concurrent verification and validation during the design of real-time computing systems.

Reliability theory and practice for unmanned aerial vehicles; This article presents a critical review of the literature on the reliability of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), covering both theoretical and practical research. It identifies failure causes and reliability challenges, and classifies methods for reliability modeling, analysis, and design of UAV systems.

Men are worse allies than they think; This article defines gender allyship as the purposeful collaboration of men with women to promote gender equality through supportive relationships, sponsorship, and public advocacy. The authors' research suggests that men often perceive themselves as better allies than they actually are.

Object-Oriented Modeling of Hardware for Embedded Systems; This chapter presents the application of object-oriented techniques to the modeling and design of hardware for embedded systems, illustrating a cross-fertilization of ideas from the software domain. It shows how data decomposition can be applied recursively to hardware components, supporting complexity management and refinement through a representation called the component-object graph.

Methods, systems and apparatuses for secure transactions; This invention is directed towards methods, systems, and apparatuses for providing secure and private electronic interactions and transactions. The system provides identity verification of an initiating party and includes a self-destruct mechanism, limiting the transfer of personal data to only what is necessary for the transaction.

Mechanisms of mechanotransduction; This review surveys both specialized and widely expressed mechanosensitive systems, suggesting that physical forces provide a general means of altering protein conformation to generate signals. It argues that essentially all organisms are mechanosensitive and that physical forces regulate a large array of physiological processes.

Rapid displacement of vimentin intermediate filaments in living endothelial cells exposed to flow; This study directly demonstrates the rapid deformation of the vimentin intermediate filament network in living endothelial cells subjected to hemodynamic shear stress. Using time-lapse optical sectioning and deconvolution microscopy, the research shows significant displacement of the filament network within the first three minutes after the onset of flow.

Analysis of SM22α-deficient mice reveals unanticipated insights into smooth muscle cell differentiation and function; This study used gene targeting to generate SM22α-deficient mice to examine the function of this smooth muscle cell (SMC) lineage-restricted protein. The analysis revealed unanticipated insights into SMC differentiation and function, including the temporal and spatial pattern of SM22α transcriptional activation during development.

The cytoskeleton under external fluid mechanical forces: hemodynamic forces acting on the endothelium; This paper discusses the crucial role of the endothelial cytoskeleton in mechanotransduction of hemodynamic shear stress, a key regulator of vascular physiology and pathology. It summarizes recent studies of four-dimensional cytoskeletal motion and strain distribution in living cells, supporting a decentralized model of endothelial mechanotransduction.

Spatiotemporal analysis of flow-induced intermediate filament displacement in living endothelial cells; This study performed a spatiotemporal analysis of flow-induced intermediate filament (IF) displacement in living endothelial cells expressing green fluorescent protein-vimentin. By analyzing time-lapse microscopy images, the research quantified the magnitude and direction of IF network displacement, revealing a rapid, heterogeneous, and primarily downstream deformation in response to shear stress.

Creating Inclusive Environments to Support Learning and Professional Development in Biomedical Engineering Education; This paper, based on workshops from the 2024 Biomedical Engineering (BME) Education Summit, proposes an “Engineering for All” framework to integrate diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) into BME education. The framework outlines strategies for lowering systemic barriers and creating an equitable and inclusive educational environment to support student learning and professional development.

WIP: A Peer-Taught Course to Lower Barriers to Undergraduate Research Experiences; This work-in-progress paper reports on a novel, one-credit, peer-taught course titled “Starting an Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE)” designed to lower barriers to entry into undergraduate research for first-year engineering students. The course combines peer-led instruction and specifications grading to increase students' confidence, guidance, and sense of belonging in research environments.

Correction: Lowering Barriers to Entry in Undergraduate Research Through Student-Led Virtual Workshops; This article is a correction to a previously published paper titled "Lowering Barriers to Entry in Undergraduate Research Through Student-Led Virtual Workshops." It clarifies that the conflict of interest statement was incomplete and should have noted that author Brian Helmke is the Deputy Editor-in-Chief of the journal.

Lowering Barriers to Entry in Undergraduate Research Through Student-Led Virtual Workshops; This paper describes the design and implementation of Starting an Undergraduate Research Experience (SURE), a novel extracurricular workshop series aimed at lowering barriers for engineering students to gain research experiences. The student-led program, developed in fall 2020, provided guidance and small-group mentorship to over 150 students to address challenges like limited guidance and feelings of inadequacy.

Transmission with energy harvesting nodes in fading wireless channels: Optimal policies; This paper considers the optimization of point-to-point data transmission for an energy harvesting transmitter with a limited battery, aiming to maximize throughput by a deadline or minimize transmission completion time. The authors develop optimal offline policies using a directional water-filling algorithm and propose online policies based on stochastic dynamic programming.

Optimal packet scheduling in an energy harvesting communication system; This paper studies the optimal packet scheduling problem for a single-user wireless system where both data packets and harvested energy arrive randomly. The goal is to develop offline scheduling policies that adapt the transmission rate to minimize the time by which all packets are delivered, considering scenarios with and without packet arrivals during transmission.

Optimal status update for age of information minimization with an energy harvesting source; This paper designs optimal online status update policies for an energy harvesting sensor to minimize the long-term average Age of Information (AoI) at a destination. The study considers three battery size scenarios (infinite, finite, and one unit), proposing a best-effort uniform policy for the infinite case and an energy-aware adaptive policy for the finite case.

Broadcasting with an energy harvesting rechargeable transmitter; This paper investigates the transmission completion time minimization problem for an energy harvesting transmitter in a two-user AWGN broadcast channel. The authors analyze the structural properties of the optimal transmission policy, proving that the optimal total transmit power sequence has a structure similar to the single-user case.

Energy cooperation in energy harvesting communications; This paper introduces the concept of energy cooperation, where one energy harvesting user wirelessly transmits energy to another to shape energy arrivals and improve overall system performance. The authors determine optimal energy management policies that maximize throughput for relay, two-way, and multiple access channels with energy harvesting and transfer capabilities.

Robust Offline Reinforcement Learning for Non-Markovian Decision Processes; This paper studies the problem of robust offline reinforcement learning for non-Markovian decision processes where the nominal model has a low-rank structure. The authors propose a new algorithm featuring novel dataset distillation and a lower confidence bound design, and derive new dual forms for robust values to make the algorithm more practical.

Decision feedback in-context symbol detection over block-fading channels; This paper proposes DEcision Feedback IN-ContExt Detection (DEFINED), a new wireless receiver design that performs direct symbol detection using limited pilot data through in-context learning. The key innovation is a decision feedback mechanism where sequentially detected symbols are incorporated into the prompts to improve detections for subsequent symbols.

Augmenting Online RL with Offline Data is All You Need: A Unified Hybrid RL Algorithm Design and Analysis; This paper presents a unified algorithm and analysis for a hybrid reinforcement learning framework where an agent leverages both an offline dataset and online interactions. The results show that augmenting confidence-based online RL algorithms with offline data achieves state-of-the-art results in both sub-optimality gap and online regret minimization.

How Transformers Learn Regular Language Recognition: A Theoretical Study on Training Dynamics and Implicit Bias; This work theoretically analyzes the training dynamics of a one-layer transformer learning regular language recognition tasks, specifically 'even pairs' and 'parity check'. The analysis reveals that the joint training of attention and linear layers exhibits two distinct phases, with the attention layer first growing rapidly and the linear layer later converging towards a max-margin solution.

Entropy and heat transfer analysis using Cattaneo-Christov heat flux model for a boundary layer flow of Casson nanofluid; This paper presents a numerical investigation of Casson nanofluid flow, heat transfer, and entropy generation over a horizontal porous stretching surface. The study uses a finite difference scheme to solve the governing equations, which include effects of Lorentz forces and the Cattaneo-Christov heat flux model, for both Cu-H2O and TiO2-H2O nanofluids.

Mathematical model for thermal solar collectors by using magnetohydrodynamic maxwell nanofluid with slip conditions, thermal radiation and variable thermal conductivity; This paper presents a simplified mathematical model for solar thermal collectors, treating them as a non-uniform unsteady stretching surface with a non-Newtonian Maxwell fluid as the working fluid. The model incorporates a uniform magnetic field, slip boundary conditions, thermal radiation, and variable thermal conductivity to analyze the flow and heat transfer characteristics.

Non-Newtonian flow-induced deformation from pressurized cavities in absorbing porous tissues; This study investigates the behavior of a spherical cavity in a soft biological tissue, modeled as a deformable porous material, during the injection of a non-Newtonian power law fluid. Numerical solutions indicate that shear thickening fluids exhibit less fluid pressure and induce smaller solid deformation compared to shear thinning fluids, while tissue absorption increases for all power law fluids.

Joule and Viscous Dissipation Effects on MHD Boundary Layer Flow over a Stretching Sheet with Variable Thickness; This paper investigates the influence of Joule and viscous dissipation on the magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) boundary layer flow over a stretching sheet with variable thickness and surface temperature. The governing equations are solved numerically using a shooting method to analyze the impact of physical parameters like the power index and magnetic parameter on velocity and temperature profiles.

Infiltration of MHD liquid into a deformable porous material; This paper analyzes the capillary rise dynamics of a magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) fluid flowing through a deformable porous material, including gravity effects, using a mixture theory approach. Numerical solutions show that the capillary rise process for an MHD fluid slows down compared to a Newtonian fluid due to the Lorentz force.

A MATHEMATICAL MODEL OF NON-NEWTONIAN FLUID FLOW THROUGH A POROELASTIC CYLINDER WITH MOVING BOUNDARIES; This paper investigates the radial flow of a non-Newtonian power-law fluid through a poroelastic cylinder with moving boundaries, a problem relevant to applications like fluid flow through arteries and oil extraction. A general one-dimensional nonlinear diffusion equation for dilatation is derived and solved for both constrained and unconstrained cylinder cases.

Effect of inertia on viscous fluid in a wall-driven corner flow with leakage; This study presents an analytical investigation of the inertial flow of a viscous fluid near the corner of two intersecting walls with leakage, where one wall moves parallel to itself. An approximate solution is obtained by applying a recursive approach, yielding expressions for stream functions, velocity fields, and stresses up to the second approximation.

Dendritic cell activation and T cell priming with adjuvant-and antigen-loaded oxidation-sensitive polymersomes; This study applies oxidation-sensitive nanoscale polymersomes for the co-delivery of antigen and adjuvant to dendritic cell (DC) endosomes to elicit cell-mediated immunity. The polymersomes, loaded with a Toll-like receptor agonist, successfully activated DCs and, when co-delivering antigen, induced antigen-specific T cell proliferation and cytokine production.

Toll-like receptor 8 agonist nanoparticles mimic immunomodulating effects of the live BCG vaccine and enhance neonatal innate and adaptive immune responses; This study uses rational engineering to construct polymer nanocarriers that encapsulate a Toll-like receptor (TLR) 8 agonist for selective uptake and intracellular release by dendritic cells (DCs). These nanoparticles were shown to mimic the immunomodulating effects of the live BCG vaccine and enhance both innate and adaptive immune responses in newborns.

Tunable T cell immunity towards a protein antigen using polymersomes vs. solid-core nanoparticles; This study compares the T cell immune responses induced by ovalbumin (OVA) antigen delivered via two different nanocarrier morphologies: watery-core polymersomes (PSs) and solid-core nanoparticles (NPs). The results show that antigen-loaded PSs induced enhanced frequencies of both CD4+ and CD8+ T cells, while antigen-conjugated NPs primarily induced CD8+ T cell responses.

Tailoring nanostructure morphology for enhanced targeting of dendritic cells in atherosclerosis; This study reports that nanostructure morphology alone can be engineered for selective uptake by dendritic cells (DCs), which are critical mediators of atherosclerotic inflammation. Using a multimodal imaging approach, the research found that filamentous nanostructures (filomicelles) exhibited significantly enhanced targeting of DCs in atherosclerotic plaques compared to spherical nanoparticles.

Facile assembly and loading of theranostic polymersomes via multi-impingement flash nanoprecipitation; This paper presents flash nanoprecipitation (FNP) as a single, customizable method for the rapid and scalable assembly of various soft nanoarchitectures, including polymersomes, from block copolymers. The study demonstrates that multiple impingements during the FNP process can decrease vesicle diameter and polydispersity, enabling gram-scale fabrication of monodisperse theranostic polymersomes.

Linking autophagy to endothelial cell immunogenicity in transplant-associated ischemia-reperfusion injury; This study investigates the role of autophagy in the activation and immunogenicity of microvascular endothelial cells (ECs) during cold storage and ischemia-reperfusion injury in heart transplantation. Using genetic and pharmacological modulation, the research found that inhibiting autophagy in ECs reduced their activation and subsequent T cell-mediated alloimmune responses.

Facile Assembly of Soft Nanoarchitectures and Co-Loading of Hydrophilic and Hydrophobic Molecules via Flash Nanoprecipitation; This work describes flash nanoprecipitation methods for the facile assembly of soft nanoarchitectures and the co-loading of both hydrophilic and hydrophobic molecules. The techniques enable the encapsulation of various target molecules, including bioactive protein therapeutics, within amphiphilic copolymer nanocarriers.

Filomicelle-Embedded Composite Hydrogels for Localized Gelation within the Anterior Chamber of the Eye; This paper presents a composite hydrogel (C-gel) embedded with filomicelles that enables localized in situ gelation and sustained nanocarrier release within the anterior chamber of the eye. The filamentous structure of the filomicelles confines crosslinking reactions, promoting efficient gel formation and retention, while their oxidation-induced transition facilitates gradual nanocarrier release for over a month.

A biomimetic multi-component subunit vaccine via ratiometric loading of hierarchical hydrogels; This paper reports a hierarchical hydrogel depot vaccine that enables ratiometric loading of a protein antigen and four distinct adjuvants using simple poly(propylene sulfone) homopolymers. This 5-component nanogel vaccine, capable of noncovalent anchoring to subcutaneous tissues, demonstrated enhanced humoral and cell-mediated immune responses in mice compared to standard single-adjuvant formulations.

New tools for genetic targeting of the Schlemm's canal endothelium; This study develops a novel nanocarrier system to deliver the active tamoxifen metabolite, 4-OH-tamoxifen, specifically to the Schlemm’s canal (SC) endothelium for genetic studies in glaucoma research. This system, using poly(ethylene glycol)-b-poly(propylene sulfide) nanocarriers with a VEGF-C derived peptide, provides highly efficient, SC-specific gene deletion and eliminates systemic phenotypes in nonspecific Cre mouse strains.

Supporting controlled experimentation with testing techniques: An infrastructure and its potential impact; This paper describes the design and construction of a research infrastructure created to support controlled experimentation with software testing and regression testing techniques. The infrastructure aims to address the high cost and difficulty of obtaining necessary components for such experiments, thereby facilitating progress and the generation of empirical data in the field.

Test case prioritization: A family of empirical studies; This paper presents a family of empirical studies comparing various test case prioritization techniques aimed at increasing a test suite's rate of fault detection. The studies address questions about targeting specific modified versions, trade-offs between fine and coarse granularity, and the potential benefits of incorporating fault-proneness measures.

Prioritizing test cases for regression testing; This paper investigates test case prioritization techniques, which schedule test cases to increase their effectiveness in meeting performance goals like improving the rate of fault detection. The studies address whether prioritization can be effective for specific modified versions, the tradeoffs between different granularities, and if incorporating fault-proneness measures improves effectiveness.

Incorporating varying test costs and fault severities into test case prioritization; This paper presents a new metric, APFDc, for assessing the rate of fault detection of prioritized test cases that incorporates varying test case costs and fault severities. A case study illustrating the application of the metric is presented, raising practical questions that may arise when applying such a metric.

Techniques for improving regression testing in continuous integration development environments; This work presents algorithms to make regression testing in continuous integration development environments more cost-effective. The approach uses regression test selection techniques in a pre-submit phase to choose a subset of tests, and test case prioritization in a post-submit phase to provide faster feedback on test failures.

T4PC: Training Deep Neural Networks for Property Conformance; This paper proposes T4PC, a framework designed to increase the conformance of Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) to specified properties during the training process, rather than after. T4PC achieves this by enriching the data preparation phase to account for property preconditions and the training phase to account for property satisfaction.

Steering the Future: A Catalog of Failures in Deep Learning-Enabled Robotic Navigation Systems; This paper introduces Defects4DeepNav, a growing catalog of over 100 failures from a deep learning-enabled commercial robotic navigation system operating in the real world. The catalog, which includes diverse failures and full sensor data, serves as a key instrument to drive the evolution and assessment of program analysis techniques for robotic systems.

10 Years Later: Revisiting How Developers Search for Code; This paper revisits a 2015 study on developers' code search practices by conducting three new surveys with over 1,900 responses to see how practices have evolved over the last decade. The study explores whether the original observations about why, how often, and in what situations developers search for code have stood the test of time amid changes like new languages and AI tools.

Scene Flow Specifications: Encoding and Monitoring Rich Temporal Safety Properties of Autonomous Systems; This work introduces Scene Flow Specifications to overcome the limitations of scene graphs in expressing temporal safety properties for autonomous driving systems. The new specification language and its associated monitoring framework enable the encoding and runtime monitoring of rich temporal properties, such as right-of-way at intersections.

Monitoring safety properties for autonomous driving systems with vision-language models; This paper investigates the use of Vision-Language Models (VLMs) to monitor safety properties for autonomous driving systems by extracting spatial relationships from real images, bridging the semantic gap between high-level properties and raw sensor data. To facilitate this, the authors created DriST, a dataset of road-scene images with extracted spatial triplets, and evaluated VLM performance on this new task.

A community-driven global reconstruction of human metabolism; This paper describes Recon 2, a community-driven consensus model that provides the most comprehensive reconstruction of human metabolism for computational analysis. The model was validated by accurately predicting biomarkers for inborn errors of metabolism and has been used to generate a compendium of cell type-specific models.

Applications of genome‐scale metabolic reconstructions; This review examines the major applications of genome-scale metabolic reconstructions, including contextualizing high-throughput data, guiding metabolic engineering, directing hypothesis-driven discovery, interrogating multi-species relationships, and discovering network properties. It also highlights trends and future directions in the field that will have a broad impact on biology.

Reconstruction of cellular signalling networks and analysis of their properties; This review discusses the reconstruction of large-scale cellular signalling networks, enabled by advances in high-throughput technologies over the past 20 years. It emphasizes the need to describe the properties of these carefully reconstructed networks within an integrative and quantitative modeling framework that accounts for their complexity.

Genome-scale microbial in silico models: the constraints-based approach; This paper reviews the constraints-based approach for creating and analyzing genome-scale microbial in silico models, which are reconstructed from genome sequencing and annotation. It highlights that such models have successfully predicted substrate preference, gene deletion consequences, and optimal growth patterns with a high degree of accuracy.

MEMOTE for standardized genome-scale metabolic model testing; This paper reports on MEMOTE, a community-developed, standardized test suite for assessing the quality of genome-scale metabolic models (GEMs). MEMOTE aims to address the lack of quality control and issues like incompatible formats and missing annotations that limit the reuse and interoperability of GEMs.

Reframing the role of the objective function in its proper context for metabolic network modeling; This commentary reframes the discussion around the "objective function" in metabolic network modeling to enhance its value and clarify common misunderstandings. It argues for placing the objective function in its proper context to better drive deeper understanding of cellular metabolism.

Genome-scale metabolic network reconstruction analysis identifies bacterial vaginosis-associated metabolic interactions; This study uses genome-scale metabolic network reconstructions (GENREs) to analyze metagenomic data from vaginal swabs and predict metabolic interactions associated with bacterial vaginosis (BV). In silico simulations and co-culture experiments revealed functional metabolic relationships between BV-associated species that are distinct from their genetic relatedness.

Methods, systems and compositions for the prediction and prevention of parenteral nutrition associated cholestasis using fecal biomarkers; This work provides fecal biomarkers for diagnosing and assessing the risk of parenteral nutrition-associated cholestasis (PNAC) in subjects, particularly infants. The methods enable early identification of high-risk infants, allowing clinicians to optimize nutrition and proactively mitigate PNAC development.

Comparison of parametric and nonparametric models for traffic flow forecasting; This research compares parametric seasonal ARIMA models with nonparametric regression models for single point, short-term traffic flow forecasting. The study finds that refined nonparametric regression models can deliver statistically superior results compared to seasonal ARIMA models, motivating further investigation into data-driven approaches.

Traffic flow forecasting: comparison of modeling approaches; This research developed and tested four models—historical average, time-series, neural network, and nonparametric regression—for forecasting freeway traffic flow 15 minutes into the future. The nonparametric regression model significantly outperformed the other models, experiencing statistically lower errors in tests on two sites in Northern Virginia.

Short-Term Traffic Flow Prediction: Neural Network Approach; This paper explores the use of a neural network approach for short-term traffic flow prediction. The research aims to develop a model capable of accurately forecasting traffic conditions in the near future.

Traffic signal control with connected vehicles; This paper presents the predictive microscopic simulation algorithm, a new, decentralized, fully adaptive traffic control algorithm that uses data from connected vehicles. The algorithm employs a rolling-horizon strategy to choose signal phasing that optimizes an objective function of delay, stops, and queue length over a 15-second future period.

Divine war in the Old Testament and in the ancient Near East; This book explores the concept of divine war in the Old Testament and compares it to similar concepts in the broader ancient Near East. The work is part of a series covering all areas of Old Testament research, including the Hebrew Bible and its connections to neighboring cultures.

0844 Dermal fibroblast-derived thrombospondin 2 orchestrates extracellular matrix organization and influences wound healing; This study investigates the role of dermal fibroblast-derived thrombospondin 2 in extracellular matrix organization and wound healing, particularly in chronic diabetic and leprosy-related foot ulcers. The research compares Platelet-Rich Plasma (PRP) therapy with conventional treatment, assessing wound healing through various clinical and laboratory parameters.

Evaluating current and future pedestrian mid-block crossing safety treatments using virtual reality simulation; This research presents a case study using virtual reality (VR) simulation to evaluate pedestrian behavior and safety with three different mid-block crossing treatments. The study demonstrates how immersive virtual environments can be used as a proactive, low-risk platform to compare design alternatives and ITS technologies before real-world implementation.

Immersive collaboration of remote participants via media displays; This invention describes an immersive digital experience for video conferencing that simulates the common presence of a remote participant in a local environment. The system may use a transparent media display to project the participant's image, place a camera behind the display at gaze level, and add virtual overlays to enhance the sense of depth.

Cyberattack monitoring architectures for resilient operation of connected and automated vehicles; This paper develops a prototype real-time monitoring system for a V2I-based connected and automated vehicle (CAV) system to detect cyberattacks and ensure resilient operation. The system uses a long-short term memory (LSTM) neural network to detect deviations from normal CAV operation and trigger countermeasures to revert the system to a safe state.

Display construct for media projection and wireless charging; This invention describes a display construct that integrates media projection and wireless charging capabilities. The technology aims to combine visual display functionalities with the convenience of wirelessly powering devices.

Research Progress on Memristor: From Synapses to Computing Systems; This survey provides a comparative overview of research progress on memristors, from their use as synaptic devices to their application in new computing systems. It classifies different memristor synaptic devices, analyzes their working mechanisms, and discusses the advantages of crossbar-based memristors for vector-matrix multiplication and in-memory computing.

ReTransformer: ReRAM-based Processing-in-Memory Architecture for Transformer Acceleration; This paper proposes ReTransformer, a ReRAM-based Processing-in-Memory (PIM) architecture designed to accelerate Transformer models for NLP applications. The architecture addresses the performance bottleneck of the scaled dot-product attention mechanism and proposes a fine-grained pipeline design to handle matrix multiplication and intermediate results efficiently.

Harnessing Optoelectronic Noises in a Photonic Generative Network; This paper demonstrates a photonic generative network, implemented as part of a generative adversarial network (GAN), that harnesses inherent optoelectronic noises for computation. The network, which uses a photonic core of programmable phase-change memory cells, can generate handwritten digits and demonstrates resilience to noise through noise-aware training.

Multi-Objective Optimization of ReRAM Crossbars for Robust DNN Inferencing under Stochastic Noise; This paper proposes a multi-objective optimization framework for designing robust, area- and energy-efficient ReRAM-based hardware accelerators for DNN inferencing. The framework includes a stochastic-noise-aware training method (ReSNA) and an information-theoretic algorithm (CF-MESMO) to identify Pareto-optimal solutions that trade off accuracy, area, time, and energy.

Memory Is All You Need: An Overview of Compute-in-Memory Architectures for Accelerating Large Language Model Inference; This survey paper provides an overview of compute-in-memory (CIM) architectures for accelerating large language model (LLM) inference, addressing the challenges of growing computational and memory demands. It reviews transformer-based models and various CIM designs, highlighting challenges, trends, and insights for using CIM to overcome the memory wall in modern AI systems.

Norm-Q: Effective Compression Method for Hidden Markov Models in Neuro-Symbolic Applications; This paper proposes Norm-Q, a normalized linear quantization approach for compressing probabilistic symbolic models like Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) used in neuro-symbolic applications. The method introduces a normalized quantization-aware expectation-maximization process during training, achieving high compression rates with minimal impact on performance, thereby reducing memory and bandwidth stress.

Titanus: Enabling KV Cache Pruning and Quantization On-the-Fly for LLM Acceleration; This paper proposes Titanus, a software-hardware co-design that efficiently compresses the key-value (KV) cache on-the-fly to accelerate large language model (LLM) inference. Titanus uses a cascade pruning-quantization method and a customized two-stage design space exploration framework to significantly improve energy efficiency and throughput compared to GPU and other accelerator designs.

AutoRAC: Automated Processing-in-Memory Accelerator Design for Recommender Systems; This paper proposes AutoRAC, a framework that automates the co-optimization of recommender models and Processing-In-Memory (PIM) accelerator designs. AutoRAC formulates the problem as a combinatorial search over mixed-precision operations and uses a one-shot supernet to efficiently explore the vast design space, achieving significant speedups over state-of-the-art PIM accelerators.

Neuromorphic Computing in the Era of Large Models; This survey explores the intersection of neuromorphic computing and large-scale deep learning models like BERT and GPT, focusing on how neuromorphic principles can address their significant computational and energy challenges. It reviews neuromorphic models, learning methods, and hardware, while also examining the scalability limitations of current neuromorphic systems and identifying future directions.

Optimizing and Exploring System Performance in Compact Processing-in-Memory-based Chips; This work optimizes system performance for compact Processing-in-Memory (PIM) designs, which face challenges when neural network weights exceed on-chip memory capacity. The authors propose a novel pipeline method and scheduling algorithm that maximizes weight reuse and mitigates pipeline bubbles, achieving significant improvements in throughput and energy efficiency for compact PIM chips.

A Deeper Look at Experience Replay; This paper presents a systematic empirical study of experience replay in deep reinforcement learning, rethinking its utility and focusing on the underestimated importance of the memory buffer size. The study showcases that a large replay buffer can significantly hurt performance and proposes a simple O(1) method to remedy this negative influence.

GradientDICE: Rethinking Generalized Offline Estimation of Stationary Values; This paper presents GradientDICE, a method for estimating the density ratio between the target policy's state distribution and the sampling distribution in off-policy reinforcement learning, which fixes problems in the state-of-the-art GenDICE. By using a different objective based on the Perron-Frobenius theorem, GradientDICE avoids the need for nonlinear parameterization and is provably convergent under linear function approximation.

Distributional Reinforcement Learning for Efficient Exploration; This paper proposes a novel and efficient exploration method for distributional deep reinforcement learning that utilizes the estimated value distribution to model both parametric and intrinsic uncertainties. The method combines a decaying schedule to suppress intrinsic uncertainty with an exploration bonus from the upper quantiles of the learned distribution, achieving significant performance gains in Atari games and a driving simulator.

DAC: The Double Actor-Critic Architecture for Learning Options; This paper reformulates the option framework as two parallel augmented MDPs, which allows any policy optimization algorithm to learn intra-option policies, termination conditions, and a master policy. Applying an actor-critic algorithm to this formulation yields the Double Actor-Critic (DAC) architecture, which outperforms its hierarchy-free counterpart in challenging robot simulation tasks.

mlpack 3: a fast, flexible machine learning library; This paper introduces mlpack 3, a fast and flexible machine learning library written in C++ with bindings for other languages like Python. The library is designed for scalability and efficiency, enabling researchers and practitioners to quickly prototype and develop solutions for large-scale data problems.

Extensions of Robbins-Siegmund Theorem with Applications in Reinforcement Learning; This paper extends the Robbins-Siegmund theorem for almost supermartingales where the zero-order term is not summable but square summable, a condition often not met in reinforcement learning (RL) applications. By introducing a mild assumption on the increments, the new results establish almost sure convergence to a bounded set and provide convergence rates, with applications shown for stochastic approximation and Q-learning.

Finite Sample Analysis of Linear Temporal Difference Learning with Arbitrary Features; This paper establishes the first convergence rates for the linear Temporal Difference (TD) learning algorithm when operating with arbitrary, potentially linearly dependent, features. To address the non-uniqueness of solutions, the authors develop a novel stochastic approximation result that provides convergence rates to the solution set rather than a single point.

Changing the resilience paradigm; This article argues that resilience management must go beyond traditional risk management to address the complexities of large, integrated systems and the uncertainties of future threats. It emphasizes the need for a new paradigm to handle challenges like climate change.

Inoperability input-output model for interdependent infrastructure sectors. I: Theory and methodology; This paper presents the theory and methodology of the inoperability input-output model (IIM), which is based on Leontief’s economic model and characterizes interdependencies among infrastructure sectors. The IIM analyzes initial disruptions and their ripple effects, and a dynamic extension analyzes recovery over time to help prioritize critical sectors.

Risk filtering, ranking, and management framework using hierarchical holographic modeling; This paper contributes an eight-phase methodological framework for identifying, prioritizing, assessing, and managing risk scenarios for a large-scale system. The framework uses qualitative screening and hierarchical holographic modeling initially, followed by quantitative evaluation and ranking to manage a large number of potential risk scenarios.

Inoperability input-output model for interdependent infrastructure sectors. II: Case studies; This paper discusses case studies applying the inoperability input-output model (IIM) to assess the impacts of willful attacks, specifically high-altitude electromagnetic pulse (HEMP) scenarios, on interdependent sectors. The studies use parametric and uncertainty analyses to assess initial disruption intensity, recovery characteristics, and the efficacy of economic loss reduction policies.

Risk of extreme events under nonstationary conditions; This paper examines the concept of the return period for extreme events under nonstationary conditions, such as those potentially caused by climate change. It explores how the definition of return period as the expected waiting time before failure can be adapted to account for changing probabilities of events like floods and droughts.

Enterprise Risk Management of Electronics and Computing Device Supply Chains; This chapter describes principles and methods from operations research and systems engineering that support the enterprise risk management of electronics and computing device supply chains. It covers the risk management process, from identifying hazards like counterfeiting to quantifying risks and designing countermeasures, which is critical for ensuring component security and reliability.

Management of Electronics and Computing Device Supply Chains; This chapter discusses the complexity of managing semiconductor supply chains, which involve numerous steps, resources, and stakeholders from design to distribution. It advocates for a systems engineering perspective to manage the intricate processes and multiple interests inherent in the industry across different time horizons.

Supply Chains of Computer and Electronics Hardware with Resilience to Counterfeiting and Other Disruptions; This chapter addresses the vulnerabilities of supply chains, particularly those for electronic hardware in cyber-physical systems, with a focus on resilience to counterfeiting and other disruptions. It discusses metrics for cyber resilience, reviews research on emerging topics, and emphasizes the need for strategies that go beyond traditional risk assessment to ensure robustness and adaptability.

Can AI help authors prepare better risk science manuscripts?; This perspective reports on the evaluation of two experimental AI systems designed to assist authors and reviewers in the scientific peer-review process for risk science manuscripts. The study explores whether AI tools can provide useful feedback, improve manuscript quality, and avoid the biases of human reviewers, or if they might instead add noise and erode trust.

Systems Analysis and Negotiation of Strategic Partnerships in the Supply of Biofuels to Commercial Aviation; This paper uses a case study on biofuel distribution to Dulles International Airport to demonstrate a systems engineering-based supply chain analysis, covering stakeholder mapping, scenario evaluations, and resilience analysis. It introduces the Engagement, Financing, and Time Horizon Analysis (EFHA) matrix to support stakeholder negotiations for complex energy and fuel supply chains.

Improving viability of stem cells during syringe needle flow through the design of hydrogel cell carriers; This study demonstrates that the cell injection process itself causes significant acute loss of cell viability due to mechanical membrane disruption at clinically relevant rates. As a protective strategy, the research shows that encapsulating various cell types within alginate hydrogels of specific mechanical properties significantly improves their viability during injection.

Maintenance of neural progenitor cell stemness in 3D hydrogels requires matrix remodelling; This study investigates how 3D hydrogel properties affect the maintenance of neural progenitor cell (NPC) stemness, finding that hydrogel degradation is necessary for this process. The requirement for degradation was independent of stiffness or adhesive ligand presentation and relied on matrix remodeling to facilitate cadherin-mediated cell-cell contact and β-catenin signaling.

Stimuli-responsive, pentapeptide, nanofiber hydrogel for tissue engineering; This paper reports a new class of short, five-residue peptides that self-assemble into nanofiber hydrogels suitable for neural tissue engineering. The study characterizes how sequence variations, pH, and concentration alter the mechanical properties of these stimuli-responsive hydrogels, which exhibit shear-thinning and rapid self-healing.

Defining and designing polymers and hydrogels for neural tissue engineering; This review aims to provide neuroscientists with basic information about hydrogels and their use as cell and drug delivery devices for neural tissue applications. It illustrates the many tunable properties of hydrogels and emphasizes their importance in obtaining reliable results for treating a broad range of neurological disorders.

Design of three-dimensional engineered protein hydrogels for tailored control of neurite growth; This study uses engineered elastin-like protein (ELP) hydrogels with modular bioactive and structural regions to systematically investigate the effects of cell-adhesive ligand density and hydrogel stiffness on neurite growth in 3D. The results show that both increasing RGD ligand density and decreasing hydrogel stiffness independently promote neurite outgrowth from dorsal root ganglia.

In Vitro Tissue Models of Neural Cell Development Towards Myelination and Remyelination; This research focuses on developing in vitro tissue models to study neural cell development, with a specific emphasis on the processes of myelination and remyelination. The goal is to create better experimental systems for understanding the complex interactions that lead to the formation of myelin sheaths around axons.

High-rate mechano-stimulation alters proliferation-and maturation-related signaling of oligodendrocyte precursor cells in a 3D hydrogel; This study aims to elucidate how oligodendrocyte precursor cells (OPCs) respond to the mechanical forces associated with mild traumatic brain injury (TBI). Using a 3D hydrogel model, the research investigates how high-rate mechano-stimulation alters the proliferation- and maturation-related signaling of OPCs, a promising therapeutic target for post-injury repair.

Guiding oligodendrocyte progenitor cell maturation using electrospun fiber cues in a 3D hyaluronic acid hydrogel culture system; This study introduces a 3D hyaluronic acid (HA) hydrogel system containing encapsulated electrospun HA fibers to guide oligodendrocyte progenitor cell (OPC) maturation. The research investigates the effects of fiber presence and hydrogel stiffness on OPC proliferation, metabolic activity, and morphological changes to better model myelination.

Effects of cell-adhesive ligand presentation on pentapeptide supramolecular assembly and gelation: Simulations and Experiments; This study combines simulations and experiments to investigate how the presentation of cell-adhesive ligands affects the supramolecular assembly and gelation of pentapeptide hydrogels. The research aims to decouple the effects of biomechanics and cell-matrix interactions in 3D environments to better understand their impact on neural lineages.

Electrochemical techniques in corrosion science and engineering; This book describes the origin, use, and limitations of electrochemical methods in corrosion science, including phase diagrams, testing schemes, and characterization of passivity. It offers practical guidelines for assessing active, passive, and localized corrosion, as well as methods for process alteration and materials selection.

Accurate electrochemical measurement of magnesium corrosion rates; a combined impedance, mass-loss and hydrogen collection study; This study conducted simultaneous electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, hydrogen gas collection, and mass-loss measurements during the corrosion of pure magnesium in NaCl solutions. The results show that the polarization resistance determined from impedance data, when accounting for a low-frequency inductive response, provides excellent correlation with corrosion rates measured by mass loss and hydrogen evolution.

Corrosion tests and standards: application and interpretation; This manual serves as a source book on corrosion tests and standards, providing guidelines for recognizing corrosion types and understanding testing fundamentals. The second edition has been revised and updated to include the most recent technologies, offering tools for making calculations, interpretations, and correlations in corrosion science.

Corrosion of magnesium alloys: the role of alloying; This article reviews the influence of alloying on the corrosion of magnesium (Mg) alloys, with a particular focus on the underlying electrochemical kinetics that dictate the corrosion rate. It provides a holistic and in-depth analysis of the chemistry-corrosion link, which is crucial as the use of Mg alloys in transport and electronics continues to grow.

Electrochemical impedance: analysis and interpretation; This book is a collection of twenty-seven papers on electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, grouped into six categories covering corrosion process characterization, data validation, inhibition, and corrosion of specific materials like aluminum and steel. The topics include applications of Kramers-Kronig transformations and the evaluation of coatings on metal substrates.

Evaluating Cold-Rolling and Irradiation Effects on Corrosion Resistance of Ni-Cr Alloys in Molten Flinak Salt; This study evaluates the effects of cold-rolling and irradiation on the corrosion resistance of Ni-Cr alloys when exposed to molten FLiNaK salt. The research aims to understand how these processing methods impact the material's performance in high-temperature, corrosive environments relevant to advanced nuclear reactors.

The Effect of Temperature on the Dealloying Behavior of Binary Ni-20Cr Alloy in Molten Flinak; This study investigates the effect of temperature on the dealloying behavior of a binary Ni-20Cr alloy immersed in molten FLiNaK salt. The research aims to understand how elevated temperatures influence the selective corrosion process in this high-temperature molten salt environment.

Investigating the Role of Alloying a Third Element on the Aqueous Passivation of Fe-Co-Ni-Cr-Al Compositionally Complex Alloys and Conventional Ternary Alloys …; This research investigates the role of adding a third element to Fe-Co-Ni-Cr-Al compositionally complex alloys and conventional ternary alloys on their aqueous passivation behavior. The study aims to understand how these alloying additions influence the formation and stability of passive films in corrosive environments.

Passivity and Pitting of Single-phase FeCoNi-Cr-Al Compositionally Complex alloys: An Al-Cr Third Element Effect in Sulfuric Acid containing Chloride; This study investigated the synergistic effects of Al on Cr passivation in a family of single-phase FeCoNi-Cr-Al compositionally complex alloys (CCAs) in chloride-containing sulfuric acid. Results showed that CCAs with both Cr and small amounts of Al achieved excellent passivation and resistance to pitting corrosion, outperforming alloys with only Cr and even 304L stainless steel.

Revisiting the Influence of Sn in Cu-Al Alloys: A Third Element Effect Enabling Stainless Steel Type Corrosion Behavior; This study revisits the influence of Sn alloying additions on the aqueous passivation of Cu-Al alloys, revealing a new third element effect that enables stainless steel-like corrosion behavior. Using electrochemical and spectroscopic techniques, the research shows that small Sn additions to Cu-Al alloys with sufficient Al content lead to the formation of a protective, Al-oxide-rich passive film.

Urban freeway traffic flow prediction: application of seasonal autoregressive integrated moving average and exponential smoothing models; This paper addresses the application of seasonal time series models, specifically seasonal ARIMA and Winters exponential smoothing, to the problem of single-interval traffic flow forecasting on urban freeways. The models were developed and tested on data from two sites on the Capital Beltway, with the results showing that seasonal models provided a better fit than those used in prior research.

Automatic crime prediction using events extracted from twitter posts; This paper presents a preliminary investigation into predicting criminal incidents, specifically hit-and-runs, using events extracted from Twitter posts. The approach combines automatic semantic analysis of tweets with latent Dirichlet allocation and linear modeling, demonstrating that the model outperforms a uniform baseline.

Health-status monitoring through analysis of behavioral patterns; This paper describes the SmartHouse project, which uses a system of basic sensors for remote, in-home monitoring of an elder's activities to support independent living. The study examined whether mixture models could be used to detect behavioral patterns from the sensor data, with results evaluated against a log of events kept by the occupant.

Quantifying the relative importance of survival threats to a long-lived reptile using expert elicitation; This study used a threat assessment with expert-elicited estimates to quantify the relative impact of various stage-specific threats on the population growth rate of the wood turtle. The results indicated that predators had the largest effect on hatchling and juvenile survival, while road mortality had the largest effect on adult survival.

Examining Vision Language Models through Multi-dimensional Experiments with Vision and Text Features; This paper develops a multi-dimensional framework to systematically examine how characteristics of both the input image and the accompanying prompt affect the performance and biases of Vision Language Models (VLMs). Using open-source VLMs, the research explores how attention values fluctuate with varying input parameters to understand and characterize changes in VLM behavior.

MisstepMath: A Diverse Student Mistake Dataset for AI in Mathematics Teacher Training; This paper introduces MisstepMath, a novel semi-synthetic dataset of 12,000 categorized student mistakes in mathematics, paired with instructional teacher responses, designed to enhance AI-driven teacher training. Developed through expert brainstorming, AI-assisted generation, and expert refinement, the dataset provides diverse and contextually rich simulations of student errors from Kindergarten to Grade 8.

A Bayesian Survival Analysis on Long COVID and Non-Long COVID Patients: A Cohort Study Using National COVID Cohort Collaborative (N3C) Data; This paper describes the creation of a balanced COVID-positive cohort from the National COVID Cohort Collaborative (N3C) database to evaluate whether a documented Long COVID diagnosis is associated with decreased survival length. A Bayesian survival analysis was conducted on the cohort, which was balanced by the presence or absence of the ICD-10-CM code for Long COVID.

Predictive Modeling and Machine Learning Insights into Multi-Drug Resistant Tuberculosis Treatment Outcomes; This study applied logistic regression, random forest, and XGBoost models to predict treatment outcomes for multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) using data from cohorts in Tanzania, Bangladesh, and Siberia. The models were trained on data stratified by treatment regimen to identify individuals at higher risk of treatment failure in low- and middle-income contexts.

PdSe2: Pentagonal Two-Dimensional Layers with High Air Stability for Electronics; This work reports on the atomic structure, electronic properties, and vibrational modes of few-layered PdSe2, a pentagonal 2D layered noble transition metal dichalcogenide that is stable in air. Micro-absorption spectroscopy and first-principles calculations reveal a wide band gap variation from 0 eV in bulk to 1.3 eV in a monolayer, and field-effect transistors demonstrate its potential for electronic applications.

Advances and future prospects of spin-transfer torque random access memory; This paper reviews the progress and future prospects of spin-transfer torque random access memory (STT-RAM), a potentially universal memory technology. It discusses the performance requirements for the core magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) element and reports on progress in device design, material improvement, and CMOS integration for a demonstration test chip.

Unified description of molecular conduction: From molecules to metallic wires; This paper describes a rigorous and computationally simple method for calculating the conductance of molecular conductors by combining quantum chemistry methods with a nonequilibrium Green’s function formalism. The approach uses self-energy matrices to partition the structure and is used to demonstrate the transition from metallic conduction in a gold nanowire to resonant conduction in a phenyl dithiol molecule.

Computational investigation of half-Heusler compounds for spintronics applications; This paper presents first-principles density functional calculations of the electronic structure, magnetism, and structural stability of 378 XYZ half-Heusler compounds. The study finds that a "Slater-Pauling gap" in the density of states is a common feature that contributes significantly to the stability of these compounds, many of which are predicted to be half-metallic ferromagnets.

Electron optics with pn junctions in ballistic graphene; This study uses transverse magnetic focusing to probe the propagation of charge carriers across an electrostatically defined p-n junction in ballistic graphene. The results show agreement with the predicted Snell’s law for electrons, including the observation of both positive and negative refraction, paving the way for electron optics based on graphene junctions.

Economic mpc with an online reference trajectory for battery scheduling considering demand charge management; This work designs an economic model predictive control (EMPC) formulation for battery energy storage system (BESS) dispatch to manage monthly demand charges in microgrids with variable renewable energy. To overcome the need for an unrealistic full-month reference trajectory, the EMPC is designed for 24 to 48-hour horizons with a corresponding reference trajectory computed online at each time step.

Economic Model Predictive Control with a Non-Fixed Reference Trajectory for Optimal Microgrid Dispatch; This paper proposes an Economic Model Predictive Control (EMPC) formulation for optimal microgrid dispatch that does not require a-priori knowledge of an optimal steady state or periodic trajectory. The framework is proven to have an asymptotic average economic cost no worse than any other non-fixed reference trajectory, and realistic simulations demonstrate its effectiveness.

Degradation Aware Optimal Allocation of Battery Energy Storage System for Unbalanced Active Distribution Network; This article proposes a battery energy storage system (BESS) integration approach for unbalanced active distribution networks that considers both cycle and calendar aging of the battery. A mixed-integer linear programming problem is formulated to minimize investment, operation, and degradation costs while supporting the network, as tested on an IEEE 37 bus system.

Demonstration of alloy scattering in quaternary Sb-based Avalanche Photodiodes; This paper presents a physics-based approach to calculate the alloy scattering rate in Sb-based quaternary alloys for avalanche photodiodes (APDs). The method, which considers screened Coulomb interactions and band non-parabolicity, advances Monte Carlo simulations for more precise modeling and improved design of APDs.

A periciliary brush promotes the lung health by separating the mucus layer from airway epithelia; This paper proposes a gel-on-brush model for airway mucus clearance, where a periciliary layer occupied by membrane-spanning mucins and mucopolysaccharides acts as a brush to separate the mucus layer from the epithelia. This model explains the stability of mucus clearance in health and its failure in airway diseases based on the relative osmotic moduli of the mucus and periciliary brush layers.

Tough self-healing elastomers by molecular enforced integration of covalent and reversible networks; This paper describes the design and fabrication of a tough, self-healing hybrid polymer network by crosslinking randomly branched polymers that carry motifs for both reversible hydrogen bonds and permanent covalent crosslinks. Forcing these two immiscible bond types to mix at the molecular level results in a "dry" elastomer with a very high fracture energy and excellent self-healing capability.

Mobility of Nonsticky Nanoparticles in Polymer Liquids; This paper uses scaling theory to derive the time dependence of the mean-square displacement of a nonsticky nanoparticle moving in polymer solutions and melts. The analysis shows that particle motion transitions from ordinary diffusion to subdiffusion and back to diffusion depending on the particle size relative to the polymer correlation length and tube diameter.

Self-healing of unentangled polymer networks with reversible bonds; This paper uses scaling theory to study a simple model of autonomic self-healing in unentangled polymer networks with reversible bonds. The analysis of reaction kinetics reveals that the recovery of material strength across a fractured interface occurs faster after a shorter waiting time between fracture and healing.

Cystic fibrosis airway secretions exhibit mucin hyperconcentration and increased osmotic pressure; This study investigates mucin concentrations in cystic fibrosis (CF) airway secretions, finding that while immunologically based techniques show low concentrations, physical measurement techniques reveal hyperconcentration compared to normal secretions. This hyperconcentration, along with increased osmotic pressure, is consistent with a model where mucus stasis in CF is driven by compression of the periciliary layer.

Hybrid 3D Printing of Anisotropic Bottlebrush Polymer Nanocomposites; This work explores the hybrid 3D printing of anisotropic bottlebrush polymer nanocomposites. The research aims to create materials with controlled structural anisotropy by combining advanced polymer synthesis with additive manufacturing techniques.

Method and system for all-aqueous printing of viscoelastic droplets; This document describes a method and system for all-aqueous printing of viscoelastic droplets into a receiving material. The process involves controlling the deposition flow velocity and nozzle detachment acceleration to form and position a captive viscoelastic droplet.

Molecular Structure of Foldable Bottlebrush Polymers in Melts; This paper presents the deterministic relationships among molecular architecture, mesoscopic conformation, and macroscopic properties of foldable bottlebrush polymers with incompatible side chains and backbones. A combination of scaling theory and experiments reveals that as side chain length increases, the backbone collapses into a globule, leading to a transition from a stretchable to a brittle material.

A gel coated air-liquid-interface culture system with tunable substrate stiffness matching healthy and diseased lung tissues; This disclosure describes an air-liquid-interface culture apparatus featuring a porous support coated with a polyacrylamide hydrogel layer. The hydrogel's mechanical properties are designed to mimic the extracellular matrix of the human airway, providing a more physiologically relevant environment for culturing epithelial cells.

Immersive virtual environments versus physical built environments: A benchmarking study for building design and user-built environment explorations; This study benchmarks immersive virtual environments against physical built environments to better understand user-environment interactions for building design and exploration. The research aims to leverage technologies like virtual and augmented reality to revolutionize the architecture, engineering, and construction industry by improving design, construction, and operations.

Vision-based action recognition of earthmoving equipment using spatio-temporal features and support vector machine classifiers; This paper presents a new computer vision algorithm for recognizing single actions of earthmoving equipment from site video streams using spatio-temporal features and support vector machine classifiers. The method addresses challenges such as partial occlusion and variations in equipment scale and pose to improve the efficiency of construction performance analysis.

Trend analysis on adoption of virtual and augmented reality in the architecture, engineering, and construction industry; This paper analyzes trends in the adoption of virtual and augmented reality in the AEC industry through surveys of industry experts conducted a year apart. The findings demonstrate significant growth in AR/VR utilization from 2017 to 2018 and show that older generations are more confident about the future of these technologies.

Towards user centered building design: Identifying end-user lighting preferences via immersive virtual environments; This paper presents a systematic approach to collect end-user lighting preferences using immersive virtual environments (IVEs) and integrate this data with building performance simulation (BPS) tools. The study demonstrates how user preference data can be used to evaluate design alternatives with the objective of meeting user needs while reducing energy consumption.

What drives our behaviors in buildings? A review on occupant interactions with building systems from the lens of behavioral theories; This paper provides a structured literature review of how behavioral theories from various disciplines can explain occupant interactions with building systems. The review aims to provide an in-depth understanding of the drivers behind occupant behavior to inform the development of innovative approaches for reducing building energy consumption without impacting comfort.

Adoption of virtual and augmented reality in the architecture, engineering, construction, and facilities management (AEC-FM): mixed method analysis of trends, gaps, and solutions; This study investigates the adoption trends, challenges, and potential of Augmented and Virtual Reality (AR/VR) in the AEC-FM industry using surveys and interviews with over 200 experts. The findings reveal a shift from initial optimism to more tempered expectations, with recent growth in the industrial sector and a trend towards outsourcing AR/VR tasks.

Wcdt: World-centric diffusion transformer for traffic scene generation; This paper introduces the World-centric Diffusion Transformer (WcDT), a novel framework for autonomous driving trajectory generation that combines diffusion models and transformers. The approach preprocesses historical data into an "Agent Move Statement," encodes it into a latent space using DDPM, and then fuses it with map and traffic information using transformer-based encoders to generate realistic trajectories.

Real-Time Roadway Obstacle Detection for Electric Scooters Using Deep Learning and Multi-Sensor Fusion; This study introduces a novel real-time ground obstacle detection system for e-scooters that integrates an RGB camera, a depth camera, and an IMU to enhance road hazard detection. A deep learning model powered by YOLO detects six categories of obstacles, and depth data is used to estimate proximity, achieving a high mean average precision of 0.827 in naturalistic riding conditions.

Tifl: A tier-based federated learning system; This paper proposes TiFL, a Tier-based Federated Learning System that addresses client heterogeneity by dividing clients into tiers based on their training performance. TiFL selects clients from the same tier in each training round to mitigate the straggler problem and employs an adaptive model synchronization strategy to handle non-IID data.

FedAT: A High-Performance and Communication-Efficient Federated Learning System with Asynchronous Tiers; This paper presents FedAT, a high-performance and communication-efficient federated learning system that uses asynchronous tiers to address both the straggler problem and the communication bottleneck. FedAT groups clients into tiers and performs intra-tier synchronous and inter-tier asynchronous model updates, achieving faster convergence and higher accuracy than existing synchronous or asynchronous methods.

FaaSNet: Scalable and Fast Provisioning of Custom Serverless Container Runtimes at Alibaba Cloud Function Compute; This paper presents FaaSNet, a system designed for scalable and fast provisioning of custom serverless container runtimes at Alibaba Cloud Function Compute. FaaSNet addresses the challenges of costly container provisioning and highly dynamic FaaS workloads to enable better control over OSes, versioning, and tooling.

Wukong: A scalable and locality-enhanced framework for serverless parallel computing; This paper describes Wukong, a scalable and locality-enhanced framework for serverless parallel computing that executes complex, burst-parallel DAG jobs. Wukong uses decentralized scheduling across Lambda executors to enhance data locality, reduce network I/O, and improve cost-effectiveness, achieving near-ideal scalability and significantly faster execution times.

Beyond efficiency: A systematic survey of resource-efficient large language models; This survey systematically reviews a broad spectrum of techniques designed to enhance the resource efficiency of Large Language Models (LLMs), addressing challenges in computational, memory, energy, and financial consumption. It categorizes methods by their optimization focus and applicability across the LLM lifecycle, and presents standardized evaluation metrics to facilitate fair comparisons.

Efficient and Workload-Aware LLM Serving via Runtime Layer Swapping and KV Cache Resizing; This paper presents MorphServe, a dynamic, workload-aware LLM serving framework that uses morphological adaptation to handle fluctuating workloads without compromising accuracy. MorphServe introduces two runtime mechanisms—quantized layer swapping and pressure-aware KV cache resizing—which significantly reduce SLO violations and improve latency compared to static approaches.

ZenFlow: Enabling Stall-Free Offloading Training via Asynchronous Updates; This paper presents ZenFlow, a new offloading framework for fine-tuning large language models that avoids GPU stalls by prioritizing important parameters and decoupling updates between the GPU and CPU. ZenFlow performs in-place updates of important gradients on the GPU while asynchronously offloading less important ones to the CPU, achieving up to a 5x end-to-end speedup.

Towards Efficient LLM Storage Reduction via Tensor Deduplication and Delta Compression; This paper presents zLLM, a model storage reduction pipeline that unifies tensor-level deduplication and a novel lossless delta compression algorithm called BitX to address the massive storage consumption of fine-tuned LLMs. By synergizing deduplication and compression around LLM family clustering, zLLM reduces model storage by 49.5%, over 20% more than state-of-the-art designs.

Centralization in the Decentralized Web: Challenges and Opportunities in IPFS Data Management; This paper analyzes over three years of IPFS internal traffic to provide an accurate view of its evolving centralization, revealing a low data replication level and high content concentration in a few hosting providers. The study highlights the challenges of this centralization for data availability and the opportunities for better data management and cost savings through deduplication.

NotebookOS: A Replicated Notebook Platform for Interactive Training with On-Demand GPUs; This paper introduces NotebookOS, a GPU-efficient notebook platform tailored for interactive deep learning training (IDLT) that uses replicated, Raft-synchronized notebook kernels distributed across GPU servers. By oversubscribing resources and allocating GPUs only during active cell execution, NotebookOS enables interactive training with minimal delay while saving significant GPU hours.

Prioritization of regression tests using singular value decomposition with empirical change records; This paper proposes a methodology for prioritizing regression test cases by analyzing empirical software change records using singular value decomposition. The technique generates clusters of files that historically change together, which are then combined with test case information to create a prioritized list of tests for a new system modification.

Empirical software change impact analysis using singular value decomposition; This paper proposes a methodology for analyzing the impact of a new system modification by using singular value decomposition on historical software change records. The technique, which generates clusters of files that tend to change together, was shown to be effective in identifying impacted files in a post hoc case study of five open-source systems.

A service learning practicum capstone; This paper presents the design and execution of a year-long Service Learning Practicum (SLP) capstone course for computer science seniors. In the course, student teams develop software for local nonprofit organizations, and the paper describes the course structure, challenges, and student perceptions.

A (updated) review of empiricism at the sigcse technical symposium; This paper examines the state of empiricism in recent proceedings of the SIGCSE Technical Symposium to categorize the research and identify areas for increased rigor. The study found an increase in empirical work compared to prior investigations, but many papers still lack the detail needed for replication.
