Addressing Challenges in Teaching-Track Faculty Promotion; This panel discussion addresses the challenges of evaluating teaching-track faculty for promotion, as departments and universities often struggle to apply appropriate standards. The panelists, including both teaching-track and tenured faculty, will share experiences and discuss how to best evaluate these positions without resorting to watered-down tenure-track standards.

Teaching track faculty in computer science; This birds-of-a-feather session is designed for teaching-track faculty in computer science to share their experiences, especially regarding challenges and lessons learned from pandemic teaching. It also provides an opportunity for schools considering such positions to gather information and for participants to celebrate their successes.

Engineering a complete curriculum overhaul; This paper presents an eight-year curriculum redesign effort in a computer science department that impacted almost every course. The systematic process involved collecting requirements from stakeholders, developing a compromise plan for seven new courses, and iterating on piloted courses based on feedback.

Training computing educators to become computing education researchers; This paper reports on six years of experience running a year-long professional development and mentoring program for computing educators to train them in empirical research methods. The goal is to help instructors transition their educational innovations from anecdotal experience reports to empirical results that can be replicated by others.

A systematic literature review of empiricism and norms of reporting in computing education research literature; This systematic literature review characterizes the reporting of empiricism in Computing Education Research (CER) literature to determine if published work contains the necessary content for replication, meta-analysis, and theory building. The study analyzes 1,351 papers from four top CER venues to assess the state of reporting norms in the community.

Nanomaterial-based electrochemical sensing of neurological drugs and neurotransmitters; This article reviews electrochemical methods for detecting neurological drugs and neurotransmitters, with a focus on how nanomaterial-modified detection systems enhance sensitivity, selectivity, and versatility. It discusses how specific nano-sized modifiers influence electron transfer events and surveys electrodes based on carbon materials, metal nanoparticles, and conductive polymers.

Real-time electrochemical monitoring of adenosine triphosphate in the picomolar to micromolar range using graphene-modified electrodes; This paper reports a competitive, wash-free electrochemical detection system for real-time monitoring of adenosine triphosphate (ATP) over a five-log concentration range. The system uses an aptamer-based recognition surface and a graphene-gold nanoparticle-modified signaling electrode to achieve a low detection limit in the picomolar range.

Photoelectrochemical Stability of Electrodeposited Cu2O Films; This paper reports on the photoelectrochemical stability of p-type cuprous oxide (Cu2O) films electrodeposited from an alkaline lactate solution onto Au substrates. The study found that while the initial photocurrent decayed, the film morphology changed from a dense structure to a more stable network of elongated crystals, attributed to the higher stability of {111} facets.

Electrokinetic preconcentration and detection of neuropeptides at patterned graphene-modified electrodes in a nanochannel; This work demonstrates the electrochemical detection of neuropeptides NPY and OXA at picomolar levels from subnanoliter samples by using electrokinetic preconcentration onto patterned graphene-modified electrodes in a nanochannel. The high sensitivity of the method, which avoids interferences from dopamine and ascorbic acid, makes it suitable for analyzing noninvasively collected biological samples like sweat.

Single-cell microfluidic impedance cytometry: From raw signals to cell phenotypes using data analytics; This tutorial review presents a comparative survey of approaches for elucidating cellular and subcellular features from microfluidic impedance cytometry data. It covers device design, data analytics (including signal processing and dielectric modeling), and population clustering to enable multiparametric cell characterization and subpopulation distinction.

Detecting apoptotic bodies by impedance cytometry as an indicator of drug sensitivity; This work describes a microfluidic system that uses impedance cytometry to quantify apoptotic bodies (ABs) with single-cell sensitivity, providing real-time information on cellular disassembly. By measuring electrical impedance magnitude and phase parameters, the system can distinguish subpopulations of ABs to assess the drug sensitivity of cancer cells.

Multiparametric single-cell biophysical cytometry under tunable viscoelastic extensional flows for classification of T-cell lymphomas on their nuclear phenotypes; This study utilizes single-cell biophysical cytometry under tunable viscoelastic extensional flows to correlate the nuclear phenotypes of T-cell lymphoma cells with their deformability characteristics. By coupling impedance, deformability, and recovery dynamics, the research provides insights into how nuclear size, shape, and protein expression affect cell mechanics and migration potential.

Controlled Nanoconfinement in a Microfluidic Modular Bead Array Device via Elastomeric Diaphragm Collapse for Enhancing Biomolecular Binding Kinetics (Small 34/2025); This article describes a modular microfluidic platform for controlled nanoconfinement over a large area, using an elastomeric diaphragm with integrated strain sensors and microfabricated posts. The device enhances biomolecular binding by alternating between confinement and bulk transport, demonstrating rapid DNA immobilization and screening of aptamers.

Modified cells as multimodal standards for cytometry and separation; This work describes a method for inline classification of biological specimens, such as mammalian cells, using impedance cytometry. A model specimen class is used to determine an impedance parameter value indicative of a specified biophysical characteristic, which can then be used for classification.

On-Chip Integration of Impedance Cytometry for Inline Optimization of Dielectrophoretic Separations on Multiple Cellular Biophysical Metrics; This paper demonstrates the on-chip integration of impedance cytometry for the inline optimization of dielectrophoretic cell separations based on multiple biophysical metrics. The integrated system overcomes the limitations of traditional endpoint assays by providing label-free, real-time quantification of separated cell fractions, enabling their use in downstream studies.

Teaching societal and ethical implications of nanotechnology to engineering students through science fiction; This article suggests using selected science fiction stories in the engineering ethics classroom to teach students about the societal and ethical implications of nanotechnology. This approach provides students with the ethical skills and cultural knowledge needed to engage in public debates and make responsible decisions about futuristic technologies.

Nanotalk: Conversations with scientists and engineers about ethics, meaning, and belief in the development of nanotechnology; This book, "Nanotalk," presents a series of conversations and explorations with thirty-five nano-research scientists and engineers. In these discussions, the researchers share their ideas about the ethics, meaning, and beliefs surrounding the development of nanotechnology.

Towards the conscientious development of ethical nanotechnology; This article discusses the ethical challenges and social changes associated with nanotechnology, an emerging capability that has captured the attention of government, scientists, and the public. It argues for the conscientious development of this technology, which holds the potential for dramatic and unpredictable impacts on human existence.

Science fiction in computer science education; This panel discussion explores the use of science fiction (SF) to engage students in computer science education, making connections between technical content and human experience. Panelists from a range of schools will present overviews of how they have used SF to engage students in technical topics as well as ethical and societal issues.

Ethics, technology, and the future: an intergenerational experience in engineering education; This article explores the use of intergenerational dialogue between undergraduate engineering students and senior citizens as a learning tool in a required engineering ethics course. The dialogue helps students appreciate and understand the practical and ethical meaning of technological change by learning from the lifetime experiences of seniors.

Animals, Ethics, and Engineering: Intersections and Implications; The book "Animals, Ethics, and Engineering: Intersections and Implications" is a seminal work exploring the intricate relationship between technology, ethics, and the welfare of nonhuman animals. Edited by Rosalyn W. Berne, the volume brings together leading scholars and practitioners to examine the ethical responsibilities inherent in technological progress and its impact on animal well-being.

Non-human Animals and a New Ethics for Engineering; This paper argues that engineering education has a critical role in addressing the sixth mass extinction by preparing engineers with a new ethical framework that dismantles the distinction between nature and technology. It submits that this new ethics must first challenge the rationalist worldview that separates humans from other animals and treats them as technologies for human use.

Race and ethics in the design of biomedical technologies: the pulse oximeter as a case in point (The Daniel W. Foster, MD, Visiting Lectureship in Medical Ethics); This lecture uses the pulse oximeter as a case study to discuss how race can become a matter of ethics in the design of biomedical devices. It highlights that despite early studies showing the device overestimates oxygen saturation in dark-skinned individuals, it remains unaltered, a disregard with significant implications during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Race Matters in Engineering and Technology; This webinar, part of the ASEM DE/I series, features a talk by Professor Rosalyn W. Berne titled "Race Matters in Engineering and Technology." The discussion covers the role of values in technology development and how those values can be used to create more ethically designed technology.

A practical guide to hydrogels for cell culture; This guide introduces hydrogels to researchers who may be unfamiliar with them, providing procedures for culturing and studying cells within these systems. With a focus on commercially available hydrogels, it aims to lower the knowledge barrier for scientists interested in using these materials to better recapitulate native cellular environments.

N-cadherin adhesive interactions modulate matrix mechanosensing and fate commitment of mesenchymal stem cells; This study uses a hyaluronic acid hydrogel system to show that N-cadherin adhesive interactions modulate mesenchymal stem cell (MSC) mechanosensing and fate commitment. Decoupled presentation of N-cadherin and RGD motifs revealed that N-cadherin ligation reduces the cellular contractile state and nuclear YAP/TAZ localization, altering the interpretation of ECM stiffness.

Dimensionality and spreading influence MSC YAP/TAZ signaling in hydrogel environments; This study investigates how culture dimensionality and microenvironmental factors like stiffness and degradability regulate the mechanosensitive signaling mediators YAP/TAZ in mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs). Using tunable hyaluronic acid hydrogels, the research found that MSCs showed increased YAP/TAZ nuclear localization on stiffer 2D hydrogels but the opposite trend when encapsulated in 3D.

Matching material and cellular timescales maximizes cell spreading on viscoelastic substrates; This study uses analytical methods and Monte Carlo simulations to examine the dynamics of motor clutches between a cell and a viscoelastic substrate. The model predicts that for soft substrates, maximum cell spreading is achieved at an optimal viscosity where the substrate relaxation time is between the clutch binding timescale and its binding lifetime.

The effect of anisotropic collagen-GAG scaffolds and growth factor supplementation on tendon cell recruitment, alignment, and metabolic activity; This study describes the development of an anisotropic collagen-glycosaminoglycan (CG) scaffold with aligned ellipsoidal pores to mimic native tendon physiology for tissue engineering. The results show that equine tendon cells cultured in these scaffolds exhibited greater attachment, metabolic activity, and alignment compared to those in isotropic scaffolds.

Substrate stiffness and viscoelasticity influence fibroblast senescence; This study investigates the influence of hydrogel stiffness and viscoelasticity on fibroblast senescence, both independently and in combination with genotoxic stress. The results reveal a unique role for soft viscoelastic substrates in promoting the onset and amplification of senescence, even without genotoxic stress, suggesting a role for nuclear organization in this phenotype.

Norbornene homopolymerization limits cell spreading in thiol–ene photoclick hydrogels; This study investigates unintended norbornene homopolymerization in thiol-norbornene photoclick hydrogels, which can limit 3D cell spreading. The results show that norbornene conversion exceeds 1:1 thiol-ene expectations, and reducing the number of norbornenes per hyaluronic acid chain mitigates this homopolymerization, leading to hydrogels with greater stress relaxation.

M2 macrophage co-culture overrides viscoelastic hydrogel mechanics to promote IL-6-dependent fibroblast activation; This study uses tunable hyaluronic acid hydrogels to investigate how tissue mechanics and macrophage signaling combine to influence fibroblast activation, a driver of fibrotic disease. While fibroblast activation increased on stiff hydrogels, co-culture with M2 macrophages overrode these mechanical cues and increased activation even on soft hydrogels, an effect dependent on IL-6 signaling.

Freeze-dried porous collagen scaffolds for the repair of volumetric muscle loss injuries; This study assessed the ability of aligned collagen-glycosaminoglycan (CG) scaffolds to facilitate functional muscle recovery in a rat model of volumetric muscle loss (VML). After 12 weeks, muscles treated with either nonconductive or conductive scaffolds produced significantly greater maximum isometric torque than nontreated tissues, supporting the platform's potential for VML repair.

Heparin-modified aligned collagen scaffolds enhance in vitro myogenesis; This study develops aligned collagen-glycosaminoglycan (CG) scaffolds and systematically varies the GAG content by incorporating hyaluronic acid, chondroitin sulfate, or heparin to regulate myogenesis. Results show that heparin-modified collagen scaffolds significantly enhance myoblast metabolic activity, myogenic differentiation, and sequestration of insulin-like growth factor-1, highlighting their promise for skeletal muscle tissue engineering.

Perspectives on thermoelectrics: from fundamentals to device applications.; This review provides an update on the field of thermoelectrics, focusing on progress in understanding charge and heat carrier transport, strategies to improve the thermoelectric figure of merit, and new discussions on device physics. It assesses recent advances and remaining challenges, highlighting the significant role of first-principles calculations and the development of new experimental tools.

Enhancement of thermoelectric properties by modulation-doping in silicon germanium alloy nanocomposites; This paper reports the enhancement of the thermoelectric figure-of-merit (ZT) in silicon germanium alloy nanocomposites by using an alternative modulation-doping design. By using alloy Si70Ge30 as the nanoparticles and Si95Ge5 as the matrix, the design increases the power factor without increasing thermal conductivity, leading to a ZT of 1.3 at 900 °C.

Power factor enhancement by modulation doping in bulk nanocomposites; This paper introduces and experimentally demonstrates the concept of modulation doping in three-dimensional nanostructured bulk materials to increase the thermoelectric power factor. By creating a two-phase composite of doped silicon nanograins and intrinsic silicon germanium grains, charge carriers are separated from their parent grains, resulting in enhanced mobility and higher electrical conductivity.

Thermoelectric power factor: Enhancement mechanisms and strategies for higher performance thermoelectric materials; This review focuses on the thermoelectric power factor, a key parameter for determining the performance of thermoelectric materials. It discusses the fundamental mechanisms and various strategies that have been developed to enhance the power factor for achieving higher performance.

High-performance thermoelectric nanocomposites from nanocrystal building blocks; This paper presents a versatile bottom-up strategy to produce high-performance thermoelectric nanocomposites by assembling colloidal nanocrystals. In a PbS-Ag system, Ag nanodomains are shown to block phonon propagation and also provide electrons to the PbS host, resulting in reduced thermal conductivity and enhanced charge transport.

Innovation in thermoelectric materials: From fundamental physics to practical applications; This issue of MRS Bulletin highlights key innovations in thermoelectricity, driven by a deeper understanding of physics, inventive material design, and progress in computational and experimental techniques. It covers topics from spin caloritronics to waste heat recovery, emphasizing the need for efficient, stable, and sustainable materials for a futuristic economy.

Enhanced Thomson and Unusual Nernst Coefficients in 1T‐TiSe2 Due to Bipolar Transport and CDW Phase Transition; This paper presents a comprehensive investigation of the thermoelectric properties of 1T-TiSe2, focusing on the Thomson and Nernst effects around its charge density wave transition. The study reveals an exceptional peak in the Thomson coefficient and an unusual Nernst coefficient, highlighting the material's potential for developing practical Thomson coolers with extended operational ranges.

Spin-lattice entanglement in; This study uses Raman scattering, infrared absorption, and X-ray techniques to investigate the complex chalcogenide CoPS3, which lies at the nexus of different structural and magnetic behaviors in its material family. The findings reveal a structural component to its magnetic ordering transition and a remarkable set of lower-temperature magnon-phonon pairs, pointing to strong spin-phonon entanglement.

High thermoelectric power factor in Ni-Fe alloy for active cooling applications; This work identifies Ni-Fe as a promising metallic alloy for active cooling applications by using machine learning to screen a database of binary alloys for large Seebeck coefficients. Fabricated Ni-Fe ingots demonstrated high thermoelectric power factor values, making them attractive candidates composed of cost-effective and abundant elements.

Sign Reversal of Hall Conductivity in Polycrystalline FeRh Films via the Topological Hall Effect in the Antiferromagnetic Phase; This study investigates the temperature-dependent transport properties of FeRh thin films, observing a nonzero anomalous Hall effect (AHE) signal in the antiferromagnetic (AFM) phase that reverses its sign upon transitioning to the ferromagnetic phase. This observation, which contrasts with theoretical predictions, is attributed to an additional Hall conductivity contribution from the topological Hall effect.

Saint Venant’s torsion of homogeneous and composite bars by the finite volume method; This paper proposes a new finite-volume based approach for solving Saint Venant’s torsion problems for homogeneous and composite prismatic bars. The method uses a semi-inverse approach to construct an approximate displacement field within discretized subvolumes, enabling the analysis of bars with heterogeneous microstructures and orthotropic materials.

Parametric finite-volume method for Saint Venant’s torsion of arbitrarily shaped cross sections; This paper extends a finite-volume method for Saint Venant’s torsion problems to enable the analysis of arbitrarily shaped cross sections with curved boundaries. This is achieved by incorporating parametric mapping based on transfinite grid generation, which allows the cross section to be discretized by quadrilateral subvolumes.

Response of Complex Microstructure Composites via an Integrated API Based on Finite-Volume Homogenization; This work presents an integrated Application Programming Interface (API) based on finite-volume homogenization to analyze the mechanical response of composites with complex microstructures. The tool aims to provide an efficient method for predicting the effective properties of heterogeneous materials.

An Integrated Homogenization Engine Based on Microgravity Driven Microstructure Generation for Random Unidirectional Composites; This paper presents an integrated homogenization engine that uses microgravity-driven microstructure generation to predict the properties of random unidirectional composites. The tool combines microstructure modeling with a homogenization technique to analyze the effective mechanical behavior of these materials.

DNA purification using dynamic solid-phase extraction on a rotationally-driven polyethylene-terephthalate microdevice; This paper reports the development of a disposable, polyester-toner centrifugal microdevice for the semi-automated, dynamic solid-phase extraction (dSPE) of DNA from whole blood samples. The low-cost device integrates novel valving to allow sequential reagent addition, achieving a DNA extraction efficiency of ~45% and enabling successful multiplexed PCR amplification.

Designing a spatially aware and autonomous quadcopter; This paper describes the design and implementation of an autonomous quadcopter that uses commercial off-the-shelf technologies to independently explore and map an unknown area. The system integrates an Android smartphone, an Arduino microcontroller, and ultrasonic sensors to achieve autonomous navigation and mapping for intelligence, surveillance, and reconnaissance (ISR) applications.

Thin-film aerogel thermal conductivity measurements via 3ω; This study thermally characterized thin-film silica aerogel films using the 3ω technique to determine their thermal conductivity. The results indicate that thin-film aerogel, deposited on SiO2 substrates, can maintain the ultra-low thermal conductivity commonly observed in bulk aerogel, making it a promising thermal insulator for microelectronic systems.

Hematocrit analysis through the use of an inexpensive centrifugal polyester-toner device with finger-to-chip blood loading capability; This paper presents the HCT Disc, an inexpensive centrifugal microdevice fabricated from polyester and toner, for measuring hematocrit from a single drop of blood. The device uses centrifugal force for blood metering and cell sedimentation, with analysis performed using a cell phone, showing good correlation with clinical laboratory values.

Rapid detection of Clostridium difficile via magnetic bead aggregation in cost-effective polyester microdevices with cell phone image analysis; This study presents a rapid, low-cost method for detecting Clostridium difficile using a magnetic bead aggregation assay within an inexpensive polyester microfluidic device. The system uses centrifugal force for fluid control and a rotating magnetic field to manipulate beads, with detection and analysis performed in under an hour using a cell phone.

Optimized Biomanufacturing for Treatment of Volumetric Muscle Loss Enables Physiomimetic Recovery; This work details the implementation of a fully enclosed bioreactor environment (FEBE) system that interfaces with automated bioprinting methods for manufacturing tissue-engineered muscle repair (TEMR) constructs. Implantation of these constructs, which consist of a porcine bladder matrix seeded with muscle progenitor cells, resulted in significant functional recovery in a rat model of volumetric muscle loss.

Hermetically or aseptically sealed bioreactor system and related method thereof; This disclosure relates to a bioreactor system that can be hermetically or aseptically sealed to protect against external contaminants during the artificial manufacturing of cells and tissues. The system uses cyclic motion to stimulate cell growth and maturation within the enclosed environment.

Bioreactor controller device and related method thereof; This invention provides an inexpensive, microcontroller-based bioreactor controller with a linear motor and a simple user interface. The controller offers greater temporal accuracy and allows a user to select and run protocol and setup modes for stimulating cell growth.

Development And Evaluation Of A Fully Enclosed Bioreactor Environment (FEBE) For Automated Biofabrication Of Implantable Tissue Engineered Muscle Repair Constructs; This work describes the development and evaluation of a Fully Enclosed Bioreactor Environment (FEBE) for the automated biofabrication of implantable Tissue Engineered Muscle Repair constructs. The system aims to improve the manufacturing process for these therapeutic tissues.

System for monitoring and maintaining separation; This invention describes a system for monitoring and maintaining separation between individuals or objects. The system is designed to help enforce social distancing or other spatial requirements.

Data-driven phenotypic dissection of AML reveals progenitor-like cells that correlate with prognosis; This study developed a data-driven approach using mass cytometry and a new algorithm, PhenoGraph, to define phenotypes in high-dimensional single-cell data from acute myeloid leukemia (AML) patients. This method revealed that leukemic blast surface phenotypes do not always reflect their intracellular state and identified a progenitor-like cell population that correlates with prognosis.

A pharmacological map of the PI3-K family defines a role for p110α in insulin signaling; This paper describes a pharmacological approach to interrogate the PI3-K family by synthesizing and profiling a diverse panel of inhibitors, revealing cryptic homologies and a uniquely exploited mobile region in p110γ. Using this chemical array, the study defines p110α as the primary insulin-responsive PI3-K in cultured cells and in vivo.

Multiplexed mass cytometry profiling of cellular states perturbed by small-molecule regulators; This paper describes mass-tag cellular barcoding (MCB), a method that uses n metal ion tags to multiplex up to 2n samples for high-throughput mass cytometry analysis. The authors applied this technique to characterize human PBMC signaling dynamics, inhibitor effects, and donor-to-donor variability in a single multiplexed experiment.

Palladium-based mass tag cell barcoding with a doublet-filtering scheme and single-cell deconvolution algorithm; This paper presents an optimized mass-tag cell barcoding (MCB) protocol that uses palladium-based labeling reagents to expand the number of available measurement channels in mass cytometry. The method includes an error-detecting barcoding scheme to identify and remove cell doublets and a single-cell-based deconvolution algorithm to improve accuracy.

Highly multiplexed simultaneous detection of RNAs and proteins in single cells; This paper introduces PLAYR (proximity ligation assay for RNA), a method for highly multiplexed quantification of transcripts by flow and mass cytometry that is compatible with standard antibody staining. When used with mass cytometry, PLAYR allowed for the simultaneous quantification of more than 40 different mRNAs and proteins in single primary cells.

Atypical CD11c+ B-cells Expand In Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis And Are Associated With IgA Antibodies Against Oxidized Cholesterol; This study performed deep phenotyping of circulating B-cells in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and healthy controls using mass cytometry. The research identified an expansion of atypical CD11c+ B-cells in IPF, which was associated with elevated levels of IgA antibodies against oxidized cholesterol.

Characterizing Microglial Signaling Dynamics During Inflammation Using Single‐Cell Mass Cytometry; This study utilized time-resolved single-cell mass cytometry (CyTOF) to measure distinct signaling pathways activated in microglia upon exposure to bacterial and viral mimetics. The research also evaluated the immunomodulatory role of astrocytes on microglial signaling in mixed cultures to better understand neuroinflammatory responses.

Extrinsic Apoptosis and Necroptosis in Telencephalic Development: A Single-Cell Mass Cytometry Study; This study uses single-cell mass cytometry (CyTOF) to characterize the cellular landscape of the developing mouse telencephalon in wild-type and knockout mice, revealing the roles of extrinsic apoptosis and necroptosis. The results show that combined deletion of RIPK3 and Caspase-8 leads to an increase in total cell count, challenging the notion that intrinsic apoptosis exclusively governs developmental cell elimination.

A single-cell mass cytometry-based atlas of the developing mouse brain; This study presents a single-cell mass cytometry-based atlas of the developing mouse brain, analyzing over 24 million cells with a 40-antibody panel from embryonic day 11.5 to postnatal day 4. The analysis identifies 85 molecularly distinct cell clusters, confirms canonical neurogenesis and gliogenesis pathways, and predicts two distinct trajectories for cortical oligodendrogenesis.

Condemned to connection? Network communitarianism in Mark Zuckerberg’s “Facebook Manifesto”; This article analyzes Mark Zuckerberg’s 2017 open letter, “Building Global Community,” as a political manifesto that outlines a future of ubiquitous social media and government in an era of surveillance capitalism. Using a critical framework, the article argues that the letter constitutes a coherent statement on the future of governance, evoking a social media-age version of Rousseau's "General Will."

Leveraging liminality: How San Diego taxi drivers used their precarious status to win reform; This case study explores how the ambiguous status of San Diego taxi drivers as independent contractors shaped their work conditions and opportunities for resistance. While objectively disempowered, drivers leveraged their dual identity as both workers and entrepreneurs to build alliances and successfully campaign for reform.

The privacy paradox: How market privacy facilitates government surveillance; This paper analyzes US congressional debates on encryption controls from 1993 to 1999 to investigate how privacy claims were used to legitimate government surveillance. The analysis reveals that a market liberalization discourse, which framed loosened encryption controls as a way to protect privacy in market transactions, dominated the debates.

Building ideal workplaces: Labor, affect, and identity in tech for good projects; This study, based on participant observation and interviews with civic technologists in the San Francisco Bay Area, argues that "Tech for Good" initiatives are structured by technologists' affective attachments to their careers. Participants engage in "repair work," repurposing civic technology organizations into idealized versions of their workplaces to work through feelings of disillusionment with the high-tech sector.

Volunteering the Valley: Designing technology for the common good in the San Francisco Bay Area; This study investigates how civic technology organizations, comprised of volunteers from the high-tech industry, work to design digital technologies for the common good in the San Francisco Bay Area. Drawing on participant observation and interviews, the research explores how these groups attempt to address local social problems through technology.

Centering Race in Analyses and Practices of Countersurveillance Advocacy: Mythologies of the Racialized Other in the Crypto Wars; This chapter analyzes how race has shaped the development and regulation of encryption technologies by examining US congressional hearings from 1990 to 2016, known as the “Crypto Wars.” The analysis demonstrates how state and private actors mobilized racialized mythological constructions of criminals while negotiating how to regulate encryption, highlighting the need to center race in countersurveillance advocacy.

Reliable broadcast of safety messages in vehicular ad hoc networks; This article proposes and analyzes a topology-transparent broadcast protocol for vehicular networks that reliably delivers safety messages with better performance in terms of success probability and delay compared to existing protocols.

Duplication-correcting codes for data storage in the DNA of living organisms; This paper presents two families of error-correcting codes designed to correct tandem duplication errors in data stored within the DNA of living organisms, with one family correcting any number of errors and the other correcting a bounded number.

Error-Correction in Flash Memories via Codes in the Ulam Metric; This paper introduces translocation rank codes for flash memories to handle arbitrary charge-drop errors, deriving their asymptotic capacity and providing construction techniques for asymptotically good codes with simple decoding methods.

Capacity and expressiveness of genomic tandem duplication; This paper investigates the capacity and expressiveness of generating a large number of sequences from a small initial seed using tandem duplications of bounded length, a process common in the human genome.

The Capacity of String-Duplication Systems; This paper investigates the capacity of four fundamental string-duplication systems, including those resembling genomic duplication, to determine their expressive power in constructing an exponentially large number of sequences from a short initial sequence.

Constrained coding for error mitigation in nanopore-based DNA data storage; This study designs constrained codes using de Bruijn graphs to mitigate the high error rate of nanopore-based DNA sequencing for data storage, finding that the novel codes significantly improve overall performance compared to unconstrained coding.

Asymptotically Optimal Codes Correcting One Substring Edit; This paper constructs asymptotically optimal codes that can correct one substring edit error, where a substring is replaced by another of bounded length, achieving a redundancy of 2k log n.

Linear List Decodable Edit-Correcting Codes with Rate Approaching; This paper constructs linear list decodable codes that can correct k edits with a rate approaching 1-H(2k/n) and a reasonable list size, using an encoder and decoder that run in polynomial time.

Optimal Codes Correcting a Substring Edit; This paper constructs almost optimal codes that correct one substring edit error with a redundancy of 2k log n + O(1) and also proposes a hash with an expected length of approximately 2k log n for the average-case document-exchange problem.

Correcting a substring edit error of bounded length; This paper introduces and constructs binary codes of length n that can correct a single k-substring edit error with a redundancy of O(k log n), showing that such codes are more efficient for synchronizing related documents than general indel/substitution-correcting codes.

Rethinking the design of presentation slides: A case for sentence headlines and visual evidence; This article argues for an alternative presentation slide design characterized by a succinct sentence headline supported by visual evidence, which is more effective for technical communication than the traditional bulleted list format.

Mary Somerville: science, illumination, and the female mind; This book retells the story of Mary Somerville, a leading 19th-century woman scientist, focusing on the cultural factors that enabled her to become an eminent figure and arguing for a rethinking of the history of women's participation in science.

Liberal education in twenty-first century engineering: Responses to ABET/EC 2000 Criteria; This book presents various institutional and individual responses to the ABET/EC2000 accreditation criteria, showing paths forward for faculty to integrate liberal education topics like communication, ethics, and humanities into 21st-century engineering curricula.

Woman as mediatrix: Women as writers on science and technology in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries; This article argues that women writers on science and technology in the 18th and 19th centuries, often acting as mediators or "mediatrixes," performed essential tasks that clarified scientific knowledge and were crucial for the functioning of the scientific enterprise.

Discovering the power of PowerPoint: Rethinking the design of presentation slides from a skillful user's perspective; This paper proposes an alternative presentation slide design that uses a succinct sentence headline supported by visual evidence, arguing it is more effective for communicating engineering content than the traditional phrase headline/bullet list format, despite resistance from users accustomed to PowerPoint's defaults.

Engineering Communication as an Area of Specialization and a Fundamentally Interdisciplinary Domain: What We Can Learn from Fred Newton Scott; This paper draws on the scholarship of Fred Newton Scott to articulate a humanistic and functional view of engineering communication, arguing that it should be seen as an interdisciplinary area of specialization grounded in fundamental notions of human interaction.

Expanding the Audience for the Discourse on Diversity by Recognizing the Framing Power of Implicit Messages; This paper explores how the language used to discuss diversity, equity, inclusion, and social justice can inadvertently deter audiences outside the diversity community, and argues for using a conversational rhetorical mode and thematic framing to expand the audience.

Knowledge Integration as the Foundation of Ethical Action: or, Why You Need All Three Legs of a Three-Legged Stool; This paper describes a systems approach to engineering ethics that integrates sociotechnical systems thinking, communication ability, and traditional ethics to situate ethical action within the organizational, cultural, and technical contexts of engineering practice.

The Person behind the Mann Report: Charles Riborg Mann as an Influential but Elusive Figure in Engineering Education; This paper examines the life and work of Charles Riborg Mann, author of the influential 1918 report on engineering education, highlighting his integrative, systems-based approach and noting that many of his observations and recommendations remain relevant today.

Remote epitaxy through graphene enables two-dimensional material-based layer transfer; This study demonstrates that the weak van der Waals potential of graphene does not completely screen the stronger potential field of an underlying substrate, enabling a phenomenon termed "remote epitaxy" that allows for epitaxial growth and facile layer release.

Dynamic kirigami structures for integrated solar tracking; This paper demonstrates a novel solar cell design using kirigami to create an array of tilted surface elements from thin-film gallium arsenide, enabling integrated solar tracking with high mechanical robustness and optical efficiency comparable to conventional trackers.

Controlled crack propagation for atomic precision handling of wafer-scale two-dimensional materials; This paper demonstrates a layer-resolved 2D material splitting technique that enables high-throughput production of multiple wafer-scale monolayers by splitting a single stack of thick 2D materials grown on one wafer.

Heterogeneous integration of single-crystalline complex-oxide membranes; This paper demonstrates a universal mechanical exfoliation method for producing freestanding, single-crystalline membranes from a wide range of complex-oxide materials, enabling their heterogeneous integration with semiconductor technologies and overcoming the limitations of substrate clamping.

Non-destructive wafer recycling for epitaxial lift-off thin-film device using a superlattice epitaxial layer; This disclosure presents methods and growth structures for epitaxial lift-off of thin-film devices that use at least one superlattice layer as a wafer protection scheme to preserve wafer surface integrity and increase the number of times it can be reused for regrowth.

Simultaneous Determination of Transition Dipole Moment Orientation and Refractive Index in Morphologically Non‐Uniform Nanoscale Films; This paper presents a high-precision, single-shot technique using Fourier imaging microscopy to simultaneously quantify the refractive index and transition dipole moment orientation in morphologically non-uniform nanoscale emissive films.

Microdisplay technologies in augmented reality and virtual reality headsets; This Perspective explores the key requirements for microdisplays in augmented and virtual reality headsets, considers the advantages of different light-engine technologies like LCoS, OLEDoS, and LEDoS, and discusses how their performance can be accurately characterized.

Fabrication of piezoelectric polymer and metal–organic framework composite thin films using solution shearing; This study utilizes solution shearing to fabricate composite thin films of the metal-organic framework UiO-66 and the piezoelectric polymer P(VDF-TrFE), investigating how polymer concentration influences the film's crystallinity, surface coverage, and piezoelectric performance.

EAS-CiM 2.0: Event-driven Asynchronous Stream-based Compute-in-Memory Kernels with Scalable Precision; This paper presents EAS-CiM 2.0, an event-driven, asynchronous, stream-based Compute-in-Memory architecture that leverages Asynchronous Stream Computing to dynamically adapt computational precision and speed in response to workload demands and available energy resources.

Artificial Intelligence in Advanced Manufacturing: Current Status and Future Outlook; This paper reviews the state-of-the-art applications of Artificial Intelligence in manufacturing, provides a systematic view for analyzing data and process dependencies, and identifies challenges and opportunities for leveraging AI to transform the manufacturing domain.

Data driven bottleneck detection of manufacturing systems; This research proposes a new data-driven method for detecting throughput bottlenecks in both the short and long term by utilizing production line blockage and starvation probabilities and buffer content records, without needing an analytical model.

Recurrent neural network for motion trajectory prediction in human-robot collaborative assembly; This paper presents a deep learning method based on a recurrent neural network to parse visual observations of human actions and forecast the operator's future motion trajectory for online robot action planning in a human-robot collaborative assembly setting.

Deep reinforcement learning based preventive maintenance policy for serial production lines; This paper proposes a deep reinforcement learning-based approach to obtain an optimal preventive maintenance policy for serial production lines to improve cost efficiency. The algorithm, based on the Double Deep Q-Network, is proven effective in delivering a policy that increases throughput and reduces cost through simulation studies.

Data driven production modeling and simulation of complex automobile general assembly plant; This paper develops a data-driven simulation methodology to automatically model a complex automobile general assembly plant and rapidly modify the model to respond to dynamic requirements and real-time information, enabling quick analysis and remodeling in response to demand fluctuations.

Generative AI-powered planning: A hybrid graph-diffusion approach for demand-driven flexible manufacturing systems; This paper presents a novel Hybrid Graph-Diffusion Based Planning Framework that integrates generative AI with system-theoretic modeling to autonomously generate optimal Flexible Smart Manufacturing System configurations based on different market demands.

Advances in Modeling, Analysis, and Control of Manufacturing Systems: Methods, Gaps, and Research Frontiers; This review paper provides a comprehensive synthesis of system-level modeling, analysis, and control methodologies in manufacturing, covering classical, simulation-based, and cutting-edge AI/ML approaches to guide future research toward improving modern manufacturing environments.

Demand-driven hierarchical integrated planning-scheduling control for a mobile robot-operated flexible smart manufacturing system; This paper presents a demand-driven hierarchical framework that integrates planning and scheduling for a mobile, multi-skilled, robot-operated Flexible Smart Manufacturing System to address the challenges of adapting to frequent demand fluctuations and managing system complexity.

Can pre-trained LLMs be used as out-of-the-box bottleneck detectors? An explorative study; This study explores whether pre-trained Large Language Models, specifically GPT-4, can function as out-of-the-box bottleneck detectors in manufacturing without domain-specific fine-tuning by evaluating three prompting techniques with increasing levels of domain knowledge.

Train small, deploy large: Scaling multi-agent reinforcement learning for multi-stage manufacturing lines; This paper presents a scalable Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning control framework for multi-stage manufacturing lines that enables training a small, characteristic 3-workstation model which can then generalize to production lines of any size.

A Neural Network Approach to Context-Sensitive Generation of Conversational Responses; This paper presents a novel response generation system using a neural network architecture trained end-to-end on unstructured Twitter conversations, which shows consistent gains over machine translation and information retrieval baselines by effectively incorporating contextual dialogue history.

Dynet: The dynamic neural network toolkit; This paper describes DyNet, an open-source toolkit for implementing neural network models that uses dynamic declaration of network structure, allowing for efficient and flexible implementation of complex architectures with speeds comparable to or faster than static declaration toolkits.

Creative writing with a machine in the loop: Case studies on slogans and stories; This paper presents two case studies on machine-in-the-loop creative writing for slogans and stories, finding that while participants found the process fun and helpful, the machine-suggested content did not necessarily lead to better written artifacts.

Representation Learning for Text-level Discourse Parsing; This paper presents a representation learning approach for text-level discourse parsing that jointly learns to parse discourse and a discourse-driven projection of surface features, resulting in a shift-reduce parser that achieves substantial improvements on the RST Treebank.

Better Document-level Sentiment Analysis from RST Discourse Parsing; This paper shows that discourse analyses from Rhetorical Structure Theory (RST) parsers can improve document-level sentiment analysis by reweighting discourse units in a dependency representation or by using a recursive neural network over the RST structure.

Syntactic Blind Spots: How Misalignment Leads to LLMs Mathematical Errors; This paper identifies "syntactic blind spots" in Large Language Models, a systematic failure mode where models misapply familiar reasoning to semantically straightforward but syntactically unfamiliar mathematical problems, and shows that rephrasing these problems often leads to correct answers.

Optimizing Latent Dimension Allocation in Hierarchical VAEs: Balancing Attenuation and Information Retention for OOD Detection; This work introduces a theoretically grounded framework for optimizing latent dimension allocation in hierarchical variational autoencoders (HVAEs) for out-of-distribution detection, demonstrating that tuning the allocation ratio consistently improves performance across datasets and architectures.

" CASE: Contrastive Activation for Saliency Estimation; This paper proposes CASE, a contrastive saliency estimation method that isolates features uniquely discriminative for a predicted class, addressing the finding that many widely used saliency methods are class-insensitive and produce nearly identical explanations regardless of the class label.

A strain-driven morphotropic phase boundary in BiFeO3; This study demonstrates the formation of a strain-driven morphotropic phase boundary in lead-free piezoelectric bismuth ferrite films, where a tetragonal-like phase can be reversibly converted into a rhombohedral-like phase with an electric field, yielding large electromechanical responses.

Photovoltaic effects in BiFeO3; This paper reports a significant photovoltaic effect in ferroelectric BiFeO3 thin-film heterostructures, characterized by high open-circuit voltages of ~0.8-0.9 V and external quantum efficiencies up to ~10%, an order of magnitude larger than previously reported for ferroelectric-based devices.

Realizing optical magnetism from dielectric metamaterials; This paper demonstrates the first all-dielectric metamaterial composite in the midinfrared, based on micron-sized, high-index tellurium dielectric resonators, which exhibits optical magnetism and is desirable for its low loss and angular invariance.

Optical band gap of BiFeO3 grown by molecular-beam epitaxy; This study reports the growth of phase-pure, epitaxial BiFeO3 thin films on SrTiO3 substrates using molecular-beam epitaxy, and determines through spectroscopic ellipsometry that the material has a direct optical band gap of 2.74 eV.

Linear and nonlinear optical properties of BiFeO3; This study reports the room temperature refractive index and absorption of ferroelectric antiferromagnet bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3) using spectroscopic ellipsometry, finding a direct band gap at 2.81 eV, and determines its nonlinear optical coefficients using second harmonic generation.

Nanoscale Phase Identification Using Two-Dimensional Pair Correlation Functions: A Case Study on Hafnium Oxide; This report presents a methodology for nanoscale phase and orientation identification in polymorphic materials by leveraging vector pair correlation functions extracted from atomically resolved scanning transmission electron microscopy images, demonstrating its accuracy on HfO2-based films.

Characterization of fluorite-structured ferroelectrics using transmission electron microscopy: Techniques, challenges, and recent advances; This review discusses the use of transmission electron microscopy (TEM) to characterize fluorite-structured ferroelectrics like hafnium oxide, highlighting recent advances in TEM techniques that have provided critical insights into their switching mechanisms and phase evolution, while also outlining persistent experimental challenges.

Ischemia‐reperfusion injury in chronic pressure ulcer formation: a skin model in the rat; This study developed and characterized a reproducible rat model of cyclic ischemia-reperfusion injury in the skin to investigate its role in chronic pressure ulcer formation, finding that tissue injury increased with the number and duration of cycles.

Macrophages: an inflammatory link between angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis; This review examines the role of macrophages as key regulators in both angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, particularly in environments of tissue injury or pathology where their numbers are increased and their dynamic behaviors can influence vessel growth and remodeling.

Multiscale computational models of complex biological systems; This review highlights recently published multiscale computational models of biological systems, proposing best practices for future model development that involve coupling continuous and discrete systems to capture biological information across spatial, temporal, and functional scales.

Non-classical monocytes are biased progenitors of wound healing macrophages during soft tissue injury; This study demonstrates that circulating non-classical monocytes are directly recruited to polymer films within skin injuries and are biased progenitors of wound healing macrophages, highlighting their critical role in guiding the design of immunoregenerative materials.

Human adipose-derived stromal cells accelerate diabetic wound healing: impact of cell formulation and delivery; This study shows that human adipose-derived stromal cells (ASCs) accelerate diabetic wound healing in mice, with cells delivered as multicellular aggregates showing a significantly greater therapeutic effect than those delivered in suspension due to enhanced secretion of pro-angiogenic factors.

Multimodal analysis identifies pericyte-centered signaling programs altered by sex and brain region in Alzheimer’s Disease; This study uses single-nucleus RNA sequencing to identify sex- and brain region-specific alterations in pericyte-centered signaling programs in Alzheimer's Disease, revealing changes in TGFβ and estrogen pathways in female donors and a conserved inflammatory program in both sexes.

Pericyte capillary constriction in the hyperglycemic brain similar to in Alzheimer's Disease; This study investigates pericyte-mediated capillary constriction in the hyperglycemic brain, finding similarities to the vascular dysfunction observed in Alzheimer's Disease.

Mechanically Tunable Poly (Ethylene Glycol) Diacrylate Hydrogels Reveal Stiffness‐Related Impairments in Capillary Sprouting in Experimental Lung Fibrosis; This study developed a bioactive PEGDA hydrogel model with tunable stiffness to show that while healthy lung explants had decreased capillary sprouting on stiffer gels, fibrotic lung explants were not impacted by stiffness, a difference associated with higher angiogenic marker expression.

Two‐Photon microscopy functional assays for serial imaging of brain microvessels and the neurovascular unit through disease progression; This paper provides a comprehensive protocol for using two-photon microscopy for serial imaging of neurovascular unit cell types like pericytes, astrocytes, and microglia to evaluate their changes throughout the progression of brain diseases.

Generative diffusion model surrogates for mechanistic agent-based biological models; This work leverages denoising diffusion probabilistic models to train a generative AI surrogate of a computationally expensive Cellular-Potts Model used to investigate in vitro vasculogenesis, enabling accelerated evaluation of the complex biological system.

Fast Preisach-based magnetization model and fast inverse hysteresis model; This paper presents fast computational methods for Preisach-based magnetization models and their inverses, using a differential equation approach that is substantially faster than standard models and enables effective open-loop control of magnetic hysteresis.

Implementation of the Preisach DOK magnetic hysteresis model in a commercial finite element package; This paper describes a method to integrate the fast, Preisach-based DOK magnetic hysteresis model into the ANSYS finite element program, showing that it provides an accurate representation of magnetization without affecting the convergence of the FE solution.

Fast Preisach based magnetostriction model for highly magnetostrictive materials; This paper presents a fast, Preisach-based magnetization model for highly magnetostrictive materials like Terfenol-D that accounts for prestress-induced anisotropy using a bimodal structure and discusses the necessity of strain feedback.

Isotropic media and the simplified vector Preisach model; This paper addresses and suggests a correction for an orientation error in the simplified vector Preisach model, which incorrectly predicts a ratcheting motion for the magnetization of an isotropic medium under a smoothly rotating field.

Preisach modeling of aftereffect in a magneto-optical medium with perpendicular magnetization; This study measures the magnetic aftereffect in Co/Pt multilayer films using a MOKE magnetometer and calculates it with a newly developed Preisach-Arrhenius model, which accurately describes the magnetization decay over time.

Fast Preisach-based vector magnetization model; This paper reformulates the simplified vector Preisach model to speed up its computations for vector magnetization by extending the use of a "cobweb" grid to define the Preisach function for this multi-dimensional model.

Implementation of the simplified vector model; This paper details a new algorithm for the simplified vector Preisach model (SVPM) that extends it from a two-dimensional to a three-dimensional model and provides an efficient implementation.

Dominant Role of Entropy in Stabilizing Sugar Isomerization Transition States within Hydrophobic Zeolite Pores; This study employs experimental and theoretical techniques to show that the dominant stabilization of sugar isomerization transition states within hydrophobic zeolite pores arises from entropic effects, rather than enthalpic effects, due to the disordered nature of confined water.

Structure and solvation of confined water and water–ethanol clusters within microporous Brønsted acids and their effects on ethanol dehydration catalysis; This study disentangles the effects of clustered and networked water structures on ethanol dehydration catalysis within microporous Brønsted acids by measuring turnover rates as water pressure is increased to the point of intrapore condensation.

Heterogeneous MNC Catalysts for Aerobic Oxidation Reactions: Lessons from Oxygen Reduction Electrocatalysts; This review discusses the use of heterogeneous metal-nitrogen-carbon (MNC) catalysts for aerobic oxidation reactions, drawing lessons from their application as oxygen reduction electrocatalysts to guide the design of more effective oxidation catalysts.

Distinct Catalytic Reactivity of Sn Substituted in Framework Locations and at Defect Grain Boundaries in Sn-Zeolites; This study identifies two types of Sn sites in Sn-zeolites with catalytic reactivity for ethanol dehydration differing by more than an order of magnitude, with the more reactive sites attributed to Sn atoms located at grain boundaries or defect sites.

First principles, microkinetic, and experimental analysis of Lewis acid site speciation during ethanol dehydration on Sn-Beta zeolites; This study combines density functional theory calculations with kinetic measurements of ethanol dehydration to identify the relative catalytic contributions of structurally distinct Sn site speciations in Beta zeolite frameworks, constructing a microkinetic model that agrees well with measured data.

Progress and pitfalls in designing heterogeneous catalysts with molecular precision; This Perspective provides a methodological framework for accurately assessing the uniformity of active sites in atomically dispersed heterogeneous catalysts and for linking their synthesis, structure, and function, supplemented with recent case studies.

Chemical kinetics of heterogeneous catalysis: experimental research methodologies and case studies of site-isolated materials; This review discusses experimental research methodologies for performing quantitative kinetic studies of heterogeneous catalysis, with a focus on site-isolated materials, and emphasizes the importance of accurately modeling transport processes to obtain intrinsic kinetic data.

Recommendations for improving rigor and reproducibility in site specific characterization; This work provides an overview of active site characterization techniques in heterogeneous catalysis, outlining common experimental challenges and best practices to avoid data misinterpretation and improve rigor and reproducibility.

Chemical Kinetic Method for Active-Site Quantification in Fe-NC Catalysts and Correlation with Molecular Probe and Spectroscopic Site-Counting Methods; This study develops a kinetic probe reaction method using the aerobic oxidation of a model hydroquinone substrate to quantify the density of FeNx active centers in Fe-N-C catalysts, showing good agreement with other site-counting methods.

Mechanisms underlying rhythmic locomotion: dynamics of muscle activation; This study investigates the dynamical properties of tension development in leech longitudinal muscle during swimming by using a novel 'dual-sinusoid' experimental method that subjects the muscle to both periodic activation and rhythmic length changes.

Muscle function in animal movement: passive mechanical properties of leech muscle; This study investigated the passive mechanical properties of the leech body wall, finding nonlinear and hysteretic length-tension relationships, and developed a mathematical model that accurately describes the tension dynamics for step-stretch experiments.

Analysis of impulse adaptation in motoneurons; This paper presents an analysis of motoneuron input-output relationships in the medicinal leech, revealing that a simple model with a static threshold and a single time constant accurately predicts impulse frequency adaptation to various current injections.

A design approach in an Introduction to Engineering course; This paper describes an Introduction to Engineering course taught with a design-centric approach, where first-year students completed collaborative projects like building a solar-powered phone charger and a persistence of vision wand to learn the engineering design process.

Muscle function and neuromuscular transformation in leech swimming; This work developed a complete systems model for the leech neuromuscular system that predicts tensions generated during swimming by modeling active muscle tension as a product of length-dependent and frequency-dependent factors, capturing the complex transformation from motoneuron activity to muscle contraction.

Navigating AI-Assisted Literature Reviews in First-Year Engineering; This paper discusses the challenges first-year engineering students face with literature reviews and explores how the integration of traditional library instruction and new Generative AI tools like ChatGPT can reshape their research process.

GIFTS: Integrating Generative AI into First-Year Engineering Education: From Knowledge Acquisition and Arduino Projects to Defining Accessibility Problems and Solutions; This GIFTS paper presents two approaches for employing Generative AI in the engineering design process for first-year students, aiming to build their understanding and analytical skills in using tools like Copilot and ChatGPT for knowledge acquisition and ideation.

WIP: Assessing the Progression of Design Process Learning in First-Year Engineering Students; This Work in Progress paper investigates how first-year engineering students' design process knowledge evolves during a two-semester course sequence and evaluates the influence of prior high school engineering experiences on their learning.

Workshop-Leveraging Different Scales of Course Feedback for Enhanced Student Learning and Growth; This workshop explores how various modes and methods of feedback can support holistic student development, aiming to help instructors, administrators, and advisors shape how they collect, process, and apply student feedback for enhanced learning and growth.

Detection of cracks in nuclear power plant using spatial-temporal grouping of local patches; This paper proposes a crack detection method for nuclear power plant inspection videos that fine-tunes a deep neural network to detect local crack patches, which are then grouped in spatio-temporal space for more robust group-level classification.

Thinking about computational thinking: Origins of computational thinking in educational computing; This paper traces the origins of computational thinking to the educational computing research led by Seymour Papert at MIT, arguing that the five decades of work developing environments like Logo provide an important context for contemporary integration efforts.

Improving pollen classification with less training effort; This paper proposes an automatic pollen classification method that improves accuracy with less training effort by developing a new feature to capture pollen spikes, applying classification rules from existing types to new ones, and using a new selection criterion to obtain valuable unlabeled samples.

Hydrogen sulfide modulates sinusoidal constriction and contributes to hepatic micorcirculatory dysfunction during endotoxemia; This study determined that hydrogen sulfide (H2S) contributes to hepatic microcirculatory dysfunction during endotoxemia by modulating sinusoidal constriction, as shown by in vivo portal pressure measurements and intravital microscopy in a rat model.

Tracking colliding cells in vivo microscopy; This paper presents a method to automatically track multiple colliding leukocytes in intravital microscopy videos by modeling the appearance and motion for each collision state and testing hypotheses of possible transitions between states.

The NTLS microscope prototyping system; This article introduces the National Technology Leadership Society (NTLS) microscope prototyping system, highlighting the coalition's goal of advancing the effective use of technology for teaching and learning.

Sensor Fusion Enhances Anomaly Detection in a Flood Forecasting System; This paper devises a novel multi-stream sensor data verification and anomaly detection method for IoT-based flood forecasting systems that uses sensor fusion between nearby devices to improve F1-Score by 10.8% over previous methods.

AI in Informal and Formal Education: A Historical Perspective; This paper traces the evolution of educational technology through the waves of microcomputers, the Internet, and generative AI, demonstrating how educational computing and AI have been intertwined since the development of Logo at MIT.

Creating an Impactful and Cost-Effective Flood Prediction Platform; This paper showcases the pipeline for the Flood-Watch project, which aims to advance flood monitoring and prediction by collecting weather data through the LoRa protocol to be used in flood risk forecasting and visualization.

Age prediction from 12-lead electrocardiograms using deep learning: a comparison of four models on a contemporary, freely available dataset; This study implemented and compared four deep learning models for predicting age and sex from 12-lead electrocardiograms on a freely available dataset, finding the best models achieved a mean absolute error of 8.06 years for age and an AUC of 0.92 for sex.

Deepflash: An efficient network for learning-based medical image registration; This paper presents DeepFLASH, a novel and efficient network for learning-based medical image registration that operates entirely in a low-dimensional bandlimited space, dramatically reducing computational cost while maintaining high accuracy.

Probabilistic principal geodesic analysis; This paper presents a probabilistic latent variable model for principal geodesic analysis (PGA), providing a probabilistic framework for factor analysis on manifolds and using a Monte Carlo Expectation Maximization algorithm to compute maximum likelihood estimates.

Bayesian estimation of regularization and atlas building in diffeomorphic image registration; This paper presents a generative Bayesian model for diffeomorphic image registration and atlas building that simultaneously estimates the atlas and the parameters controlling transformation smoothness using a Monte Carlo Expectation Maximization algorithm.

Finite-Dimensional Lie Algebras for Fast Diffeomorphic Image Registration; This paper presents a fast geodesic shooting algorithm for diffeomorphic image registration by introducing a finite-dimensional Lie algebra structure on bandlimited velocity fields, which allows computations to be performed in a much lower-dimensional space.

Fast diffeomorphic image registration via Fourier-approximated Lie algebras; This paper introduces FLASH, a fast geodesic shooting algorithm for diffeomorphic image registration that approximates the infinite-dimensional Lie algebra of vector fields with a low-dimensional, bandlimited space, resulting in dramatic savings in time and memory.

Interior Object Geometry via Fitted Frames; This paper proposes a method to compute fitted frames on the boundary and interior of objects to produce alignment-free, locally corresponding geometric features for powerful statistical analysis of object populations, such as hippocampi shapes.

Unsupervised Cardiac Video Translation Via Motion Feature Guided Diffusion Model; This paper proposes an unsupervised method for cardiac video translation using a motion feature-guided diffusion model to generate realistic cardiac motion sequences.

IGG: Image Generation Informed by Geodesic Dynamics in Deformation Spaces; This paper presents IGG, a novel framework for Image Generation informed by Geodesic dynamics that combines an efficient autoencoder learning geodesic paths with a latent geodesic diffusion model to ensure smooth, topology-preserving, and interpretable image deformations.

Robust Deep Convolutional Dictionary Model with Alignment Assistance for Multi-Contrast MRI Super-resolution; This paper proposes a robust alignment-assisted multi-contrast convolutional dictionary (A2-CDic) model for MRI super-resolution that explicitly models correlations, handles spatial misalignment, and effectively constrains complementary information between modalities.

Performance degradation and gassing of Li4Ti5O12/LiMn2O4 lithium-ion cells; This study on 2 Ah Li4Ti5O12/LiMn2O4 cells reveals that at elevated temperatures, significant capacity and power loss occurred due to the formation of a manganese, phosphorous, and fluorine-containing coating on the anode, accompanied by substantial hydrogen gas generation.

Electrochemistry and safety of Li4Ti5O12 and graphite anodes paired with LiMn2O4 for hybrid electric vehicle Li-ion battery applications; This paper describes the electrochemical and safety characterization of Li4Ti5O12 (LTO) and graphite anodes paired with LiMn2O4 cathodes, finding that LTO outperforms graphite in cycle life, pulsing impedance, and thermal stability, making it an attractive alternative for high-power automotive applications.

A Review on Synthesis and Engineering of Crystal Precursors Produced Via Coprecipitation for Multicomponent Lithium-Ion Battery Cathode Materials; This highlight summarizes advancements in producing crystalline precursor particles for lithium-ion battery cathodes via coprecipitation, focusing on the synthesis of tunable, complex morphologies and the fundamental knowledge gained from studying the reaction process.

Growth mechanism of Ni0. 3Mn0. 7CO3 precursor for high capacity Li-ion battery cathodes; This study investigates the nucleation and growth of Ni0.3Mn0.7CO3 precursor particles for Li-ion battery cathodes during a continuous stirred tank reactor process, finding that a lead time of about 5 hours was necessary to achieve uniformity in particle shape and chemical composition.

Composition-tailored synthesis of gradient transition metal precursor particles for lithium-ion battery cathode materials; This paper reports the tailored synthesis of precursor particles with internal gradients in transition metal composition using a coprecipitation reaction, which were then used to create a novel Li1.2(Mn0.62Ni0.38)0.8O2 cathode material for lithium-ion batteries.

Sulfonated Cation Exchange Membrane for Selective Transport in Non-Aqueous Redox Flow Battery Applications; This work focuses on the development and characterization of a sulfonated cation exchange membrane designed for selective ion transport in non-aqueous redox flow battery applications.

Poly (Phenylene Oxide) Backbone Membrane Separators for Lithium-Metal Batteries; This study investigates the use of poly(phenylene oxide) backbone membranes as separators for lithium-metal batteries, aiming to improve battery safety and performance.

Lithium capture from simulated geothermal brine via chemical reduction of iron phosphate in a packed bed reactor; This study explores an alternative approach for lithium capture from simulated geothermal brine using a packed bed reactor where the capture is driven by the chemical reduction of iron phosphate intercalation host particles by a Fe2+-citrate complex.

Selective Cation Exchange Membrane for Nonaqueous Flow Battery Separator; This paper discusses the development of selective cation exchange membranes for nonaqueous redox flow batteries, which offer the potential for higher cell voltages and energy densities compared to traditional aqueous systems.

Evaluation of All Active Material Electrodes with Varying Thickness in Lithium-Ion Batteries; This study evaluates the performance of thick, all-active-material lithium-ion battery electrodes, which lack binder or conductive additives, to understand the trade-offs between increased volumetric energy density and potential increases in cell overpotential.

Adaptive sensitivity encoding incorporating temporal filtering (TSENSE); This article presents an adaptive method of sensitivity encoding called TSENSE, which incorporates both spatial and temporal filtering by acquiring phase encodes in an interleaved manner to improve image reconstruction from undersampled k-space data.

Cardiovascular magnetic resonance phase contrast imaging; This article provides a comprehensive review of the current state-of-the-art in cardiovascular magnetic resonance phase contrast imaging, covering methodology, clinical applications, and emerging research that utilizes the latest technology.

Myocardial tissue tracking with two-dimensional cine displacement-encoded MR imaging: development and initial evaluation; This paper describes the development and initial evaluation of a breath-hold, two-dimensional cine displacement-encoded (DENSE) MR pulse sequence for quantitative myocardial motion tracking, which demonstrated good agreement with conventional MR tagging for measuring circumferential strain.

Collagen-targeted MRI contrast agent for molecular imaging of fibrosis; This paper describes the development of a collagen-targeted MRI contrast agent for the noninvasive detection, assessment, and monitoring of fibrosis, a common outcome in many chronic diseases of the heart, kidney, liver, and lungs.

Macrophage subpopulations are essential for infarct repair with and without stem cell therapy; This study investigates the role of macrophages in mediating the favorable effects of mesenchymal stromal cell (MSC) therapy in myocardial infarction, finding that MSCs increase the percentage of reparative M2 macrophages, which are essential for infarct repair.

Multiparametric CMR identifies macrophage NOS2-mediated benefits of preventive SGLT2 inhibition in a mouse model of metabolic heart disease; This study used multiparametric cardiac magnetic resonance to investigate whether preventive SGLT2 inhibitor administration attenuates metabolic heart disease in mice, finding that the benefits are mediated by macrophage NOS2.

Prospective Evaluation of the Cardiovascular Effects of BRAF and MEK Inhibitors in Patients With Melanoma; This prospective cohort study characterizes the incidence and risk factors for BRAF and MEK inhibitor-associated hypertension and cardiac dysfunction in melanoma patients, finding a high incidence of cardiovascular adverse effects despite low baseline cardiotoxicity risk.

Preclinical MRI of proinflammatory epicardial adipose tissue: Accelerated methods for simultaneous fatty acid composition and relaxation parameter mapping with relationships to …; This study presents an accelerated cardiac magnetic resonance method for simultaneous mapping of epicardial adipose tissue fatty acid composition and T1, and evaluates their relationships with histological and cytokine markers of inflammation in a mouse model of obesity.

DENSE-Guided Deep Motion Networks Accounted by Large Rotations to Improve Myocardial Strain Analysis from Routine Cine MRI; This paper introduces a novel DENSE-guided deep learning network that explicitly accounts for large rotational motion to improve myocardial strain analysis from standard cine bSSFP images, demonstrating improved accuracy in predicting myocardial displacements and strains.

Tensor decomposition for signal processing and machine learning; This overview article provides a foundational starting point for researchers and practitioners interested in learning about and applying tensor decomposition in signal processing, statistics, data mining, and machine learning.

Transmit beamforming for physical-layer multicasting; This paper proves that transmit beamforming for physical-layer multicasting is NP-hard but shows that semidefinite relaxation techniques can be successfully applied to find approximate solutions with performance guarantees for both minimum power and max-min SNR problem formulations.

Towards k-means-friendly spaces: Simultaneous deep learning and clustering; This work proposes a joint dimensionality reduction and K-means clustering approach that learns a deep neural network to recover clustering-friendly latent representations from data generated by an unknown nonlinear function, showcasing improved performance on real datasets.

Learning to optimize: Training deep neural networks for interference management; This paper proposes a new learning-based perspective for interference management in wireless communications by using a deep neural network to approximate the input-output mapping of a traditional optimization algorithm, significantly reducing computational complexity while maintaining high performance.

Parallel factor analysis in sensor array processing; This paper establishes a link between multiple invariance sensor array processing and parallel factor (PARAFAC) analysis, which facilitates the derivation of powerful identifiability results and shows that the uniqueness of ESPRIT stems from the uniqueness of low-rank tensor decomposition.

Subspace Clustering of Subspaces: Unifying Canonical Correlation Analysis and Subspace Clustering; This paper introduces Subspace Clustering of Subspaces (SCoS), a novel framework for clustering a collection of tall matrices based on their column spaces by using a Block Term Decomposition of a third-order tensor, achieving superior performance in hyperspectral imaging datasets.

The Vertex-Attribute-Constrained Densest -Subgraph Problem; This paper introduces the Vertex-Attribute-Constrained Densest k-Subgraph (VAC-DS) problem, a new variant of the densest subgraph problem that incorporates vertex attributes, and proposes an efficient Frank-Wolfe algorithm to solve its tight continuous relaxation.

Linearly Precoded Signal Alignment: How to Excise Interference with Little Rate Loss; This paper introduces a repetitionless signal alignment strategy that uses linear precoding to guarantee interference excision in wireless communication with a controllable and practically negligible rate loss.
