From the Editor: How to Do Continuity; This is an editorial titled "How to Do Continuity" from The Electrochemical Society Interface.

Leveraging Finite Element Method Modeling to Evaluate ZnNi Plating as a Mitigation Strategy for Galvanically Induced Environmental-Assisted Cracking of a P675-Anodized Titanium …; This study uses a combined experimental and computational approach to evaluate the effectiveness of a sacrificial ZnNi plating in mitigating galvanically induced environmental-assisted cracking of a Pyrowear 675-anodized titanium assembly.

From the Editor: Lessons in Chemistry; In this editorial from The Electrochemical Society Interface, the author humorously reflects on his personal struggles with pool chemistry, drawing parallels to his professional life as an electrochemist.

Experimental and Computational Comparison of Two Chromate-Free Corrosion Protection Coatings for Mitigating Galvanic Attack on AA7075 Coupled to Corrosion-Resistant Steel A286 …; This work experimentally and computationally compares a sol-gel barrier coating and a sacrificially pigmented polymer coating for their effectiveness in mitigating galvanic corrosion on AA7075 coupled to steel.

Generalized stacking fault energy, ideal strength and twinnability of dilute Mg-based alloys: A first-principles study of shear deformation; This first-principles study systematically investigates how 14 different alloying elements affect the generalized stacking fault energy, ideal shear strength, and twinnability of dilute magnesium alloys.

Diffusion coefficients of alloying elements in dilute Mg alloys: A comprehensive first-principles study; This paper presents a comprehensive first-principles study calculating the temperature-dependent tracer diffusion coefficients for 47 different alloying elements in dilute hexagonal close-packed magnesium.

Adsorption-controlled growth of La-doped BaSnO3 by molecular-beam epitaxy; This study demonstrates the growth of high-mobility La-doped BaSnO3 films by molecular-beam epitaxy in an adsorption-controlled regime, suggesting that defects other than threading dislocations are the primary limiters of electron mobility.

A comprehensive first-principles study of pure elements: Vacancy formation and migration energies and self-diffusion coefficients; This paper reports a comprehensive first-principles study that calculates and compiles vacancy formation energies, migration energies, and self-diffusion coefficients as a function of temperature for 82 pure elements.

First-principles thermodynamic theory of Seebeck coefficients; This paper presents a novel thermodynamic theory for first-principles calculations of Seebeck coefficients that, unlike traditional methods, does not rely on assumptions about electron-scattering mechanisms.

Opportunities for novel refractory alloy thermal/environmental barrier coatings using multicomponent rare earth oxides; This article discusses the opportunities and challenges of developing single-layer, multicomponent rare earth oxide coatings for refractory alloys to serve as thermal and environmental barriers in combustion environments.

A cluster-based computational thermodynamics framework with intrinsic chemical short-range order: Part I. Configurational contribution; This paper develops a hybrid computational thermodynamics framework that combines the Cluster Variation Method and CALPHAD to efficiently and reliably predict chemical short-range order in multicomponent alloys.

Thermodynamic modeling of the Hf-Ta-O system for the design of oxidation resistant HfC-TaC ceramics; This study develops a CALPHAD thermodynamic model of the Hf-Ta-O system, in conjunction with experimental and first-principles data, to improve the understanding of the oxidation resistance of HfC-TaC ultra-high temperature ceramics.

Structure and formation mechanisms in tantalum and niobium oxides in superconducting quantum circuits; Using advanced electron microscopy and thermodynamic modeling, this study reveals that the surface oxide on tantalum has fewer suboxides and a more abrupt transition to the base metal compared to niobium, potentially explaining its lower loss in superconducting quantum circuits.

Quantitative comparison of algorithms for tracking single fluorescent particles; This paper quantitatively compares four common algorithms for tracking single fluorescent particles in noisy images, finding that cross-correlation provides the best combination of accuracy and precision for a wide range of particle sizes.

Mechanics of actomyosin bonds in different nucleotide states are tuned to muscle contraction; Using a laser trap, this study shows that the actomyosin bond behaves as a "catch" bond, with increasing lifetimes under increasing loads, and surprisingly finds that the myosin-ADP bond is stronger under load than the rigor bond.

Smooth muscle and skeletal muscle myosins produce similar unitary forces and displacements in the laser trap; Using a laser trap and mean-variance analysis, this study found that single molecules of smooth and skeletal muscle myosin produce similar unitary forces and displacements, suggesting that differences in their force-generating capacity and velocity are due to cross-bridge kinetics rather than individual mechanical events.

Two heads of myosin are better than one for generating force and motion; Using an optical-trap transducer, this study found that double-headed smooth- and skeletal-muscle myosins produce approximately twice the unitary displacement and force of their single-headed counterparts, suggesting that both heads are required for maximal force and motion.

Teaching peer review and the process of scientific writing; This paper presents a detailed method for teaching undergraduate students the full scientific publishing process, including anonymous peer review and revision, through a term paper assignment in a cell and molecular biology course.

Impact of a curriculum and design course redesign on student’s engineering design process knowledge; This paper examines the impact of redesigning a first-year engineering curriculum by integrating a technical design course with a sociotechnical concepts course into a single sequence, aiming to improve students' understanding of the engineering design process.

System and method for disinfection of a plumbing system associated with liquid waste; This patent describes a thermal disinfection system for plumbing that uses a heating device in contact with a liquid-carrying conduit, covered by an insulating layer, to heat the conduit's lumen and prevent microbial growth.

Tailpiece Heating device for effective prevention of biofilm growth in sink plumbing; This study demonstrates that a novel electronic tailpiece heater, when set to 75°C, effectively prevents the upward growth of bacterial biofilm from a sink's p-trap, offering a promising approach to prevent the spread of resistant bacteria in hospitals.

From theory to practice: unraveling the impact of experiential learning in biomedical engineering education; This paper explores the impact of experiential learning in biomedical engineering education, arguing that hands-on, real-world experiences like clinical and research projects are crucial for developing problem-solving skills and understanding user needs.

Accelerated wound healing by injectable microporous gel scaffolds assembled from annealed building blocks; This paper shows that an injectable, interconnected microporous gel scaffold, assembled from annealed microgel building blocks, can circumvent the limitations of traditional hydrogels by facilitating rapid cell migration and tissue regeneration in vivo.

Activating an adaptive immune response from a hydrogel scaffold imparts regenerative wound healing; This study shows that slowing the degradation of Microporous Annealed Particle (MAP) scaffolds by using d-chiral peptides unexpectedly elicits an antigen-specific adaptive immune response that imparts significant regenerative wound healing, including hair neogenesis.

Photodegradable macromers and hydrogels for live cell encapsulation and release; This paper describes the synthesis and characterization of photodegradable hydrogels incorporating ortho-nitrobenzyl groups, which allow for external real-time spatial and temporal control over hydrogel degradation for the staged release of encapsulated cells.

Particle hydrogels based on hyaluronic acid building blocks; This paper discusses the formation of injectable, in situ forming microporous scaffolds from hyaluronic acid-based microgel particles, an emerging platform that mimics the extracellular matrix while allowing for enhanced cell integration.

Photodegradable hydrogels to generate positive and negative features over multiple length scales; This paper presents a photodegradable hydrogel based on an ortho-nitrobenzylether moiety that can be used as a biocompatible photoresist to create both positive and negative features over a broad range of length scales using single- and two-photon degradation.

PS17. 3: Optimizing islet transplantation with Microporous Annealed Particle MAP scaffold to improve engraftment and modulate immune responses.; This study investigates the use of Microporous Annealed Particle (MAP) gel as an injectable, granular scaffold to enhance islet viability, promote engraftment, and modulate immune responses in both syngeneic and xenogeneic transplantation settings for diabetes management.

Microporous Annealed Particle (MAP) Gel as a Novel Scaffold for Beta-Cell Replacement Therapy: Enhancing Engraftment and Immunomodulation in a Murine Model; This study evaluates microporous annealed particle (MAP) gel as a supportive scaffold for dissociated murine islet transplantation, demonstrating that it enhances engraftment and restores normoglycemia in a syngeneic mouse model of diabetes.

Delivery of dissociated islets cells within microporous annealed particle scaffold to treat type 1 diabetes; This patent describes compositions and methods for treating Type 1 diabetes by administering a suspension of pancreatic islet cells contained within or encapsulated by an injectable, microporous annealed particle (MAP) scaffold.

Development of a Clinically Relevant Rabbit Model of Acute Laryngeal Injury; This study demonstrates a reliable rabbit model of acute laryngeal injury that reproduces the acute wound process seen clinically, characterized by significant posterior glottic thickening and a shift towards active collagen formation consistent with early scar development.

07-4: ADVANCING ISLET AND CELL TRANSPLANTATION: MICROPOROUS ANNEALED PARTICLE (MAP) GEL AS A SCAFFOLD FOR ENHANCED ENGRAFTMENT AND IMMUNOMODULATION; This study investigates the use of Microporous Annealed Particle (MAP) gel as a scaffold for islet transplantation, showing that it restores and maintains normoglycemia in diabetic mice when co-transplanted with dissociated islet cells.

Treadmarks: Shared memory computing on networks of workstations; This paper discusses the TreadMarks distributed shared memory system, which allows parallel programs to run on a network of workstations by providing the abstraction of a globally shared virtual memory.

Parallel metropolis coupled Markov chain Monte Carlo for Bayesian phylogenetic inference; This paper presents a parallel algorithm for Metropolis-coupled Markov chain Monte Carlo that retains the ability to explore multiple peaks in the posterior distribution of phylogenetic trees while achieving nearly linear speed improvement through parallelization.

Treadmarks: Distributed shared memory on standard workstations and operating systems.; This paper presents a performance evaluation of TreadMarks, a user-level distributed shared memory system, demonstrating good speedups for several applications on an 8-processor ATM network and supporting the viability of DSM for parallel computation on workstation clusters.

Peer-to-peer information retrieval using self-organizing semantic overlay networks; This paper presents pSearch, a decentralized, non-flooding peer-to-peer information retrieval system that distributes document indices based on their semantics to reduce search costs and improve efficiency.

Energy-efficient processor design using multiple clock domains with dynamic voltage and frequency scaling; This paper describes and evaluates a multiple clock domain processor architecture where the chip is divided into several domains that can be independently scaled in voltage and frequency to achieve significant energy savings.

JSPIM: A Skew-Aware PIM Accelerator for High-Performance Databases Join and Select Operations; This paper introduces JSPIM, a skew-aware Processing-in-Memory accelerator that co-designs the algorithm and hardware to accelerate database join and select queries by deploying parallel search engines and redesigned hash tables to achieve significant speedups.

Concurrent PIM and Load/Store Servicing in PIM-Enabled Memory; This paper characterizes the performance of a PIM-enabled GPU system when co-executing regular GPU kernels with PIM kernels, finding that memory saturation by PIM can lead to extreme unfairness and proposing a concurrent servicing mechanism to mitigate this issue.

Rollingcache: using runtime behavior to defend against cache side channel attacks; This patent describes the RollingCache system, a method to defend against cache side-channel attacks by dynamically changing the set of addresses contending for cache sets using one or more levels of indirection controlled by whole-cache runtime behavior.

RollingCache: Using Runtime Behavior to Defend Against Cache Side Channel Attacks; This paper presents RollingCache, a cache design that defends against contention-based side channel attacks by dynamically and non-deterministically changing the mapping of addresses to cache sets based on whole-cache runtime behavior.

Relief: Relieving memory pressure in socs via data movement-aware accelerator scheduling; This paper presents RELIEF, an online, least laxity-driven accelerator scheduling policy that relieves memory pressure in accelerator-rich architectures by being aware of and prioritizing data movement opportunities like peer-to-peer DMA.

Patterns in property specifications for finite-state verification; This paper addresses the challenge of specifying system requirements for finite-state verification tools by proposing a pattern-based approach to codify and reuse common property specifications, making them more accessible to practitioners.

Bandera: Extracting finite-state models from Java source code; This paper describes Bandera, an integrated collection of program analysis and transformation components that enables the automatic extraction of safe, compact, finite-state models from Java source code for use in model checking.

Property specification patterns for finite-state verification; This paper proposes a pattern-based approach to the presentation, codification, and reuse of property specifications for finite-state verification to address the challenge practitioners face in translating informal requirements into formal specification languages.

Constructing interaction test suites for highly-configurable systems in the presence of constraints: A greedy approach; This paper develops a family of greedy combinatorial interaction testing algorithms that leverage modern Boolean satisfiability solvers to efficiently construct test suites for highly-configurable systems with constraints between parameters.

Differential symbolic execution; This paper introduces differential symbolic execution, a novel technique that computes a precise behavioral characterization of a program change by exploiting similarities between program versions to reduce analysis cost and improve results.

LoCaL: Countering Surface Bias in Code Evaluation Metrics; This work introduces LoCaL, a new benchmark for code evaluation metrics that includes code pairs designed to be surface-similar but functionally dissimilar, revealing that state-of-the-art reference-based metrics are strongly biased towards surface-level features rather than code functionality.

NeuralSAT: A High-Performance Verification Tool for Deep Neural Networks; This paper presents and evaluates NeuralSAT, a high-performance verification tool for Deep Neural Networks that uses the DPLL(T) framework and has demonstrated competitive performance and versatility in recent VNN-COMP competitions.

Instructor strategies to aid implementation of active learning: a systematic literature review; This systematic literature review analyzes 29 studies to identify instructor strategies for implementing active learning in STEM classrooms and addressing negative student responses, finding that strategies often focus on explaining the benefits of active learning and providing structure.

Negative student response to active learning in STEM classrooms: A systematic review of underlying reasons; This systematic literature review of 57 STEM studies examines the reasons behind students' negative responses to active learning, identifying six overarching categories including perceived limited value, lack of time, and increased difficulty.

Bilevel methods for image reconstruction; This review discusses bilevel optimization methods for learning parameters in image reconstruction problems, where prior assumptions are learned from training data to improve the recovery of unknown variables from collected measurements.

Systematic literature review of students’ affective responses to active learning: Overview of results; This paper presents an overview of a systematic literature review of 412 studies on students' affective responses to active learning in undergraduate STEM courses, finding that responses are overwhelmingly positive but that few studies received a high quality score.

Instructional factors influencing conceptual understanding of signals and systems; Through interviews with faculty, students, and practicing engineers, this paper investigates instructional factors that influence conceptual understanding of signals and systems, identifying practices like lectures that connect concepts to math and hands-on activities with immediate feedback.

Developing an introductory machine learning course; This paper presents the design of an introductory machine learning course for first and second-year undergraduates that emphasizes the mathematical perspective and conceptual understanding behind ML algorithms without requiring advanced math prerequisites.

Circuit Troubleshooting Techniques in an Electrical and Computer Engineering Laboratory; This research investigates the hardware troubleshooting methods used by undergraduate electrical engineering students when working with breadboarded circuits, aiming to identify common strategies to help educators improve students' troubleshooting ability.

Building Better Engineers: Teaching Chemical Engineers to Troubleshoot in the Laboratory; This study examines the efficacy of integrating structured troubleshooting training modules into a chemical engineering laboratory course, finding that the modules improved students' troubleshooting skills during a hands-on exercise.

Experimental Self-Efficacy and Troubleshooting Ability in a Chemical Engineering Laboratory; This study assesses the experimental self-efficacy and troubleshooting abilities of fourth-year chemical engineering students, finding that while students were confident in their conceptual understanding, they often resorted to less effective troubleshooting strategies like simply following directions or random guessing.

Rodinia: A benchmark suite for heterogeneous computing; This paper presents and characterizes Rodinia, a benchmark suite of applications and kernels designed for heterogeneous computing platforms like multi-core CPUs and GPUs, which covers a wide range of parallel patterns and has led to important architectural insights.

Scalable parallel programming with cuda: Is cuda the parallel programming model that application developers have been waiting for?; This article discusses the potential of CUDA as a scalable parallel programming model that allows application developers to leverage the increasing number of processor cores in mainstream multicore CPUs and manycore GPUs.

PIMsynth: A Unified Compiler Framework for Bit-Serial Processing-In-Memory Architectures; This paper presents PIMsynth, a fully automated compiler framework that takes Verilog as input and generates optimized micro-operation code for both digital and analog bit-serial processing-in-memory architectures.

DReX: Accurate and Scalable Dense Retrieval Acceleration via Algorithmic-Hardware Codesign; This paper proposes DReX, a dataset-agnostic, accurate, and scalable dense retrieval acceleration scheme that uses a novel algorithmic-hardware co-design with in-DRAM logic to perform early filtering of embedding vectors for retrieval-augmented generation.

Memory devices including processing-in-memory architecture configured to provide accumulation dispatching and hybrid partitioning; This patent describes an integrated circuit memory device with a processing-in-memory architecture that includes sub-array level processors configured to perform column-oriented processing for tasks like sparse matrix operations.

Dynamic random access memory-based content-addressable memory (DRAM-CAM) architecture for exact pattern matching; This patent discloses a Dynamic Random Access Memory-Based Content-Addressable Memory (DRAM-CAM) architecture that can perform concurrent, bit-by-bit exact pattern matching on data organized into specific block formats.

Systems, circuits, methods, and articles of manufacturer for dram-based digital bit-serial vector computing architecture; This patent discloses a DRAM-based digital bit-serial vector computing architecture that embeds computation in the DRAM subarray, leveraging massive parallelism to outperform analog techniques and traditional CPU/GPU approaches.

Designing for a Sustainable World: Integrating the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals into a First-year Engineering Course in Science, Technology, and Society; This paper describes the integration of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals into a first-year engineering course in science, technology, and society to guide students in developing innovative technological designs.

Fostering Ethical Innovation in Engineering Education and Design; This paper describes how ethical frameworks of sustainability, justice, and care were integrated into a first-year engineering course to challenge students to apply both technical and ethical training in generating innovative and socially responsible designs.

Rogue Engineering: Teaching Frankenstein as a Parable of (Un) ethical Engineering Practice; This paper analyzes how Mary Shelley's novel Frankenstein was used in a science, technology, and society course to foster ethical reflection among engineering undergraduates on the perils of irresponsible, presumptuous, and biased techno-science.

Communication across Divisions: Trends Emerging from the 2019 Annual Conference of ASEE and Some Possibilities for Strategic Action; This paper analyzes papers on communication from the 2019 ASEE Annual Conference, revealing growing interest across divisions and identifying trends such as a focus on disciplinary communication and interdisciplinary collaboration, while also proposing strategies to develop a Communication across Divisions Network.

Frankenstein Lives! Teaching Mary Shelley's Novel in the Engineering Classroom; This study performs a thematic analysis of student reflections on reading Mary Shelley's Frankenstein in an engineering STS course, finding that students were able to articulate ethical themes from the novel and express a commitment to more socially responsible engineering practices.

Learning through Play: Using LEGO® Products, Practices, and Values to Teach Social and Ethical Aspects of Engineering Design; This paper describes an STS course called "The LEGO Course" that pairs seminar discussions with studio design experiences to integrate social and ethical perspectives with authentic engineering design challenges, leveraging the LEGO Group's philosophy of "learning through play."

On the mechanical performance of closed cell Al alloy foams; This study examines the mechanical properties of three commercially available closed-cell aluminum alloy foams, affirming that curved and wiggled cell walls play a prevalent role in determining stiffness and strength.

Experimental analysis of deformation mechanisms in a closed-cell aluminum alloy foam; This study monitors the evolution of plastic deformation in a cellular aluminum alloy during compression using digital image correlation, identifying three stages: uniform localized straining at nodes, formation of discrete strain bands, and finally, complete plastic collapse of one band.

Compressive deformation and yielding mechanisms in cellular Al alloys determined using X-ray tomography and surface strain mapping; Using X-ray computed tomography and surface strain mapping, this study establishes that compressive deformation in cellular Al alloys localizes into narrow bands, with yielding initiated by the collective deformation of primarily elliptical cells.

Tuna robotics: A high-frequency experimental platform exploring the performance space of swimming fishes; This paper describes the design and testing of Tunabot, a high-frequency robotic platform based on yellowfin tuna and Atlantic mackerel, which achieved swimming speeds of 4.0 body lengths per second at a 15 hertz tail beat frequency, enabling exploration of the high-performance fish swimming space.

Measurement and analysis of the structural performance of cellular metal sandwich construction; This study measured and simulated the bending performance of sandwich construction with thin cellular metal cores, generating a mechanism map to characterize failure phenomena and finding that initial discrepancies with simulations were rectified by using core shear properties measured on materials of the same thickness.

Development of a turning control strategy for a bio-inspired underwater vehicle; This study presents a single-actuator turning strategy for a bio-inspired robotic fish, the Tunabot, which uses asymmetric tail-beat timing to generate turning forces, achieving a turning radius of 1.42 body lengths with a 66% timing difference.

Morphokinematic Impacts on Hydrodynamics and Performance of Tuna-Inspired Robots; This research utilizes computational fluid dynamics to study how morphological and kinematic parameters, such as body thickness, affect the hydrodynamic performance and thrust generation of the Tunabot Flex, a high-performance tuna-inspired robotic platform.

Effects Fin Geometry and Fin Ray Stiffness on the Performance of Bio-inspired Flapping Propulsion; This work uses a computational model with two-way fluid-structure interaction to investigate how altering the geometry and stiffness of the median fins on a bio-inspired swimming robot affects vortex interactions and hydrodynamic force production.

Understanding, detecting and localizing partial failures in large system software; This paper studies 100 real-world partial failures in large distributed systems and proposes OmegaGen, a static analysis tool that automatically generates customized watchdogs to detect and localize such failures with high accuracy and low detection time.

Fast and concurrent {RDF} queries using {RDMA-assisted}{GPU} graph exploration; This paper addresses the challenge of inefficient concurrent SPARQL query processing on large RDF graphs by proposing a solution that uses RDMA-assisted GPU graph exploration to achieve fast and concurrent query execution.

RESIN: A Holistic Service for Dealing with Memory Leaks in Production Cloud Infrastructure; This paper presents RESIN, a holistic service designed to address the challenge of memory leaks in large production cloud systems by providing a low-overhead, high-accuracy solution for their detection and diagnosis.

Demystifying and Checking Silent Semantic Violations in Large Distributed Systems; This paper investigates the under-studied problem of silent semantic violations in large distributed systems, where bugs cause the system to deviate from its expected behavior without any apparent anomalies, leading to prolonged damage.

Comprehensive and efficient runtime checking in system software through watchdogs; This paper advocates for the use of intrinsic, fine-grained software watchdogs to detect complex failure modes in modern systems software and presents an early exploration into automatically generating mimic-type watchdogs that imitate the main program for comprehensive runtime checking.

Verifying Computational Graphs in Production-Grade Distributed Machine Learning Frameworks; This paper presents Scalify, a lightweight framework that verifies the semantic equivalence of computational graphs in production-grade distributed machine learning frameworks to expose silent errors, using equality saturation and Datalog-style reasoning to scale to models as large as Llama-3.1-405B.

Deriving semantic checkers from tests to detect silent failures in production distributed systems; This paper proposes a method to automatically derive semantic checkers from existing tests to detect silent failures in production distributed systems, addressing the challenge that manually writing good checkers requires deep domain knowledge and substantial effort.

Orchestrating Cross-Layer Anomaly Detection and Mitigation to Address Gray Failures in Large-Scale Cloud Infrastructure; This paper presents Panacea, a holistic framework that automatically detects and mitigates host anomalies causing gray failures in production cloud infrastructure by correlating insights from VMs, applications, and the underlying host.

Verifying Semantic Equivalence of Large Models with Equality Saturation; This work proposes Aerify, a framework that uses equality saturation to automatically verify the semantic equivalence of machine learning models, thereby exposing silent computational errors introduced by parallelism and optimization techniques in modern ML frameworks.

ENHANCING CLOUD SYSTEM RUNTIME TO ADDRESS COMPLEX FAILURES; This dissertation enhances the runtime capabilities of cloud systems to detect, localize, and react to complex failures by introducing tools like OmegaGen for partial failures, Oathkeeper for silent semantic violations, and RESIN for memory leaks.

The gendered division of labor among STEM faculty and the effects of critical mass.; Using data from the 2004 National Study of Postsecondary Faculty, this study found a gendered division of labor among STEM faculty at research universities that is mitigated by the presence of a critical mass of women in the discipline.

Promoting gender diversity in STEM faculty through leadership development: From local and national leadership workshops to the online LEAD-it-Yourself! toolkit; This paper chronicles the growth of the ADVANCE leadership program at the University of Washington, which evolved from a campus-based workshop for department chairs to a national program and a web-based toolkit designed to promote gender diversity in STEM faculty.

Majorism: Neoliberalism in Student Culture; This ethnography describes an ideology called "majorism" within a university's student culture, which reflects the preferential treatment of science and technology over the Liberal Arts and shapes students' understanding of the institution's values and purpose.

The ADVANCE mentoring-for-leadership lunch series for women faculty in STEM at the University of Washington; This paper describes the University of Washington ADVANCE program's Mentoring-for-Leadership lunch series, a group mentoring initiative designed to build community and encourage women faculty in STEM to consider leadership roles.

“The Revolution Will Not Be Supervised:” Consent and Open Secrets in Data Science; This article uses the concept of consent to analyze the social dynamics and power relations in data science knowledge production, hypothesizing a link between gender harassment in the workplace and the extraction of human experiences to produce Big Data.

Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Convenience—on whose terms and at what costs?; This piece from the Digital Technology for Democracy Lab at the University of Virginia questions the societal costs and power dynamics behind the pursuit of convenience enabled by digital technology.

Cracking the Bro Code; This book, "Cracking the Bro Code," presents an ethnographic study of sexism and racism in contemporary computing cultures, arguing that transforming the field's hostile environment can change who produces technology and the core values of its production.

Sheltering: Care Tactics for Ethnography Attentive to Intersectionality and Underrepresentation in Technoscience; This article introduces "Sheltering," a set of ethnographic care tactics inspired by "black boxing" and "strong objectivity," designed to protect underrepresented collaborators in technoscience research while protesting epistemic and social injustice.

Introduction: Caring for equitable relations in interdisciplinary collaborations; This introduction to a special section explores the growing trend of collaborative research between STS and STEM scholars, using a feminist politics of care to transform tensions in these collaborations into resources for envisioning more equitable interdisciplinary work.

Negotiating boundaries: an intersectional collaboration to advance women academics in engineering; Drawing on data from the LATTICE program, this paper uses ethnography to examine how a diverse group of women worked across social and professional identities to support early-career women in academic engineering, offering actionable strategies for building coherent communities.

SIMPLE: a sequential immunoperoxidase labeling and erasing method; This paper describes SIMPLE, a novel sequential immunoperoxidase labeling and erasing method that enables the simultaneous visualization of at least five markers within a single paraffin-embedded tissue section by using an alcohol-soluble substrate and a rapid antibody dissociation technique.

Electrocardiographic diagnosis of acute coronary occlusion myocardial infarction in ventricular paced rhythm using the modified Sgarbossa criteria; In a retrospective case-control study of patients with ventricular paced rhythm, this investigation found that the modified Sgarbossa criteria had significantly higher sensitivity than the original criteria for the electrocardiographic diagnosis of acute coronary occlusion myocardial infarction.

Serial multiple antigen colocalization in paraffin-embedded tissue; This paper describes a method for serial multiple antigen colocalization in paraffin-embedded tissue, addressing the limitations of traditional methods like multi-color immunofluorescence to provide insights into cellular biochemistry and protein interactions.

Bystander intervention in out-of-hospital cardiac arrest; This commentary on a study of out-of-hospital cardiac arrest outcomes in Japan highlights the importance of bystander intervention, noting that arrests in public areas had the best outcomes due to higher rates of witnessed events and public-access defibrillator use.

Dephosphorylation of β-arrestin 1 in glioblastomas; Using immunohistochemistry and Western blot analysis on human glioma samples, this study found that β-arrestin 1 is dephosphorylated in glioblastomas compared to nonneoplastic brain tissue, suggesting a potential role for its altered phosphorylation status in gliomagenesis.

Musculoskeletal, airway, and vascular injuries in the patient with nonjudicial hanging: A narrative review for the emergency clinician; This narrative review investigates the frequency of musculoskeletal, neurologic, airway, and vascular injuries in patients following non-judicial hanging events to help emergency clinicians anticipate and manage potential injuries.

Comparison of Deep Learning Approaches for Conversion of International Classification of Diseases Codes to the Abbreviated Injury Scale; This study compares the accuracy of feedforward neural networks and neural machine translation models for converting International Classification of Diseases codes to the Abbreviated Injury Scale, a crucial step for standardizing trauma injury research.

Cluster analysis for gene expression data: a survey; This paper provides a survey of clustering techniques used for analyzing gene expression data from DNA microarrays, a crucial first step in revealing natural structures and identifying interesting patterns within the massive datasets.

Wavecluster: A multi-resolution clustering approach for very large spatial databases; This paper proposes WaveCluster, a novel clustering approach for very large spatial databases that uses wavelet transforms to efficiently detect clusters of arbitrary shape at different resolutions, while being insensitive to noise and data order.

A survey on causal inference; This paper provides a comprehensive survey of causal inference methods under the potential outcome framework, categorizing and reviewing both traditional statistical methods and recent machine learning-based approaches for estimating causal effects from observational data.

WaveCluster: a wavelet-based clustering approach for spatial data in very large databases; This paper proposes WaveCluster, a novel and efficient clustering approach for very large spatial databases that utilizes the multiresolution property of wavelet transforms to effectively identify arbitrarily shaped clusters at different levels of detail.

Representation learning for treatment effect estimation from observational data; This paper proposes SITE, a deep representation learning method for estimating individual treatment effects that simultaneously preserves local similarity and balances data distributions by focusing on hard samples in each mini-batch.

Chart-RVR: Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards for Explainable Chart Reasoning; This paper presents Chart-RVR, a framework that fine-tunes Large Vision-Language Models for chart reasoning by using reinforcement learning with automatically verifiable rewards, resulting in improved robustness, explainability, and state-of-the-art performance.

COCO-Tree: COmpositional Hierarchical COncept Trees for Enhanced Reasoning in Vision Language Models; This paper presents COCO-Tree, a novel approach that improves the compositional reasoning of vision language models by augmenting their outputs with neurosymbolic concept trees learned from large language models, significantly boosting performance on several compositionality benchmarks.

KDD 2025 Panel on AI for Science; This KDD 2025 panel will examine the opportunities and challenges in designing cutting-edge AI models for scientific discovery and highlight the transformative potential of cross-disciplinary partnerships in shaping the future of both AI and science.

AI and Science Day; This special day at KDD 2025 will host a series of talks by leading experts to discuss the transformative potential of AI in scientific discovery and the challenges that must be addressed to realize this potential.

Improving Group Robustness on Spurious Correlation via Evidential Alignment; This paper proposes Evidential Alignment, a novel framework that leverages uncertainty quantification to mitigate reliance on spurious correlations in deep neural networks, thereby improving out-of-distribution robustness without requiring external group annotations.

The UVA/PADOVA type 1 diabetes simulator: new features; This paper describes the development of a new version of the UVA/PADOVA Type 1 Diabetes Simulator, which incorporates new insights into the nonlinearities of insulin action and glucagon kinetics in the hypoglycemic range.

In Silico Preclinical Trials: A Proof of Concept in Closed-Loop Control of Type 1 Diabetes; This paper presents a proof of concept for in silico preclinical trials using a realistic computer simulation environment to test closed-loop control algorithms for an artificial pancreas in type 1 diabetes, demonstrating its value in accelerating development and guiding clinical studies.

A randomized trial of closed-loop control in children with type 1 diabetes; In a 16-week randomized trial involving children aged 6 to 13 with type 1 diabetes, a closed-loop insulin delivery system resulted in a significantly greater percentage of time spent in the target glucose range compared to a sensor-augmented insulin pump.

Method, system and computer program product for real-time detection of sensitivity decline in analyte sensors; This patent describes a method, system, and computer program product for the real-time detection of sensitivity decline in analyte sensors, which is crucial for maintaining the accuracy of continuous monitoring systems.

Fully integrated artificial pancreas in type 1 diabetes: modular closed-loop glucose control maintains near normoglycemia; This paper presents clinical studies of a fully integrated, modular artificial pancreas system that demonstrated the ability to maintain near-normoglycemia and prevent extreme glucose excursions in both adolescents and adults with type 1 diabetes.

Capillary Ketone Monitoring–Guided Adaptation of Automated Insulin Delivery to Accommodate a Ketogenic Diet in an Individual With Type 1 Diabetes: Case Study and Literature Review; This case study reports on an individual with type 1 diabetes who used capillary ketone monitoring to manually adapt a closed-loop automated insulin delivery system, enabling the safe utilization of a ketogenic diet while minimizing ketosis and improving glycemic control.

Toward Personalized Decision Support Systems for Type 1 Diabetes: Integrating Psychobehavioral Factors and Glycemic Control; This article presents a framework for a personalized decision support system for type 1 diabetes that integrates psychobehavioral factors, such as individual treatment preferences, with glycemic control to provide optimized therapeutic advice.

Modeling Meal Absorption in Subjects Post-Roux-En-Y Gastric Bypass Surgery Leading to Post-Bariatric Hypoglycemia; This work aims to identify the most appropriate meal absorption model for subjects who have undergone Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass surgery by fitting various models to glucose rate of appearance data to better understand and simulate post-bariatric hypoglycemia.

Miniaturized Neural Networks for Deploying Fully Closed Loop Insulin Delivery Systems: A Pilot Study Featuring Flexible Meal Announcement Options; This pilot study assessed the safety and feasibility of a next-generation fully closed loop insulin delivery system that uses a miniature neural network, demonstrating improved time-in-range and reduced hypoglycemia compared to usual care in adults with type 1 diabetes.

Unified platform for monitoring and control of blood glucose levels in diabetic patients; This patent describes a unified and scalable system called the Diabetes Assistant (DiAs) platform, which provides monitoring and control of blood glucose levels for diabetic patients, ranging from long-term advisory functions to real-time automated closed-loop control.

Skin mechanical properties and modeling: A review; This article presents a comprehensive review of the mechanical properties of skin, covering various experimental testing methods and discussing its nonlinear, viscoelastic, and anisotropic behavior, as well as commonly used constitutive models.

Development of a finite element model for blast brain injury and the effects of CSF cavitation; This paper details the development of a finite element head and brain model to study blast-related traumatic brain injury, examining both dilatational and deviatoric responses and finding that CSF cavitation significantly increases negative pressures and shear strains.

Brain injuries from blast; This review focuses on five fundamental questions regarding brain injuries from blast, including the physical correlates, injury mechanisms in humans, and the challenges of clinically differentiating blast TBI from PTSD.

C4–C5 segment finite element model development, validation, and load-sharing investigation; This study details the development and validation of a highly detailed C4-C5 cervical spine finite element model, which incorporates advanced nonlinear material properties and demonstrates good biofidelity across various loading modes.

Cervical spine response in frontal crash; This study uses a detailed, validated human cervical spine finite element model to evaluate soft tissue response in frontal impacts, finding that disc strains were highest in the C4-C6 region and increased with crash severity.

Average Responses of Brain Displacement Under Rotational Loading for Computational Model Validation; This study addresses the challenge of validating computational brain models by creating robust biomechanical response corridors for brain displacement under rotational loading, using a dataset from six specimens and employing numerical techniques to account for experimental variations.

Cadaveric Biomechanical Comparison of Prepectoral and Submuscular Implant-based Breast Reconstruction; Using a cadaveric model and a 3D biomechanical tracking system, this study quantified the mechanical impact of breast implant placement, finding that prepectoral placement resulted in significantly less deformation of the pectoralis major muscle during shoulder movements compared to submuscular placement.

Brain injury metrics and their risk functions in frontal automotive collisions; This study developed and evaluated injury risk functions for traumatic brain injuries of varying severity (AIS 1-4+) based on FEA-derived metrics and head rotational kinematics from real-world frontal automotive collisions.

Cervical vertebral and spinal cord injuries in rollover occupants; Using national crash data, this study examined how different types of cervical spine injuries in rollover occupants vary with factors like sex, seat belt use, and ejection status, comparing these patterns to non-rollover crashes.

E-211 Surgeon perception of navigation difficulty may lay with 3D anatomical centerline features; This study evaluated objective anatomical metrics from CTA images of thrombectomy cases to determine which features, such as arch type or carotid tortuosity, best correlate with a surgeon's perception of navigational difficulty.

Design and validation of a tool for neurite tracing and analysis in fluorescence microscopy images; This paper describes the design and validation of a semiautomatic neurite tracing technique for fluorescence microscopy images, which was found to be more reproducible and significantly less labor-intensive than fully manual delineation.

MoDL: Model-based deep learning architecture for inverse problems; This paper introduces MoDL, a model-based deep learning framework for solving inverse problems that explicitly incorporates the forward model, allowing for a smaller network with fewer parameters and reduced demand for training data compared to direct inversion approaches.

Accelerated dynamic MRI exploiting sparsity and low-rank structure: kt SLR; This paper introduces kt SLR, a novel algorithm for reconstructing dynamic MRI data from undersampled k-t space by posing the problem as a spectrally regularized matrix recovery problem, which simultaneously determines the temporal basis functions and their spatial weights.

Design of steerable filters for feature detection using canny-like criteria; This paper proposes a general, truly 2D approach for designing steerable filters for feature detection by optimizing a Canny-like criterion, yielding operators with closed-form expressions and better orientation selectivity than classical methods.

Blind compressive sensing dynamic MRI; This paper proposes a novel blind compressive sensing framework to recover dynamic magnetic resonance images from undersampled measurements by modeling the signal as a sparse linear combination of basis functions from a large dictionary, which is estimated simultaneously with the sparse coefficients.

Accelerating 3D radial MPnRAGE using a self‐supervised deep factor model; This paper develops a self-supervised and memory-efficient deep factor model for reconstructing 4D non-Cartesian MRI data, which represents a series of 3D multicontrast images using a neural network conditioned by inversion time and learned directly from k-space data.

Association of Contrast Enhanced Dual Energy CT-derived Pulmonary Arterial Tree-to-Lung Ratio (ArtLR) With COPD; Using dual-energy CT and a deep learning algorithm, this study developed and automated the calculation of a pulmonary-arterial-to-lung ratio (ArtLR) and found it to be significantly correlated with airway-to-lung ratio and other markers of COPD.

Motion-compensated cardiac MRI using low-rank diffeomorphic flow (DMoCo); This paper introduces DMoCo, an unsupervised motion-compensated image reconstruction algorithm for free-breathing 3D cardiac MRI that uses a low-rank model to compactly represent the family of diffeomorphisms that describe cardiac motion.

Fast and ultra-high shot diffusion MRI image reconstruction with self-adaptive Hankel subspace; To accelerate the reconstruction of high-resolution multi-shot diffusion weighted images, this paper proposes a method that decomposes the huge 2D block Hankel matrix into small 1D low-rank Hankel matrices from each k-space readout line, addressing the issue of variant low-rankness across k-space.

Accelerating Quantitative MRI Using Subspace Multiscale Energy Model (SS-MuSE); This paper proposes SS-MuSE, a method that accelerates quantitative MRI by generalizing a plug-and-play multi-scale energy-based model to a regularized subspace recovery setting, which jointly regularizes the 3D multi-contrast spatial factors for computationally efficient reconstruction.

Episimdemics: an efficient algorithm for simulating the spread of infectious disease over large realistic social networks; This paper describes EpiSimdemics, a scalable parallel algorithm designed to simulate the spread of infectious diseases in large, realistic social contact networks of up to 100 million individuals by exploiting the semantics of disease evolution and propagation.

Extended mapping and exploration of the vanadium dioxide stress-temperature phase diagram; By exploiting the superior mechanical properties of VO2 micro/nanocrystals, this study maps the stress-temperature phase diagram over a vastly extended range, revealing new structural and electronic aspects at high-strain states and demonstrating the material's potential for active strain engineering.

Generation and analysis of large synthetic social contact networks; This paper describes "first principles" based methods for generating synthetic, national-scale social contact networks by combining real-world data with behavioral theories to model every individual in the US population and their daily activities.

Commentary on Ferguson, et al.,“Impact of non-pharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) to reduce COVID-19 mortality and healthcare demand”; This paper provides a commentary on the influential Imperial College COVID-19 modeling report, discussing a coarse taxonomy of epidemic models and exploring the context and significance of various models in analyzing the pandemic.

The distance-2 matching problem and its relationship to the MAC-layer capacity of ad hoc wireless networks; This paper models the problem of determining the maximum MAC-layer capacity in ad hoc wireless networks using RTS/CTS protocols as the maximum Distance-2 Matching problem on the underlying graph and presents efficient approximation algorithms.

Equivalence hypergraphs: Dpo rewriting for monoidal e-graphs; This paper gives a categorical semantics to e-graphs using enriched monoidal categories and presents a sound and complete combinatorial representation based on a generalization of hypergraphs, enabling double-pushout rewriting for these structures.

Deutschland und seine Bundesländer: Spannende Materialien für einen abwechslungsreiche n Unterricht (3. und 4. Klasse); This e-book offers a variety of engaging materials, including tasks, puzzles, and games, to teach third and fourth-grade students in Germany about the country's 16 federal states, geography, and history in a playful and action-oriented way.

Towards an information-theoretic framework for multiple sequence alignment sub-sampling; This article develops an information-theoretic framework for multiple sequence alignments based on sub-sampling, defining a potential that quantifies the expected drop in variation of information between pairs of sites when rows are removed.

Novel multi-cluster workflow system to support real-time HPC-enabled epidemic science: Investigating the impact of vaccine acceptance on COVID-19 spread; This paper presents MacKenzie, a novel HPC-driven multi-cluster workflow system that was used to configure and execute fine-grained, US national-scale epidemic simulations in real-time to support policymakers during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The relational machine calculus; This paper presents the Relational Machine Calculus, a simple, foundational model of first-order relational programming derived from the Functional Machine Calculus, which exhibits a latent duality that gives rise to a sound and complete calculus for string diagrams of Frobenius monoids.

Subgoals, context, and worked examples in learning computing problem solving; This study investigated whether having introductory CS students generate their own subgoal labels for a programming task was more effective than being given them, finding mixed results that depended on other features of the instructional materials.

Khan academy gamifies computer science; This paper critically analyzes how Khan Academy has incorporated gaming elements into its computer science learning platform by mapping the literature on motivational processes to popular games to evaluate the success of their gamification efforts.

Measuring cognitive load in introductory CS: adaptation of an instrument; This paper reports on a study that adapts a previously developed instrument to measure the intrinsic, extraneous, and germane components of cognitive load in an introductory computer science context, a necessary step for designing instruction that minimizes cognitive overload.

Subgoals help students solve Parsons problems; This study found that introductory programming students who were given subgoal labels performed statistically better on a Parsons problem assessment for learning while loops compared to groups that did not receive or had to generate their own labels.

Reducing withdrawal and failure rates in introductory programming with subgoal labeled worked examples; This study implemented subgoal-oriented instruction throughout a semester-long introductory programming course and found that it significantly reduced withdrawal and failure rates and improved student performance compared to typical instruction.

ICER 2025: Call for Attendance; This is a call for attendance for the ACM International Computing Education Research (ICER) Conference to be held in Charlottesville, Virginia, USA, from August 3rd to 6th, 2025.

ICER 2025 Call for Participation; This is a call for participation inviting attendees to the 21st ACM Conference on International Computing Education Research (ICER), to be held from August 3-6, 2025, at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville.

How Good are Large Language Models at Generating Subgoal Labels?; This work explores whether ChatGPT can be used to generate high-quality subgoal labels for introductory programming curricula, finding through qualitative analysis that Large Language Models can effectively assist instructors in this time-intensive task.

Curriculum for a Comprehensive Statewide In-Service CS Teacher Training Program; This paper explains the curriculum development process of a comprehensive, five-course, graduate-level program designed to train in-service teachers with little prior experience to teach computer science in grades 5-12.

Panel Session: A Vision for the Next 15 Years of Computing Education; This panel session will present and discuss the final report of an NSF-sponsored workshop that created a vision for the next 15 years of computing education, engaging attendees in a discussion about the field's future direction.

Identifying the best machine learning algorithms for brain tumor segmentation, progression assessment, and overall survival prediction in the BRATS challenge; This study assesses state-of-the-art machine learning methods from the International Brain Tumor Segmentation (BraTS) challenge for glioma segmentation, progression assessment, and overall survival prediction using multi-parametric MRI scans.

Selection of a convolution function for Fourier inversion using gridding (computerised tomography application); This paper compares various convolving functions for the gridding technique in Fourier inversion, showing that a new function can improve upon the prolate spheroidal wave function in some circumstances for applications like computerized tomography.

Fast spiral coronary artery imaging; This paper describes a flow-independent method for imaging coronary arteries within a single breath-hold on a standard MRI scanner using interleaved spiral k-space scanning, cardiac gating, and fat suppression.

Simultaneous spatial and spectral selective excitation; This paper describes the design and implementation of a single excitation pulse that is simultaneously selective in both space and resonant frequency, enabling rapid water and fat imaging free of chemical shift artifacts.

Coronary Angiography with Magnetization‐Prepared T2 Contrast; This paper describes a magnetization-prepared, T2-weighted sequence that, when combined with lipid suppression and a multi-slice spiral acquisition, improves the visualization of coronary arteries by suppressing muscle and venous structures within a single breath-hold.

Evaluating Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Progression Assessment Patterns in Routine Clinical Practice Among Patients with Newly Diagnosed Multiple Myeloma; This study evaluates racial and ethnic disparities in the patterns of disease progression assessment among patients with newly diagnosed multiple myeloma in a routine clinical practice setting.

Demonstration of Interoperability Between MIDRC and N3C: A COVID-19 Severity Prediction Use Case; This study investigated the potential for interoperability between the MIDRC imaging resource and the N3C clinical record resource by using a COVID-19 severity prediction use case, successfully demonstrating patient-level matching and data integration.

Systems and methods for magnetic resonance image reconstruction with nonconvex single value decomposition; This patent describes a computer-implemented method for reconstructing undersampled MRI data by using an image model, such as ADMM with non-convex low rank regularization, and an iterative optimization process to converge to an accurate output image.

A retraced spiral strategy with semi‐automatic deblurring for volumetric thermometry; This paper develops and validates a 3D MRI-thermometry technique for transcranial MR-guided focused ultrasound using a stack of retraced in-out spirals and a minimized energy deblurring strategy to accurately monitor temperatures during insonation.

Variable‐flip‐angle 3D spiral‐in‐out turbo spin‐echo imaging using concomitant gradient compensation and echo reordering at 0.55 T; This paper develops a single-slab 3D spiral turbo spin-echo imaging sequence for a 0.55T scanner that achieves 1-mm3 isotropic whole-brain T2-weighted imaging with high scan efficiency through interleaved spiral-in-out trajectories, variable-flip-angle refocusing, and concomitant-field compensation.

Structural vibration control using high strength and damping capacity shape memory alloys; This chapter reviews the use of high strength and damping capacity shape memory alloys in passive vibration control devices for civil structures, highlighting their potential for energy dissipation and re-centering to protect against dynamic hazards like earthquakes.

Hysteresis Identification Using Extended Preisach Neural Network; This paper introduces the Extended Preisach Neural Network, a universal adaptive model with two hidden layers that can simulate both rate-independent and rate-dependent hysteresis with congruent or non-congruent, symmetric or asymmetric loops.

Neural network software for dam-reservoir-foundation interaction; This paper describes a software called "Neuro-modeller" that uses artificial neural networks to model the nonlinear hysteretic response of concrete gravity dams under earthquake loading, including reservoir and foundation interactions.

Universal hysteresis identification using extended Preisach neural network; This paper introduces the Extended Preisach Neural Network, an adaptive universal model for hysteresis that uses two hidden layers and a hybridized training algorithm to simulate both rate-independent and rate-dependent hysteresis with congruent or non-congruent, symmetric or asymmetric loops.

Seismic Performance Assessment of Steel Frames Upgraded with Shape Memory Alloy Re-centering Dampers for Passive Protection of Structures Subjected to Seismic Excitations Using …; This study investigates the performance of a super-elastic memory alloy re-centering damper (SMARD) using high-performance NiTiHfPd SMA bars to improve the seismic response of steel frame structures subjected to multi-level earthquake hazards.

Exploring the Impact of Mastery Grading on Student Performance; This paper discusses the evolution of a mastery grading system in a Calculus I course and investigates its impact on student grade distribution and subsequent performance in Calculus II compared to traditionally graded courses.

Exploiting a Grading Option to Measure Mathematics Confidence of Engineering Students; This study aims to identify patterns in engineering students' choice of credit/no-credit grading options for applied mathematics courses by correlating survey data on math confidence with registrar data on grades, GPA, and demographics.

Impact of Covid-19 on Applied Mathematics Courses for Engineering Students; This study investigates the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on Applied Mathematics courses for engineering students at the University of Virginia, aiming to identify which students were most affected and to understand their comfort level with online teaching.

Novel computational mathematical algorithms for structural optimization using graph-theoretical methods; This paper proposes five novel topological algorithms based on graph-theoretical methods to optimize the conditioning of structural flexibility matrices, demonstrating that these methods can remarkably reduce round-off errors in numerical simulations.

A novel passive structural control device using high-performance NiTiHfPd material; This study proposes and analyzes a super-elastic memory alloy re-centering damper (SMARD) that uses high-performance NiTiHfPd SMA bars, showing through nonlinear time history analyses that it can enormously mitigate the dynamic response of steel frame structures under various seismic hazards.
